talk.start.para: —I inform the Senate that the Governor-General on 7 May of this year made the following appointments: Mr Sinclair, Minister for Defence; Mr Killen, Vice- President of the Executive Council; Mr Fife, Minister for Aviation; Mr Macphee, Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations; Senator Peter Baume, Minister for Education; Mr Hunt, Minister for Transport and Construction; Mr Viner, Minister for Defence Support; Mr N. A. Brown, Minister for Communications; Mr McVeigh, Minister for Home Affairs and Environment; Mr Wilson, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs; Mr Carlton, Minister for Health; and Mr Hodges, Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

speech.para: The revised representation arrangements in this place are as follows: I will represent the Prime Minister, the Vice-President of the Executive Council and the Minister for Trade and Resources; Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will represent the Treasurer, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Science and Technology; Senator Durack will represent the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Defence Support and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; Senator Chaney will represent the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the Minister for Primary Industry and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations; Senator Peter Baume will represent the Minister for Health, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Minister for Communications and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment; and Senator Messner will represent the Minister for Transport and Construction, the Minister for Aviation, the Minister for the Capital Territory and the Minister for Administrative Services.

I inform the Senate also that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is undertaking a visit to the United States of America, Canada, Japan and the Republic of Korea from 15 to 26 May 1982. Mr Fraser will be visiting the United States at the invitation of President Reagan with whom he will be holding discussions. He will also be holding discussions with the Canadian Prime Minister, the Prime Minister of Japan and the President of the Republic of Korea . During Mr Fraser's absence from Australia Mr Anthony will be Acting Prime Minister. Mr Fraser will be accompanied by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) and during his absence Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle is Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs.

I will be departing after Question Time on Thursday for a visit to France, Austria and the United Kingdom. I will be attending the annual ministerial meeting of the International Energy Agency governing board in Paris and holding discussions on energy matters in the United Kingdom and Vienna. I will be returning to Australia on 3 June. The Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the House (Mr Killen) will be Acting Minister for National Development and Energy during my absence from Australia. The Attorney-General ( Senator Durack) will be Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate and will answer those questions which would normally be directed to me. The Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) will be undertaking a visit to the United Kingdom and Europe from 20 May to 11 June. He will be attending the International Labour Conference meeting in Geneva, on Mr Macphee's behalf, and holding discussions on transport matters in the United Kingdom. The Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) will be Acting Minister for Transport and Construction during Mr Hunt's absence.

talk.start.para: —I present the following petition from 34 citizens of Australia:

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between relatives close by blood or by marriage
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
i. intolerable behaviour;
ii. desertion for two years;
iii. separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.

speech.speaker: MASON

talk.start.para: —I present the following petition from 37 citizens of Australia:

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960 the church was not allowed to be consecrated and in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other Christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

speech.speaker: CHILDS

talk.start.para: —I present the following petition from 1,308 citizens of Australia:

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised- that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing. Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. All pension and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973. Reintroduction of Medibank; in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $ 200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

speech.para: To the President and Members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to close the Manual Assistance Telephone Exchange at Taree will place in jeopardy the existing services to telephone subscribers in the district by:
1. The loss of a local emergency '000' service being given to non-metropolitan telephone users in emergency conditions.
2. The loss of any local knowledge of the town and district being available to telephone users if this service is moved to a distant centre.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

talk.start.para: —Will the Minister for Finance confirm that, of all the organisations and departments funded through the Federal Budget, the Government Information Unit showed the greatest percentage increase in funding for this financial year over last year, an increase of some 330 per cent?

But I accept that in the case of the Government Information Unit there was some increase in activity. I will have the figures checked to see whether the figure cited is accurate. If I am able to give any further explanation I will see that that is done.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I will see that whatever information is available is given to the Senate. I will direct the attention of the appropriate Minister to the questions raised by Senator Button and as soon as I have the information available I will see that the Senate is advised accordingly.
—At Christmas time.

— It is not a matter of Christmas time or anything else. It is a matter of seeking the information from the appropriate Minister and providing it to the Senate. —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the Evidence (Amendment) Bill, passed by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in March 1982 with little public discussion, which was designed to avoid the effect of the 1981 High Court of Australia decision on the Kenbi land claim, which decision entitled the Aboriginal Land Commissioner to decide whether new regulations made by the Northern Territory Administrator were invalid because they were enacted for improper purposes. Will the Attorney-General confirm that these regulations enlarged the town area of Darwin to about four times the size of Greater London and included most of the land in the Cox Peninsula which was subject to the Kenbi land claim and that they are obviously designed to defeat the land rights claim? Does the Attorney-General agree that the Bill recently passed by the Northern Territory Administration purports to copy the 1979 New South Wales Evidence (Amendment) Act which in turn sought to destroy the rights of the courts to inspect government documents? Does not that legislation set aside the effect of the landmark case of Sankey v. Whitlam and other earlier decisions of the courts? Was not the New South Wales legislation unanimously condemned by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its 1979 freedom of information report? Does the Government consider that this action by the subordinate legislature of the Northern Territory will effectively shut out the common law rights of Aboriginals and other citizens to inspection of government documents and to seek the effective protection of the courts against arbitrary Executive action?

—Senator Missen has asked a number of questions concerning the Northern Territory legislation. The questions contain some statements of fact which I cannot confirm or deny. For instance, I do not know exactly what is the new definition of the Darwin town site, the area it covers and so on. I know that it is a fairly large area but I am not sure whether it is the size Senator Missen mentioned. Also, there are certainly some significant differences between the Northern Territory Evidence (Amendment) Act and the New South Wales legislation. I would have to refresh my mind to give a more detailed answer to the Senate than I am capable of giving at the moment to that aspect of the question. I think Senator Missen's main concern relates to the Kenbi land claim which, I understand, will be proceeding following the decision of the High Court . In regard to what evidence will be available in those proceedings and whether it could be shut out by the effect of the Northern Territory Evidence (Amendment ) Act, I refer Senator Missen to an answer I gave in the Senate in March this year in reply to a question asked by Senator Kilgariff. It followed expressions of concern by Senator Robertson and Senator Evans in regard to the matter. In that answer I made it clear that the effect of the Northern Territory legislation could not override the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights ( Northern Territory) Act and the evidentiary provisions contained in it and that therefore the legislation of the Northern Territory referred to will not have the inhibiting effect on the proceedings by the Aboriginal claimants in that case.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications: Is it a fact that as an associate member of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal , Professor Donald Gibson, whose duties with the Tribunal will cease with the presentation of the Tribunal's report on cable television by 30 June this year, is presently undertaking a two-week trip to a United States of America cable convention in Las Vegas at tribunal expense? Is it further true that the public hearings for the inquiry are complete and that the report is already substantially written? If so, what is the use of this trip and how is it justified?

—I know Professor Donald Gibson and I know of the eminence he has in his field of endeavour and of the work he does at Macquarie University. I am aware that he is presently not in Australia. If Senator Elstob says that he is in the United States at a cable convention, that may well be true. He certainly was not at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science meeting last week when a number of educational matters were being discussed. Whether he is away at Tribunal expense and whether the report is complete are matters about which I will have to seek further information, and this I will do for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. By what means does the Australian Bureau of Statistics obtain its information, particularly in relation to the operation of small businesses? Is it by confidential written inquiry or does an officer seek to obtain the relevant information by telephone inquiry? If by the latter method, what guarantee can the Minister give as to the confidentiality of the information so obtained?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I am unaware of any particular way in which the Bureau may seek its information. I imagine that it uses a variety of ways. Under its Act it does preserve confidentiality of information under certain circumstances. If Senator Bonner has a particular requirement for advice with regard to an individual survey or an individual company, I suggest that he give that information to me and I will pass it on to the Treasurer. If there is some difficulty the Treasurer may be able to deal with the matter. The Bureau of Statistics is, I think, recognised as a reputable instrument and one that does gain a variety of information through its survey processes. I am not aware of any particular difficulty in that connection. However, as I said, if there is a special difficulty I will see that it has the attention of the Treasurer.

—I preface my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate by reminding him of the question I asked him on 5 May this year concerning the probability that Argentina now has a nuclear weapons capability. The Minister will remember saying at that time that to his understanding Argentina had no nuclear facility or capacity. Is the Minister or the Government aware that the Federal Republic of Germany has been supplying sophisticated nuclear technology to the Argentine since the 1960s, in contravention of all international safeguards? Is the Minister aware that the reactors provided to Argentina by West Germany are of the most inefficient design available for the production of electricity but of the best design for providing waste for weapons grade plutonium? Can the Minister confirm that Argentina has continued to purchase nuclear technology from West Germany, including the expertise of former leading nazis, because the West Germans, by their own obscene and boastful admissions, do not insist on international safeguards? Does this not mean that Argentina could well be close to having the capacity to explode a nuclear device ? Why is the Government so seemingly ill-informed on these matters? Is the Minister aware that neither Euratom nor the International Atomic Energy Agency has any record of any transactions between West Germany and Argentina? Finally, I ask: Will the Australian Government summon the German Ambassador to Australia and demand that he obtain an explanation of how West Germany has flouted all of these nuclear safeguards?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Senator Chipp asked seven questions. The Federal Republic of Germany has denied emphatically that it has acted outside the safeguards requirements. It insists that it is complying at all times with the Euratom Treaty, the London Suppliers Group guidelines and the International Atomic Energy Agency. That has been confirmed publicly by the Energy Commissioner of the European Economic Community, Count Davignon. Argentina has had a 335-megawatt pressurised heavy water reactor in operation since 1974, supplied by the FRG, and a 600-megawatt CANDU reactor is due to come on stream next year. A 680-megawatt pressurised heavy water reactor, supplied by Germany, is under construction and due to be operational in the late 1980s. Although Argentina is a party to neither the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty nor the Treaty of Tlatelolco, it has accepted IAEA safeguards on all known operating facilities. This, I should add, does not include the reprocessing plant which is not yet operational. Argentina has stated that it has not joined the NPT because it is discriminatory.

answer.para: Argentina says that the plutonium produced will be sold for use in fast breeder reactors and that its reprocessing program has been built up solely with indigenous technology. The Australian Safeguards Office made some comments on the British Broadcasting Corporation program that has been critical on this matter. It said that, while heavy water reactors have advantages over other reactor types in producing plutonium, other interpretations might be put upon Argentina's decision. They are: Heavy water reactors can be operated on natural uranium without dependence on foreign enrichment and the extra plutonium could be useful in a thermal recycling program designed to encourage efficient fuel utilisation. Plutonium from power reactor fuel is not suitable for explosive purposes.

The Australian Safeguards Office said also that the fuel's long residence time in the reactor, essential for economic power production, would produce significant quantities of plutonium isotopes higher than the plutonium 239 weapons grade. To reduce the residence time to the maximum 239 production in a power reactor not only would result in uneconomical performance but also would be readily detected by safeguards measures, particularly in the case of pressurised reactors. Based on the capacity of the reprocessing plant, the Australian Safeguards Office estimates that it would take four years to produce a significant quantity of reactor grade plutonium and longer for weapons grade. That is the information I have, supplied by the Australian Safeguards Office, my own advisers and the Energy Commissioner of the European Economic Community, Count Davignon. In the course of the next 10 days I will be talking to Count Davignon and visiting the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna. I will be discussing, amongst other things, these matters.

I did say that I was not aware of any evidence that Argentina had weapons capability. Of course I was aware that it had nuclear power capacity for peacetime generation. Australia will be as eager as any other country to ensure that nations such as Argentina do not infringe the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty. We will be keeping a close scrutiny over the situation and I repeat that I will be discussing with the International Atomic Energy Agency the necessity for--

talk.start.para: —You would not be the best advocate.

—The fact is that Australia at this moment, through the Australian Safeguards Office, is the best advocate of the strongest nuclear safeguards in the world. Australia set up Mr Justice Fox as its ambassador-at- large to search the world to find how we could improve nuclear safeguards. I take it that Senator Georges would not be criticising Mr Justice Fox, whose appointment was made by the Whitlam Government. Australia is renowned throughout the world as having the strongest nuclear safeguards. Of course there is always more to be done, more to be investigated and more vigilance to be carried out. We will pursue that course.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question because everything the Minister has just said directly contradicts the information given in what I regarded as a magnificent Four Corners program which contained quotations from technical experts who gave evidence which, at least to me, was worrying. I ask the Minister: In view of those contradictions, will he ask his Department to get the transcript of that Four Corners program and provide the Senate with the Australian Government's reaction to the concern expressed on that program and the statements made by West German Ministers and by international experts on the question of Argentina's nuclear capability?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I would be very happy to get hold of the transcript. I did not see the program. I would be very happy to have the transcript examined by not only my own Department and its technical officers but also the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, the Australian Safeguards Office and any others who are interested. The information I gave to Senator Chipp and to the Senate is from expert sources. The Australian Safeguards Office and the Atomic Energy Commission are expert bodies. I do not say that any pronouncement is infallible, because there must always be constant vigilance on this matter. I have given the information provided to me and I take it that the BBC program which has given rise to these comments was part also of the Four Corners program. I believe that any divergence of opinion by the experts ought to be made known to the public. In no way am I here as a defender of what Argentina is doing or as a defender of any nation that may be taking liberties with safeguards. It is our job to see that all nations observe those safeguards sedulously.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services by saying that no doubt he will remember the statement made by Mr Newman during the last week that some politicians in this country are associated with criminal activities. As this statement places all politicians under a cloud-I believe this is something that Senator Jessop mentioned recently, and I and many other politicians do not appreciate it one little bit-will the Minister advise the Senate of the names of those politicians thought to be so associated? If not, can he say whether the Minister meant State politicians or Federal politicians?

—There has been some discussion in the newspapers about this item . I noticed a Press report from our colleague Senator Jessop on the matter. Other than that, I have not seen any report specifically involving Mr Newman. Nevertheless, I think the best thing I can do in the circumstances is to refer the question to the Minister and ask him to bring down an early reply for Senator Townley.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is Australia obliged to pursue a national policy implementing the 1958 International Labour Organisation Convention No. 111 on discrimination in employment and occupation? How many cases of discrimination in employment or occupation on the grounds of sex or religion have been dealt with by State and Territory committees helping to carry out this international obligation? Does the Minister agree that the program should be vigorously pursued to remove such discrimination, whether it affects access to the most ordinary and common jobs or the highest occupation in our social and political system?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I think most honourable senators are aware of the work of the employment discrimination committees which have been established in all States of Australia for nearly 10 years. Their establishment followed the declaration in 1973 of a national policy to eliminate discrimination in employment and occupation. This was made following consultation with State governments, major employer organisations and the trade union movement. The fact that that policy was declared enabled the Australian Government to ratify International Labour Organisation Convention No. 111, which relates to discrimination in employment and occupation. I agree that this program should be pursued. It is a matter of concern when people are discriminated against, whether it is on the grounds established under the ILO Convention or on the other grounds which these committees deal with. I note that it is not merely the ILO grounds that are the concern of the committees but also discrimination on grounds such as age, disability, nationality, personal attributes, criminal record, medical record, trade union activities, marital status and sexuality.

answer.para: The committees are committees of distinguished citizens and they receive a large number of complaints. In the information provided for me by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, I have some figures for the claims which have been heard and to date they total more than 5,000. The figure which I have been given to December 1981 is 4,847. Of these, 2,524 came within the classes of conduct prescribed by the ILO Convention and 2,322 were for the other sorts of causes that I mentioned a few moments ago. Of the 2,524 complaints to December 1981 which come within the Convention, 1,407 were complaints of discrimination on the ground of sex. Others were for race, colour, religion, political opinion, national extraction and social origin. I have a table which may be of interest to honourable senators. Rather than waste a lot of time in Question Time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the contents of this table which will give more precise information in response to the question.

question.block.title: TAX INCENTIVE SCHEME FOR AUSTRALIAN FILMS

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen recent newspaper articles referring to the use of our tax incentives to finance foreign films, such as The Earthling and Arthur? Although the articles imply that foreign films are being financed largely by the new tax incentive scheme for Australian films, is that actually the case? Is it not really the case that foreign film groups are making use of tax concessions provided under the long-established section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act rather than under the new Division 10BA or section 23H? Do not such deductions for investment in foreign film companies making foreign films reduce the Australian investment capital available for genuinely Australian films?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I understand that the matter referred to by Senator Hamer has been brought to the attention of the Treasurer. I understand also that the reported arrangements as outlined do not involve the use of the recently introduced income tax concessions for capital investment in Australian films but are more likely to involve film production expenditures in respect of which deductions are sought under the general deduction provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act; that is, section 51. I think whether any benefits flow to the Australian film industry from investment in the production of foreign films in Australia is a matter that could have different interpretations in different circumstances. Undoubtedly in some circumstances there could be advantages to the Australian film industry and in others it could be quite the reverse. If Senator Hamer has some interest in pursuing this matter I could seek advice from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. But I think the general response to the article to which he referred is that it is not the new concessions that have been used in the instances that he outlined but rather the general deduction under section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

question.block.title: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION: APPOINTMENT OF GENERAL MANAGER

talk.start.para: —I draw to the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications an advertisement which appeared in newspapers on 9 May calling applications for the position of General Manager of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Does the advertisement offer the successful applicant a term of seven years with eligibility for reappointment? Did the report of the Dix Committee of Review on the ABC recommend that, unlike the present General Manager, the chief executive should be an ex officio member of the board of management proposed for the ABC and that he or she should be appointed for a fixed term of seven years which was not renewable? Given these differences, was the Government consulted by the ABC before the advertisement was placed? If so, what position is a person applying for in answering this advertisement? Will the Government as a matter of urgency now finally give its response to the Dix Committee report on the ABC which was tabled more than 13 months ago?

—Although I have not seen the advertisement referred to by Senator Button I have a little information. I can confirm for the honourable senator that matters relating to the report of the Dix Committee are before the Government and at an appropriate stage the Government's decisions will be announced. Honourable senators will be aware that Sir Talbot Duckmanton, the present General Manager of the ABC, intends to retire later this year and that it has been proper and necessary for the advertisement to be placed. It is also true that the Dix Committee of Review of the ABC recommended that the chief executive of the ABC should be appointed for a non-renewable term of up to seven years. I am advised that on 8 May 1982 the ABC advertised for a General Manager and that the advertisement stated that the term of up to seven years provided eligibility for reappointment. To that extent Senator Button has drawn attention to an apparent inconsistency. I have been advised that the ABC has assured the Department of Communications that it is not trying to pre-empt the Government by advertising the General Manager's position in this manner. It is simply proceeding within the terms of existing legislation. It believes it can do nothing else. It is really a question of the Government determining its response to the Dix Committee report and making that known fairly quickly and, I hope, before this appointment is finalised.

question.block.title: FRIENDS OF THE EARTH: ANTI-URANIUM ACTIVITIES

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to the present occupation of the Honeymoon uranium deposit in South Australia by anti-uranium groups. Can the Government confirm reports that a training course to determine tactics for that occupation was conducted by the Communist Party's Camp Eureka outside Melbourne? Can the Government confirm also that the group Friends of the Earth conducted the course? Will the Minister further advise the Senate what funding the organisation Friends of the Earth has received in the way of a grant from the Federal Government in the 1981-82 financial year? Does this organisation account for its expenditure associated with this grant?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —On the first part of the question, I have not any details as to whether the training took place at the Communist Party's Eureka Camp. I will seek the information and endeavour to let the honourable senator know. The Friends of the Earth received a $5,000 Commonwealth grant in the current financial year. The applications are for administrative purposes and have to be matched on a dollar for dollar basis. As to the other question, until financial statements are provided by organisations it is not possible to determine whether Commonwealth funds granted to organisations have been expended on administrative purposes. I am not aware of the demand for accountability. I will seek information and let the honourable senator know.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs inform the Parliament when the working party on Aboriginal broadcasting was established and who served on it? Was the report of the working party presented to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Minister for Communications earlier this year? What were the recommendations of the working party? Is the report available for parliamentary or public scrutiny?
—Because of the detailed nature of the questions, I think it is appropriate that I ask the Minister whom I represent for a response.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister this question specifically because at the time he was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the report was presented to him. Now he does not remember it.
—The question asked by Senator Keeffe relates to the report, its present status, when it might be presented and in what fashion. I think it is proper that I refer it to my successor for his response.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce noticed the recent calls by the Council of Small Business Organisation of Australia for a full inquiry into small business in this country? Is the Council's contention that the Government presently lacks specific data about this important sector of Australian business correct? Will the Minister undertake to press for the inquiry called for, so that the role of small business in Australia may be better understood and so that enlightened assistance may be given where inquiry indicates the necessity in the national interest?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the Minister for Industry and Commerce is aware of the call by the Council of Small Business Organisation of Australia for an inquiry into small business in Australia. The Minister is also aware that the statistical data on businesses of different sizes is less complete than many would like. There have, however, been recent extensions to the economic census programs of the Australian Bureau of Statistics which have resulted in significant improvements to the range and quality of data on smaller enterprises and there are further improvements in prospect. There is no evidence that lack of information has inhibited the monitoring and evaluation of small business problems and policies. There is a slight dilemma here because it may be thought desirable to obtain more data on small firms; but, on the other hand, there are frequently complaints that small business is subjected to far too much paperwork . One has to balance the need for statistics against the need to minimise the burden on small businesses with respect to reporting requirements.

answer.para: The Minister has given some consideration to the inquiry which has been called for. In his view such an inquiry is not warranted at this stage. The specific problems and needs of small businesses have been subjected to formal inquiry on a number of occasions going back to the Wiltshire committee in 1971. Small business matters are monitored by the Small Business Advisory Council and the Bureau of Industry Economics as well as by a number of tertiary institutions. The Council of Small Business Organisation plays a very valuable part in all of these matters. These groups frequently communicate their findings to the Minister and have proved very effective in identifying and publicising the concerns of small business. While the Government acknowledges the vital role of small firms in the economy and will take all measures necessary to encourage the efficient development of the sector, it does not see another inquiry at this stage as advancing that end.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware that the latest figures from the Australian Electoral Office show that habitation reviews-a provision of the Australian Electoral Act-ceased in Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania in July 1981? It is now reported that they have now ceased to operate in the other three States. Does this mean that the current enrolment figures for Federal electorates are inadequate and unclear from the point of view of accuracy and equity? Further, is this change of procedure a change in Government policy or a process arising solely from cutbacks in public sector expenditure?
—I think Senator Gietzelt would agree that this is an appropriate question to be placed on notice for the Minister and I ask him to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is there evidence of any slippage in provisional tax payments this year? Will the Government give consideration to amending the late payment penalty from 10 per cent to at least a minimum of the higher of the current long term bond rate or 10 per cent, to deter a deliberate holding back of tax payments on account of high market rates of interest?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The most recent figures that we have been able to publish of transactions to the end of April show that the collection of provisional tax is slightly higher at this stage than it was at the same point last year. There does not seem to be any indication of slippage in the payment of provisional tax that could be related to interest rates or, for that matter, to any other reason. I think Senator Messner, on behalf of the Treasurer, indicated recently when dealing with legislation in this House that the Government has in hand a review of all the penalty provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. When that review is proceeding it is appropriate for all penalty provisions to be reviewed, and this is being conducted as a matter of some urgency. I shall refer to the Treasurer the interest of Senator Watson in the provisional tax penalties and draw to his attention the matter that has been raised. But, in a general way, all these things are subject to review, and I hope that some early consideration of them will be made.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Although the Minister has just taken up that position, I refer to an extraordinary exchange regarding the Curriculum Development Centre that took place in Estimates Committee B when he was the Minister representing the Minister for Education. What is the actual position with regard to the alleged savings in relation to the Curriculum Development Centre?

—It is not quite clear what information Senator Macklin is seeking in his question. The Curriculum Development Centre continues to exist. It has a statutory existence and as such it still has functions which it performs. The honourable senator will be aware that some of the materials which it has produced are still being sold and will still be produced, and that it continues to have a revolving function. He will also be aware of decisions of the committee on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which are that Commonwealth support for the Centre is to be wound down. How this is to be done and what the final method of operation of the Centre is to be are yet to be made known in detail. In fact the Government is still considering some of those details.

—I ask a supplementary question. I was seeking information about the amount of money that the Government, in its documentation of the committee on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, put against the CDC as being a saving. I want to know what has happened to that.
—I do not carry that kind of information, nor do I try to do so, as I think the honourable senator would accept. I shall seek the appropriate information for him.

—Has the Minister for Social Security seen the reported remarks today of Lieutenant Colin Lingard of the Salvation Army in New South Wales about the serious increase in the number of people seeking emergency aid and emergency relief in that State, in particular from the Salvation Army? This comes soon after the findings of the Victorian Emergency Relief Committee that we debated in this chamber two weeks ago and its claim that the greatest cause of the increase in need for such assistance was the disastrous levels of social security payments. Does the Minister consider, in light of the reports from a second State, that the Government should take some action? Does he still consider, as he has consistently done since he has had the portfolio, that the Commonwealth really has no place in the provision of emergency aid and that this matter should be given to the States?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I read those remarks attributed to Lieutenant Lingard in this morning's Press clippings just a couple of minutes ago during Question Time. I had not seen them before that time. As Senator Grimes points out, they are consistent with the claims that there is an additional requirement for emergency relief which has been put forward in Victoria over recent weeks and months. I do not accept that the requirement of emergency relief is something which is a direct function of what the honourable senator describes as the disastrous levels of social security payments. In fact, those payments in the main have been indexed to maintain their real value. There are, of course, exceptions to that but in the main they are so indexed.

answer.para: It does appear from the information which we have to hand that the increases in the numbers of those seeking emergency relief are related to matters other than the particular levels of pensions and benefits. The two areas where there have been significant increases in demand for emergency relief appear to be among those who are unemployed, particularly those who are unemployed for a significant period, and among those who are supporting parents. Of course, it is true that over the last 10 years there have been very significant increases in the numbers of those claiming benefits in both those categories. I think the major answer to those difficulties lies in the creation of as much employment as possible in Australia and, of course, in trying to do something about the social trends which are producing such a large number of supporting parents in the community.

It remains a fact on the Victorian evidence that the great bulk of pensioners and beneficiaries who receive assistance from my Department do manage on their benefits. I think the Victorian figure was that something like 6 per cent of these people might be seeking assistance. I certainly do not accept that for the generality of pensioners and beneficiaries there is an inability to live on the benefits which are provided. In regard to where responsibility lies for relief, it is true that until, I think, 1977 when this Government for the first time made some provision for emergency relief, emergency relief was always the concern of voluntary agencies and of State governments. At the time of the 1977 election a commitment of half a million dollars was made and that commitment has been met.

Senator Grimes correctly says that I have asserted that the responsibility for emergency relief ought to remain in the main that of State governments and voluntary agencies, the principal obligation of the Commonwealth being to look to the income maintenance system generally. In that regard I point out that as recently as a couple of years ago the States withdrew, at their insistence, from one of the areas of their traditional assistance, namely, the first six months of assistance to deserted wives. They thereby saved themselves, I think, some $ 30m and, I would have thought, freed up resources which might well have been used to improve State provision for social welfare. The Victorian Government, in fact, withdrew its direct assistance to emergency relief at about that time. This is a matter which will, I am sure, be the subject of Budget consideration both in the context of the general level of pensions and benefits and in the question of what provision ought to be made by the Commonwealth for emergency relief. It will certainly continue to be the subject of discussion between State governments and the Commonwealth Government. I think it is likely that I will continue to assert the view, which I have before, that that traditional area of the States' responsibility ought to continue to be met by them.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister has conceded that the large numbers of these people seeking emergency relief are the unemployed and the single parent pensioners who are, in fact, further below the poverty line as measured than other groups in the community and that the complaint of voluntary agencies like the Salvation Army and of the States is that the numbers of people needing emergency assistance are increasing and increasing considerably, does he not consider that these people whom the Commonwealth has already accepted responsibility for should receive further assistance from the Commonwealth if the Commonwealth benefits are inadequate? Should not the States receive further assistance from the Commonwealth because of the situation which arises out of these inadequate benefits?

—I do not propose to debate the matter in Question Time. It was part of my answer to point out that about 19 out of 20 beneficiaries and pensioners are living quite adequately on the social securities which are provided in that they are not the subject of these claims. In any event, the figures also show a very significant improvement in the situation of some categories of people, particularly the aged, who are dependent on my Department. I have noted the points made by Senator Grimes. I have also acknowledged that these are matters to be considered in the Budget context when one is looking at the level of pensions and benefits which are paid by the Department.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health.
—That is why our distinguished visitor left.
—I might be bloodied but I am not bowed. We won in Tasmania.
—You couldn't do anything about it.

—Senator Grimes invites me to tell honourable senators about it. I would like to take up his challenge because in my State the feeling on Saturday night in the tally room was as it was in 1975. Senator Grimes was not looking too happy at that stage.
—Too much celebration.

—Senator Grimes invites me to comment. My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and concerns the tar content of cigarettes. Does the Minister have any knowledge of the development of cigarette filters which effectively cheat the commonly used method of measuring tar in cigarette tobacco? Is he aware that the result is a lower tar reading, giving the smoker a false sense of security against the risks of cigarette smoking?

—May I begin by joining honourable senators in congratulating Senator Walters on the events of last Saturday in Tasmania. It is a result which we all welcome. If the honourable senator cannot move her neck because of the collar, we say that it has a certain je ne sais quoi about it. I do not have specific information about tar filters which are designed to cheat. I understand the honourable senator's concern that any tar filters which gave smokers a false sense of security or which led them to believe that they were incurring less health risk would be unacceptable. I think a newspaper story may have referred to these filters. I will try to follow up any details which are available and I will make the information known to Senator Walters as soon as I am able.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services to an article in today's Australian concerning the construction of a new national police college in Perth. Is it a fact that by choosing to build the college in Perth construction costs will be 10 times higher than they would have been for the Canberra alternative? Why has Perth been chosen as the site for such a national college, especially in view of its distance from Australia's major population centres? In view of the rather more central position of Adelaide and the depressed state of the building and construction industry in South Australia, will the Government give consideration to building the college in Adelaide?

—No doubt in all States there is a great deal of interest in having an important college such as this located in the respective capital city. I have no particular information about the '10 times' referred to by Senator Foreman which, I believe, he quoted from an article in the Australian. I will need to check that out to see whether it is correct. However, I am advised that the relocation of the Australian Police College has been under consideration by the Police Ministers' Council for some time. There was a meeting of that Council in Hobart in November last year and the Minister for Administrative Services undertook to raise the matter in Federal Cabinet and to report back to the next Council meeting, which will be held in Queensland this coming Friday. Accordingly, the matter is listed on that meeting's agenda for discussion then. I am further advised that the question of the relocation of the police college is to be placed on the agenda for the June Premiers Conference. No doubt there will be considerable fora available for persons of Senator Foreman's bent to put forward their particular views on this question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the Minister to an article in today's Courier-Mail in which a Brisbane hunger striker, Mrs Ana Voita, who has gone without food now for 27 days, is reported by her doctor to be only one week away from death. As the Minister no doubt is aware, Mrs Voita began her hunger strike to try to force the Romanian authorities to allow her brother to join her in Australia. A spokesman for the Romanian Embassy in Canberra has stated that Bucharest has been informed three times of Mrs Voita's hunger strike but that no answer has been given as to whether her brother will be allowed to leave the country. Can the Minister advise whether any further action can be taken in this matter to secure some definite information from Bucharest so that Mrs Voita may be spared from this obviously sincere but tragic situation?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I will answer instead of Senator Durack. I have some information from the Department of Foreign Affairs on this matter. The information may not be helpful but it will give the up to date position. The Department of Foreign Affairs is actively pursuing all courses open to it to encourage the Romanian authorities to permit Mrs Voita's brother to leave that country. Approaches are being made through the Romanian Embassy in Canberra and in Belgrade as well as directly to the Romanian Foreign Ministry in Bucharest. There is concern for the well being of Mrs Voita. It is certainly the hope of the Government that she can be dissuaded from pursuing this course of action.

answer.para: As the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, stated in the House of Representatives on 22 April, the use of the hunger strike technique is not the most likely way to overcome the problem of family reunion. Some success has been achieved in the past through repeated representations by the Australian Government to the Romanian authorities. We will continue our efforts to encourage the Romanian authorities to expedite family reunions on behalf of not only Mrs Voita but also other outstanding cases which have been approved for migration to Australia. I am afraid I am not able to give any more information. We are continuing our efforts at this end in the hope that the Romanian Government will assist also in this particularly tragic case.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the death of the Algerian Foreign Minister and his delegation in a plane crash near the Turkish-Iranian border two weeks ago. The first Iranian reports of the incident claimed that Iraq was responsible. However , consequent reports from Turkey and Iraq suggest that the plane was shot down by Iranian fighters soon after it crossed from Turkish to Iranian air space. As the Algerian Government is probably the government with the best credentials to negotiate a successful peace treaty between Iran and Iraq, can the Minister advise the Senate of the facts of this incident, which appears certain to prolong the war?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I will need to seek information on that matter. I will see that I give an early response to the Senate.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction: Is it a fact that since Australian National Railways took over Tasmanian railways from the State Government it has battled to upgrade the dilapidated and debilitated permanent way on a very limited budget? Is it a fact that Australian National derailments in Tasmania now average one per day, notwithstanding extensive speed restrictions in areas of unsafe track?
—One a day?

—Yes, one derailment a day in Tasmania. Are certain major users-in particular the wood chip plant operators-threatening, because of delays and unreliability due to derailments, to haul all logs by road, with the consequence of putting an extra 2,000 tonnes per day on the road along the north -west coast to the Tamar Valley and huge extra loads and traffic on other roads in northern Tasmania? I ask further: Will this cause a road and traffic crisis? If this is true, can the stringent requirements on Australian National be eased to enable an emergency upgrading program to be undertaken in the interests of safety and in the interests of the preservation of northern Tasmania's road system?

—I think all Australians would be concerned about the points raised by Senator Peter Rae in his question. Many of them are very detailed matters upon which I would need to get an up to date report. I think the particular interest focuses on the question of derailments. I am unable to confirm or deny the statistics cited by Senator Peter Rae. I will endeavour to obtain some information concerning that matter. The industrial ramifications of the points which the honourable senator made obviously raise significant questions about the future of Tasmania. In the light of the election results of last Saturday, no doubt such matters will come more sharply into focus as there will be more industrial activity in Tasmania as a result of the election of the new Liberal Government. I will refer the detailed matters raised by Senator Peter Rae to the Minister for Transport and Construction and endeavour to obtain an early reply.

—Is the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that in 1980 Australia was invited by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights Sub- committee on the Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities to ratify International Labour Organisation Convention No. 107-Indigenous and Tribal Populations, 1957? Is the Minister aware that my question on notice regarding this matter has remained unanswered since 23 September 1981? Can the Minister say whether the Government is refusing to ratify this Convention in order to avoid the risk that Aborigines will take the Government before the ILO Committee of Experts on the Application of Conventions and Recommendations?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I have no information on the matter. I can only suggest that I seek an early response to the question that has been on notice since last September. If any information is available with regard to the ratification, I will see that it is provided. As far as the last part of the question is concerned, I am unaware of any relationship between the matters that have been raised. However, if I can get an early response to the question on notice it may provide a reply to the question raised today.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the crisis facing the tuna fishing industry in South Australia? Can the Minister confirm that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's division of fisheries research has reported that the bluefin tuna population could collapse within five to six years? Does the Minister appreciate that as a result of earlier scientific advice South Australian tuna fishermen were encouraged to upgrade their fleets and that as a result of the present situation their investment in new equipment could be unwarranted? Is the Minister further aware that imports of tuna into Australia will have a serious effect on the economic viability of tuna fishermen in South Australia? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the action the Government intends to take to ensure that Australia's tuna fishing industry does not collapse and whether the Government will support industry moves to harvest other tuna stocks in the western Pacific?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Primary Industry is aware that there are very significant difficulties in the tuna fishing industry of South Australia. The problems which the industry faces, as is quite evident from the facts which are included in the honourable senator's question, really relate to the potential problem of the supply of tuna on the one hand and the problem of the world oversupply on the other hand. There is a complex of factors: There is the risk that the resource will not be available in the future for the local fishery and currently there are market problems which relate to world oversupply. This matter has been raised in the Senate on a number of occasions. I can confirm that the Minister is very much aware of the difficulties which Senator Jessop has raised.

answer.para: The current concern by scientists about the state of the southern bluefin tuna fishery results from further analysis of data on the fishery and from unprecedented record catches by Australian fishermen. The commercial decisions which were taken, and to which Senator Jessop referred, to upgrade the fleet were taken prior to the latest scientific assessment and were based on an assessment of market conditions at a time when prices were high. I understand that the tuna canneries are considering the preparation of applications for assistance in respect of protection against canned salmon and tuna imports. These applications will be closely examined by the Department when received.

The Department of Primary Industry, in conjunction with the States and industry , is examining the issues involved, including the need for the Australian tuna industry to diversify to other markets and to other tuna fisheries. In this respect grants have been made from the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account to develop tuna operations in waters off Queensland. As I said earlier, the problems are complex, they are multi-faceted and they will require the careful attention of both the Government and the industry.

question.block.title: COMMONWEALTH-NEW SOUTH WALES TASK FORCE ON DRUG TRAFFICKING

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —On 29 April Senator Jones asked me a question without notice relating to future volumes of the report of the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking. He asked whether the Minister would take steps to make sure that volumes 2 and 3 of that report are also made available to the Government and to the Leader of the Opposition in the same way as volume 1 was made available. I am advised that the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force reports directly to the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments. Volume 1 of the report was transmitted to both governments, as future volumes of the report will be. I am further advised that if it is considered inappropriate for future volumes of the report to be tabled in the Parliament the Government will give sympathetic consideration to any request for access from the Leader of the Opposition.

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I desire to refer to a matter which arose recently concerning the chef and the parliamentary refreshment rooms. This was a matter of some controversy while I was overseas, and I take the first opportunity of making a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented. The matter arose some time ago-indeed on 25 March 1982-when I was speaking on a motion to change the days and hours of meeting of the Senate. Towards the conclusion of my speech I made some off the cuff remarks concerning the obtaining of meals in the Parliament. I made the additional and marginally relevant point that the change of hours would enable members to take meals elsewhere, and I felt that this was certainly to their advantage. I see that my remarks led to an interjection by Senator Elstob which appears to be the major cause of distress to the chef and members of the staff of the parliamentary dining room. Taken in the context of the light-hearted debate which had preceded it, the interjection was understandable but, taken out of context, it could give offence to the staff.

speech.para: I was aware, at the conclusion of my remarks, that I had not entirely explained my concerns of a dietary nature, but as the matter was only marginally relevant to the subject of the debate I did not desire to proceed further at that time. However, as the Press subsequently picked up these remarks and took them out of context I feel that some explanation is necessary, particularly because the parliamentary chef appears to have some grounds for complaint. I see that, in the course of my remarks, I referred to having the food 'analysed' and I expressed the view that the meals that I had had in the parliamentary dining room had been 'absolutely outrageous'. On reflection, I feel that this was altogether too strong language and that what I should have said was that they were outrageous as far as my dietary requirements were concerned.

I should make it clear that I did not remove food from the Parliament to have it analysed, and it would be obvious that logistically that would have been a rather difficult undertaking. What I meant to say was that I had had the menus and type of food analysed by dietary experts and a dietitian whom I had consulted and had ascertained that the meals taken in the dining room and at committee meetings had a calorie content something like 50 per cent excessive and that, compared with meals available in Melbourne, their cholesterol content was something like 300 per cent. This was indeed a most unsatisfactory situation so far as I was concerned, and it was of concern to my medical advisers. As a result of this analysis, I made arrangements with the parliamentary dining room to obtain suitable food, and I point out that, in the course of my short speech, I acknowledged that the parliamentary dining room had been willing to fall into line with my requirements on the subject. Characteristically, the newspapers totally ignored this comment. I should emphasise that the meals supplied to me since that time have been quite satisfactory, and I have no complaint about them . However, the Press took it upon itself to resurrect these statements some five weeks later, after I had left the country, and obviously this has caused some unhappiness so far as the dining room staff is concerned.

My concern with the repetitiousness of meal menus, and with the fact that the same meals are provided for lunch and dinner, continues and is a matter that should concern the Joint House Committee. But I recognise the difficulties under which the parliamentary dining room has to work and, of course, I had no intention of criticising the chef for the efforts which he is making to provide reasonable meals.

I note that the Melbourne Herald chose to weigh in with an editorial on 30 April 1982 to suggest that senators should have more to do representing their constituents than to waste the time of Parliament 'complaining about the tucker' . I do not regard the question of parliamentary meals as trivial, or the health of members as unimportant, but I do object to the trivialisation of comments such as are contained in that editorial. I believe there are many more important things that ought to be attracting the attention of the Press and, in fact, I am happy to draw its attention to recent debates which were totally ignored by it, and in which it ought to be taking a substantial interest.

I have said that I do not regard these matters as trivial, and it is a pity that it is only when there is a sudden illness of a parliamentarian that any attention seems to be directed to the inadequacies of the lifestyle of members of this Parliament. Further to this, I want to say that I will certainly speak to the chef to reassure him that no personal criticism was intended. Otherwise, I have no intention of further commenting on the matter.

debate.sub1.title: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

proctext.para: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from Senator Mason proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

interject.para: Plans by the Commonwealth Government to encourage the early establishment in Australia of a nuclear industry, including enrichment of nuclear fuel and electric power through the use of nuclear reactors.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

speech.speaker: Mason Sen C.V.J.

talk.start.para: -In speaking to this matter of public importance dealing with plans by the Commonwealth Government to encourage the early establishment in Australia of a nuclear industry, including enrichment of nuclear fuel and electric power through the use of nuclear reactors, I will begin by sketching in briefly the recent history and likely prospects for the nuclear industry world wide. Much has happened and much has been learnt since those euphoric days of nearly 20 years ago when uranium was seen as the source of power for tomorrow. There was a frequently used phrase-that electric power would be almost too cheap to meter. What is now revealed by hindsight is a technology so hedged in with problems of the most serious kind as to be virtually impossible to bring into successful operation in any sincere way. The hardest headed business empires of the world are now abandoning it, in many cases after spending not thousands, not millions but billions of dollars. I repeat that experienced and major enterprises are cutting their losses, after enormous expenditures on nuclear power houses, to get out of nuclear power because of the difficulties and dangers it is now shown to represent and, most importantly of all, because of its sheer lack of economic competition with other sources of electric power in the world. To instance this I will mention a recent article in the Washington Post which stated:

speech.para: In one of the most dramatic and costly cancellations . . .
This is of nuclear power-

the Board of the Washington Public Power Supply System announced two months ago that it would terminate work on two of five nuclear power plants under construction, writing off the $2,250m already spent.

If we cannot understand what that means there must be something wrong with us. A responsible private enterprise authority in the United States of America, which has already spent over $2 billion on the first two of five nuclear power plants, has decided to write of the entire project and none of those plants will proceed . The article goes on to state:
In the case of the WPPS nuclear plants . . . construction costs of the five plants the utility had proposed building soared from $4,100m to nearly $23,800m.

That increase in cost is almost fourfold. The basic part of the problem which I think ought to appeal to governments and hard-headed business people everywhere is that what was supposed to be a cheap and economic form of electric power is not that at all. When one looks at recent, more realistic costings which, of course are very adequate-they are done by people actually involved in the scene, not people such as us who are merely speculating or thinking about it, but people who have actually costed carefully and know their figures are right-one finds that nuclear power is far more expensive than any other kind of power that can be produced. In saying that, one has to take into account the possibility of clean-up, such as at Three Mile Island which is costing over $1 billion, and the associated similar cost of decommissioning a nuclear power house when it reaches , as it must, the end of its useful life. In that case there are perhaps greater problems with far more radioactive materials than is the case with the contaminated water which is causing so much trouble in the Three Mile Island reactor. Referring to this subject further the article in the Washington Post continued:
The month before that cancellation was announced--
That is the one I mentioned first-

the Oklahoma Corporation Commission ordered that no further funds from customers of the Public Service Co. of Oklahoma be spent on the Black Fox nuclear power plant. The commission said that, notwithstanding $US200m already spent on it--
That is, the Black Fox plant-
the plant was 'no longer economically viable'.

The same day Standard and Poor's Corp. reduced the bond rating of the Public Service Co. of New Hampshire, raising additional questions about the fate of one of its two nuclear power plants at Seabrook, although work is continuing.
The overall picture is that in 1980 16 reactors were cancelled and 70 were delayed and in 1981 six were cancelled and 44 were deferred. The article in the Washington Post continued:
So bleak is the outlook that General Electric has said it expects no more domestic orders this decade--

I repeat that one of the major utility companies in the world making these plants expects no more domestic orders this decade. I will quote a statement made by a senior associate of a chemical engineering company at a meeting of chemical engineers last year. Mr John O. Sillin was reported as saying:

Nuclear power has become an investment with tremendous financial risks to utilities, and the utility industry itself is in such poor financial health it can no longer afford to purchase nuclear generating stations.
Mr Sillin added:
The cost of a 1200 megawatt nuclear unit going into service in the early 1990s will be over $US3,200m.

That is over $3 billion. The figure represents an almost tenfold increase in prices since the early 1970s. Some major questions ought to be posed. If experienced major enterprises in the United States are getting out of nuclear technology why is there now such strong urging in Australia to get into it? What is the reason for the abandonment of nuclear projects all over the world? Is there a reasonable demand for uranium oxide? Is there a demand for enriched uranium which, of course, is the main fuel for nuclear power houses? Lying behind all these questions is an even more basic question. Is the Commonwealth Government of Australia planning to get into nuclear technology and, importantly and significantly, the uranium enrichment industry?

There has been a great deal of equivocation and shilly-shallying over this point with no clear statements of what the Government has in mind. I feel sure that this evasion on the part of the Government is due in some measure to the fact that it knows, as a result of opinion polls, that the majority of Australians are opposed to nuclear power and certainly do not want a nuclear industry in this country. If there should be any doubt about that I point to a fact which seems obvious to all the Australian Democrats. In South Australia recently Mrs Heather Southcott was able to hold the seat of Mitcham for the Australian Democrats. I believe, and I am sure Mrs Southcott would agree with me , that this was due in no small amount to the fact that most people in South Australia do not want a nuclear industry, and they certainly do not want an enrichment industry in their own territory. This matter and its urgency, I believe, depend basically on an assessment of the Government's intentions. Is it really, behind the scenes, giving the go ahead to financial interests in the nuclear field to promote their industry within Australia?

I make no apologies in a matter so serious and important as this for quoting from a confidential leaked document which, of course, was never intended to reach my hands but which, because of that, gives a much franker indication of what is going on than the public utterances of the Government. This 25-page document purports to be the report of the interdepartmental committee set up last year to report on a review of the Atomic Energy Act and related matters. I am confident that it is indeed a copy of that document. If that is not the case I hope the Government will say so. In many places in this document the obvious assumption is that the Government is interested in pressing on with a nuclear industry in this country much more definitely and much more quickly than it has been prepared to announce to its citizens. In one of its early conclusions in the report the committee said:

. . . It has been concluded that the Atomic Energy Act 1953 is no longer an appropriate legislative basis for promotion, regulation and control of nuclear activities and development of an Australian nuclear industry. Effective promotion, regulation and control of nuclear activities and an Australian nuclear industry will require new legislation.
On page 10, this point is made:
the defence and security-related provisions of the Atomic Energy Act should not interfere with the envisaged commercial development of an Australian nuclear industry.

Envisaged by whom? That is the question we ask. Of course, there is only one answer-without doubt, the government which gave this committee its terms of reference. On page 12 the committee mentions the need for legislation to rationalise Australia's nuclear plans within our commitments under the non- proliferation treaties. The committee then says:
The legislation should be enacted as a matter of urgency--
I repeat, as a matter of urgency-
to provide a clear basis for meeting the Commonwealth's nuclear non- proliferation obligations which are a key element in obtaining public acceptance of developing a nuclear industry in Australia.

It is of some additional interest to the Australian Democrats that the problems of obtaining public acceptance of a nuclear industry in Australia are at least recognised, although I predict that they will turn out to be a good deal knottier than the Government and the proposed industry might expect. On page 19, this statement is made:
In view of the possible urgency associated with any decision on uranium enrichment, it may be necessary to pass specific legislation in that area as an interim measure.

It is not my intention to publicise information in this document beyond my purpose. However, it does include two other matters which are of public importance. They relate to the nature of the proposed enrichment industry and the possible mantle of secrecy under which it is presumably intended it might operate. On page 16 of the report the committee stated:

Since it is possible that a uranium enrichment industry in Australia would be largely owned and operated by private enterprise the reach of present Commonwealth law in that area will require careful assessment.
On page 15, it is stated:
Uranium enrichment technology is presently--
I think the words sought there are 'at present'-

the subject of a major commercial study in Australia and before a further stage of this feasibility study on establishment of a commercial enrichment facility in Australia could proceed, access to classified information would be required.
On page 17 the committee stated:
Australia incurs a responsibility to protect sensitive nuclear technology which arises within Australia; e.g. a new process of uranium enrichment.

Later on that page the committee says that special legislation is urged to protect that sensitive information. The Australian Democrats find all this worrying because we are concerned that a commercially motivated uranium enrichment industry in Australia, owned extensively or even substantially outside Australia, might be allowed to operate under a veil of secrecy which would at some time and with some future government permit enrichment to nuclear weapons grade material. I remain not satisfied that there are sufficient safguards yet written in or intended to overcome this problem. There are two major ingredients in natural uranium. By far the greater proportion is U238 which is in no way suitable for atomic bombs or atomic fuel or any fissionable purpose of that kind. Of course, the fissionable element is U235. The various processes of enrichment are designed to increase the amount of that dangerous ingredient, in the product, leaving a residue of depleted uranium which has a higher concentration of U238. It can be increased and enriched to a limited extent so that it will fuel a nuclear reactor or it can be enriched even further so that the material can be used for small dirty atom bombs of the type that devastated Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The borderline between these two grades of uranium is not clear. Indeed, it varies according to circumstances such as the design of the bomb itself.

In other words, we see this proposal to enrich as having great future dangers, possibly permitting some future government to make weapons grade material and to supply it overseas. It has been suggested that the United States of America might feel that it would be useful, strategic and good to have a source of enriched uranium for weapons use outside its territory. I do not give that suggestion any credence; I merely mention it at this stage as a possibility. We are speaking of the governments of this country and of the United States not only now but also in the future. We have no way of telling what might happen in the future or what sorts of obligations might be placed on us by some future government if indeed we did have an enrichment industry in this country. It is even possible that at some stage we could have the type of government which would want to make our own very high fallout weapons because for some reason or other this had been urged on it by the propagandists.
