Of course, there are propagandists active in this country now, including people who should know a great deal better, who have urged that sort of action on this country.

I would have thought it fairly self-evident that the number of weapons that could be produced by our relatively small potential of technology would not be enough to be of any great use, especially since we could not afford expensive delivery systems to far off targets. Rather, it would have the complete effect of making us a nuclear target. Those bombs could be removed or neutralised in the case of war. I cannot see its having any effect but that. In other words, we are worried about the general aspects of Australia's going into nuclear technology because we see a process of gradualism. In the past my remarks on this matter have been misunderstood so I will clarify them here. We believe that , having gone into enrichment and having justified those risks to ourselves, it is only one further step to go into other things. For instance, we would have large amounts of depleted uranium-U238-which is blanket material for fast breeder reactors. An economic argument could be advanced that we ought to go into fast breeder reactors because we had a supply of depleted uranium, the economic use for which is in the blanket of a fast breeder.

Is this approach to nuclear technology in Australia in any way justified? We have an industry in complete financial disarray and disorder. Among other things , there has been a recent major slump in the price of uranium, the spot price for uranium oxide now being $US20 per lb compared with the recent price of $US40 . The world is grossly oversupplied with both natural uranium and enriched uranium. In addition, Australia already has abundant sources of power. It has vast amounts of coal and a promising future in solar and wind power technology. Why should we proceed with a nuclear power plant, as indeed Sir Charles Court proposed for Western Australia? His site at Ledge Point was only a little way upwind from Perth. I am glad to see that Mr O'Connor, his successor, has seen reason on this matter. I understand he wants nuclear power delayed until after the turn of the century. Thank God that that idiocy has been put to rest for the time being.

talk.start.para: —It was politically expedient.

—I thank Senator Coleman for the comment that it was politically expendient. At least in the pragmatic sense the obvious risk of nuclear contamination affecting Perth in the case of a major accident has been removed. If there were such a nuclear power-house in Australia what would be the consequences of even a minor accident such as that at Three Mile Island? The Three Mile Island plant will probably not operate again for another eight years. It was recently estimated to cost in excess of $1 billion to clean that up. What would happen in parts of Australia, let us say Western Australia, if it were affected by such an accident? Who would meet the huge clean-up costs? Where would alternative sources of electric power come from during that time? In other words, the question of nuclear power is a case of too many eggs in one basket for Australia.

speech.para: I wish to mention one other appalling possibility which I think is of huge importance. A remarkable and definitive 60-page article in the New Yorker magazine in February describes the vastly enhanced effect of nuclear weapons dropped on any enemy's power reactor. That alone ought to be the most powerful argument for never perpetrating this sinister and potentially tragic industry on Australia. The New Yorker magazine quotes from an article in the Scientific American which describes a special study by Dr Kosta Tsipis of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on this subject. It describes how a one megaton bomb blast on other targets would affect an area of only 26 square miles but, because of the complex effect of so many radio isotopes in the fuel rods of the reactor being attacked, the same bomb dropped on a power reactor would cause the same terrifying effect in an area of 1,700 square miles. In other words, some 60 times as much territory would be affected if the bomb were dropped on a nuclear power reactor. This would guarantee some 60 times more destruction and deaths and long term contamination of huge regions.

The Australian Democrats implore the Government not to allow the considerable commercial and financial pressures which are without doubt being brought to bear on it to prejudice the future of this country in such an insane and unnecessary fashion, bringing to us the prospects of a future which is nightmarish indeed but one which we at least can easily avoid.
Motion (by Senator Sir John Carrick) agreed to:
That the document from which Senator Mason quoted be tabled.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talker.name: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
talker.role: Minister for National Development and Energy)

talk.start.para: —In this world today over 200 peacetime nuclear reactors are in operation, over two hundred more are under construction and over 200 more are in the planning stages. For 20 years or more peacetime reactors have been operating in this country. No known deaths have been attributable to any operation of any nuclear reactor. On the other hand, the history of illness and death from the mining of coal and the burning of coal in power stations runs to tens of thousands of people. It is a quaint thing that anybody should get up in this place and attempt in a selective way to put fear into people's minds knowing that they can drive people into a world that is now threatened-the International Energy Agency makes this very clear-with acid rain which will destroy the ecosystem. It is already doing great damage in Canada and in the Scandinavian countries. Not a mention of this has been made because it suits the purpose of honourable senators opposite to scare. Not a mention has been made of the greenhouse effect of overheating the atmosphere from the overburning of coal. Not a mention has been made of the ravaging of the environment by the overuse of the only other non- renewable petrochemical in this country. But there has been an attempt to scare as though there is something new, different and inherently dangerous in building nuclear power stations. This has been done regardless of Australia's 20 years of experience in this field and regardless of the 200 or more nuclear reactors operating now, the 200 or more being built and the 200 or more being designed.

speech.para: What a quaint situation it is that the Australian Democrats can be so selective that they have failed to say what is being said right round this world today by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, by the International Energy Agency and by all countries, irrespective of whether they are socialist or liberal. There is no way in which the living standards of the people of this world and society as we know it can be maintained unless we increase the use of peacetime nuclear electric power. Why, indeed, have the Australian Democrats not made mention of this? From what has been said it would not matter whether we trebled coal or gas production, whether we had the most massive conservation or whether we made the most massive use of the renewables-solar, wind or biomass. We need to have a significantly increasing use of nuclear power for peacetime purposes. Those who look at the Falkland Islands dispute today and see how an air-to-sea missile can take out a tanker without any trouble will know that in a situation of peril there is no way that oil or coal will move across the surface of this world. Therefore, the world will move more and more towards the use of uranium in this capacity.

Against the background that it is universally agreed that there is an imperative need to safeguard living standards and to safeguard the social and political stability of people and against the track record of the world, we get this tissue of misrepresentations. How is it that an honourable senator can get up in this Senate and say selectively that the Americans are lowering the number of nuclear power stations one by one without acknowledging to this Senate that even more coal fired power stations are being cancelled? Does he argue then that the rejection of contracts for coal fired power stations means that the Americans are going out of the coal fired electric power generation business? What nonsense! We have had one of the most dangerously selective presentations I have heard in this Senate. I reject it out of hand. The fact is that in a period of recession around the world many countries have slowed down their building of power plants, whether they be coal, oil, gas or nuclear plants.

The debate concerns Australia and the nuclear industry. I want to make it perfectly clear that no government has announced any intention at all of building a peacetime nuclear power plant. I want to look at the two things that are happening in Australia, firstly, the mining and milling of uranium and, secondly, prospectively the enrichment of uranium. I will take, step by step, the selective scare tactics and destroy them. Under the Whitlam Government, the royal commission headed by Mr Justice Fox and known as the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry was set up. It laboured long and heard evidence from expert witnesses everywhere in Australia. Mr Justice Fox subsequently became the Ambassador-At-Large for Nuclear Affairs. The royal commission brought in two reports. It looked at all aspects of the nuclear cycle. It looked at the mining and milling of uranium and the generation of electric power by nuclear fission. One would have thought that instead of scaring the daylights out of Australians, one would go to the report that has been universally adopted and not challenged in any way. What does the report say? I will read the first of its conclusions. It states:
The hazards of mining and milling uranium, if those activities are properly regulated and controlled, are not such as to justify a decision not to develop Australian uranium mines.

Mr Justice Fox goes on to say in the report that it can be a proper safeguarded industry to mine and mill uranium in Australia. That is being done. Yet fear is being engendered in people about that. All the time I hear most remarkable nonsense spoken in this place about the dangers of yellowcake and the supposed high radioactivity of yellowcake. That is absolute nonsense. Yellowcake is regarded as being of such shallow radioactivity that it does not need high safeguard supervision other than for its bulk in case of conversion. I hear nonsense talked of the peril of having an enrichment industry, as though radioactivity has anything to do with a uranium enrichment industry. It is to the nth degree wrong for anyone to get up in this place and misrepresent what is happening to the people of Australia. The fact is, as I have said here repeatedly, that yellowcake in itself is poisonous. If it is eaten it will make one very uncomfortable indeed. Often one used to lick it off one's Reeves's gay pastel paints-that nice little yellow paint that one used to paint with as a child, before one knew. It is poisonous to eat, but so are many other things. It is very shallow in its radioactivity. It is monitored so that we follow its course through all its changes in the cycle. It is not high in radioactivity. It offers no major threat, and Mr Justice Fox said so.

Secondly, uranium enrichment is the taking of yellowcake and combining it, first of all, in a conversion process with the gas fluorine. It is entirely a chemical process, and not a radioactive process. It is the taking of fluorine, combining it with the yellowcake, and producing uranium hexafluoride, which is produced into a white powder. It is a chemical process, needing safeguards, as all toxic chemicals do, but it is not in itself radioactive. Let me make it abundantly clear that that is so. Then, taking it from the conversion stage, there is the separating of the isotopes of the hexafluoride according to their atomic weights, largely by a centrifugal method. It is not a radioactive situation or threat but is a chemical process or a physical process. These are the basic things being talked about.
Let me put it straight, because no one can ever be complacent about radioactivity. Let me quote facts from the World Health Organisation publication 'Facts about low-level radiation':

Taking into account all the radiation (both natural and man-made) that a population is exposed to and the total number of cancer cases (from all causes) that are recorded, it is about 100 times more likely that cancer will be produced in the average individual by some other cause than by radiation.

Here are the facts coming out all the time. Here is the latest publication, World Health Organisation endorsed. An average person living in Canberra at this moment is subject to 104 millirems-that is, units of radiation. It is 102 in Sydney. It is two more here because of the altitude of Canberra. Those figures are made up in this way: From cosmic rays, 45 millirems; from soil, 15 millirems ; from food, water and air, 25 millirems. Let us get this in perspective: It is 45 millirems from cosmic rays, 15 from soil, and 25 from water, food and air. From air travel, on a round trip Sydney-Perth, the figure is 3. From diagnostic X-rays, the figure is 20, and from living in the vicinity of a nuclear plant, the figure is one.

From all the atom bomb explosions and tests since Hiroshima and Nagasaki right through to Muroroa, 2 millirems has been added to the atmosphere. I do not condone the addition of one. I want to make clear how the scare arises and how bad it is. I have said that cosmic rays average about 45 millirems, but let me show how it can be changed. Let us bear in mind that it is one millirem from being near an atomic plant. If one is in Perth it is 60. In London it is 100, in Paris it is 120, in Denver it is 125, and in Kerala in India it is about 400. So in the ordinary way of moving around the world, of flying around the world, the units we are exposed to are added to massively. We are talking about the risks inherent in these kinds of situations. I do not want to be in any way complacent about this matter. I have with me a chart which shows that 67.6 per cent of radiation is from natural background, 30.7 per cent is from medical irradiation, 0.6 per cent is from fall-out, 0.5 per cent is from miscellaneous causes, 0.45 per cent is from occupational exposure, and 0.15 per cent is due to releases from the nuclear industry. These are the scare tactics that people are trying to talk about on and on.

Now let us come to a comparison of the situation. I would welcome an honest debate in this place about the dangers to health, whether it be from radiation, coal, oil or anything else. I would regard it as being objectively more honest if we had that debate. Let me read from a booklet first published by the International Atomic Energy Agency which states:

For example, nuclear power stations emit radio-active materials; oil- and coal- fired power stations discharge sulphur dioxide (as much as 20,000 to 30,000 tonnes per year from a single large power plant). But in terms of the corresponding lethal doses of these radioactive materials and of sulphur dioxide , the emission limits for nuclear power stations are 100 times lower than they are for oil- or coal-fired stations.
In nuclear power stations the emission limits are 100 times lower than for oil- or coal-fired stations.

This is only one facet of air pollution and air pollution in turn is the only one factor to be considered in determining the relative merits of different energy sources. Furthermore, in the case of coal, it has been estimated that in Pennsylvania 30,000 miners died in the mines between 1870 and 1950-an average of about one man a day for 80 years.

That refers just to Pennsylvania. I refer also to acid rain and to the greenhouse effects. There has been not a word about the massive carcinogenic elements that are involved in coal-firing. If we are going to press on and scare the world, if we are to burn more and more coal, we are going to change the ecosystem of this world to an enormous degree and do very great damage to the health of people. It would be vastly more honest if this debate took place not selectively but in parallel with a debate on other sources of energy. It would be more honest if we could say: 'Look, we have a world in which oil is finite. We will run out of oil. We must have substitutes-coal, gas, nuclear energy and the renewables-the biomass, solar and wind power. How can we use these elements to protect the ecosystem? How can we do this to save coal for the hundreds of years ahead when we need it for a vital petrochemical system? Why are we not urging the saving of our resources?' Instead, there is concentration on one fear tactic. We are given the wrong evidence. We are talking about the nuclear power industry in Australia in relation to which we mine and we mill. The Fox committee report said that it is safe to do this with the appropriate safeguards . We are doing so. We have done this for 20 years. Those safeguards have worked. Hazards to health have not been proven at all. The Fox committee has said that it is proper to operate nuclear power stations. Several hundred or more are operating in this world with no proof of danger compared with the overwhelming deaths and injuries that have occurred in the coal and oil industries.

I repeat to honourable senators that it is fundamental knowledge that every country in the Western world is unanimous that there will be no solution to the energy problem, the maintenance of living standards and the preservation of society unless we have an orderly nuclear process of peacetime generation. We have been given this massive source of energy, this low cost vehicle of energy. We heard a lot of nonsense from Senator Mason to the effect that the cost of nuclear power stations is such that they are not going ahead. Basically, a nuclear power station costs three times as much or more to build than a coal- fired or oil-fired power station. But, in fact the cost of the fuel is very much lower. Its transportability is enormously easier. As the price of coal rises year by year, so the cost of operation of a coal-fired station, combined with its capital costs, will pass that of the nuclear power station. The nuclear power station development will move ahead.

I am second to none in wanting to limit in this world all avoidable or elective radiation. Australia is a signatory to the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty. It is nonsense to say that if Australia had a uranium enrichment plant, it would have a weapons-grade enrichment capacity. To say that is to fail to understand the chemistry of the physics or to distort the position deliberately. In fact, weapons-grade fuel is so much richer than other fuel. Senator Mason knows, as everybody else knows, that the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Australian Safeguards Office will monitor at every step the grade of the uranium and where that uranium is sent. Every tonne of yellowcake that leaves Australia is monitored over the whole of its cycle. It is monitored when it is changed from yellowcake into uranium hexafluoride by chemical volume and weight. It is monitored as it is made into enriched uranium. It is monitored when it is made into fuel rods. It is monitored through the reprocessing of the spent fuel. At every stage, wherever the uranium moves, we have the capacity to say: 'You will not divert this fuel to weapons making. You will not divert it to make anything else'. We can stop the supply immediately to any country that breaches these rules. I will be discussing this with the IAEA next week or the week after. The IAEA is vigilant in this monitoring. I say, without any complacency at all, that it is a downright misrepresentation to the Australian people to put forward the kind of nonsense and the distorted propaganda that we have heard today.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats reject absolutely the contention of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) that the nuclear power industry is safe. We reject absolutely Senator Sir John Carrick's contention that there is no alternative to nuclear power. I propose during the course of my remarks to submit evidence to substantiate those two points of view. It is a rare occasion when the Democrats have the opportunity to have debated in this Senate a matter of national importance. It is very much in line with the basic thinking of the Democrats that they should choose to debate the nuclear power industry on the rare occasion that they have an opportunity to initiate debate on an important matter. The Democrats see nuclear power as the critical issue facing mankind today, as the single greatest overriding issue that has arisen in the twentieth century. It is an enormous challenge, as we see it, facing our generation. It makes everything else pale into insignificance. The preservation of our planet, the preservation of spaceship earth, is the issue that has arisen in the twentieth century. It has not arisen before in the history of mankind.

speech.para: Senator Mason pointed to the fact that the nuclear power industry in the United States of America is tending now to become uneconomic. That is very true. I believe we are living in a fool's paradise if we hope that because the nuclear power industry in the United States is uneconomic this will lead to the nuclear power industry fading away. There will never be any shortage of Third World countries prepared to mortgage their whole economies in an attempt to get nuclear power. Why? It is for a very fundamental reason. It is through nuclear power that dictatorships can get access to nuclear weapons. That is the reason that there will be a market for nuclear power for as long as the developed Western world is prepared to sell nuclear power plants to countries like India and the Argentine. It was only recently that we were amazed that a country such as India, which one would have thought had greater priorities like feeding its population, exploded a nuclear bomb. Where did it get the material to make the nuclear bomb? It got it as the byproduct of its nuclear power reactor which it bought, I think, from West Germany.

Those of us who saw the Four Corners program on the Australian Broadcasting Commission network just a few weeks ago now realise that the Argentine has the capability of producing nuclear weapons-if, in fact, it does not already possess them. One wonders what Great Britain's reaction would be if it faced defeat in the Falkland Islands as a result of nuclear weapons being used in that war. There is no way that we can restrict the use of nuclear weapons around the world , in every tin pot dictatorship on earth, if we persist with the nuclear power industry. That is our overriding concern. The consequences of a nuclear war are too frightening to contemplate. That is the stark reality that we face right now as a result of the nuclear industry.

The Democrats' attitude regarding nuclear power is not new. From its formation, as a political force in this country, it fundamentally opposed nuclear power and the mining of uranium as a first step in the development of nuclear power. Well before that the Australia Party opposed nuclear power. As national convenor of the Australia Party in 1975 I challenged Mr Whitlam, who at that time was travelling the world selling Australia's uranium, to state the reasons why he was a party to the development of substances that are amongst the most dangerous in the world. In February 1975 a campaign against nuclear power was formed in this country for the first time. Unfortunately the conservative government-the Liberal Party-has persisted in pushing the mining of uranium and supporting the development of nuclear power around the world.

Only recently President Reagan said that money would be made available for the development of the breeder reactor. The previous President of the United States opposed any further money being spent on the breeder reactor. Now the United States, West Germany and, we believe, France and the United Kingdom are developing breeder reactors. Why are they persisting in the development of breeder reactors? It is for the simple reason that supplies of uranium are very limited. They are certainly sufficiently limited to make the billions of dollars being expended at the moment unjustifiable. The nuclear industry needs a renewable energy source to fire its reactors. That renewable energy source is plutonium and it is the breeder reactor that produces plutonium.

The Fox report, from which Senator Sir John Carrick quoted at some length, stated that the problems of the plutonium society-I think that was the term it used-were too horrifying to contemplate. Yet that is the direction that the United States of America and other Western countries are now pursuing with all the resources that they can muster. It involves carting considerable quantities of plutonium around the world's shipping lanes. A handful of plutonium spread across Melbourne or Sydney would render those cities permanently uninhabitable. We are going to transport plutonium. I see that Senator Sir John Carrick does not agree. It takes 12 pounds of plutonium to make an atom bomb.

talk.start.para: —But we do not spread it round. That is why I shook my head.

—It is very easily spread. I refer to no less an authority than Dr Gofman of the United States. He submitted a report which as yet has not been refuted by the nuclear industry. He commented on the establishment of a reprocessing plant on the east coast of the United States and went into great detail about the stores of plutonium that would be held in that reprocessing plant. He concluded:

speech.para: a 1 per cent release of the radioactivity inventory at Barnwell would be a disaster unimagined for any peacetime situation.

He indicated that the heat from a terrorist bomb would be sufficient to turn the stored plutonium nitrate into plutonium oxide which would float into the atmosphere and, with satisfactory wind conditions, cover virtually the whole east coast of the United States causing millions of people to be evacuated. That was stated by an authority who is beyond dispute. The plutonium industry requires the storing of a substance which is arguably the most dangerous that has ever been produced by mankind. What right has our generation to plan to produce plutonium in breeder reactors in ton lots and then ship it around the world, from the breeder reactor to the reprocessing plant and from the reprocessing plant to the reactors in Third World countries such as Argentina and India? If planning to pursue a technology as dangerous as this is not the greatest indictment on our generation I do not know what is. We say this is the greatest challenge. It is an evil of unimaginable proportions and there are alternatives. Perhaps they will be capital intensive. Wind power has been studied with a great deal of attention and much detail. It has been proven, by professors of physics, to be a viable alternative and a renewable energy source provided that we are prepared to invest the capital to set it up. Enormous amounts of energy, particularly in the southern hemisphere, are available by harnessing the wind. Solar energy is, admittedly, a capital intensive form of energy but it is one that, if pursued, could be a very valuable addition to our total energy requirements.

Hydrogen is the only renewable fuel for our engines and aeroplanes at this stage. Admittedly there are many problems but development could surely be pursued in these sorts of directions. Renewable energy is vital. If society, as we know it today, is to develop into the foreseeable future with a standard of living as we know it today, we must have renewable energy sources. As Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out, our fossil fuels are limited. After the year 2000 it will be very difficult to predict where we will get the energy to fuel our cities and transport. Surely now is the time to plan for that time ahead and to develop renewable energy sources, which admittedly will cost money. The investment in capital and manpower to develop renewable sources is the great challenge facing us. Unemployment would be solved overnight with the development of a renewable energy source.

Let me conclude by saying simply that in the perspective of geological ages our generation is insignificant but it carries an enormous responsibility to preserve intact our planet, spaceship earth, so that future generations-again in perspective of geological ages-can carry forward the fullness of the knowledge we have today which has been so hardly won.

talk.start.para: —Before calling Senator Collard I call Senator Mason. A motion was passed in the Senate that he table some documents. I now invite him to table them.

—I merely wish to say that the document from which I quoted was not in my possession in the Senate at the time the motion was moved. I now have it with me. The Senate has agreed to the motion of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) but I make the point that this is a confidential report. I take no responsibility for its tabling but , of course, I will comply with the motion.

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: —by leave-The Minister for National and Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) has quite properly moved a motion in conformity with Standing Order 364 which states :

speech.para: A Document quoted from by a Senator not a Minister of the Crown may be ordered by the Senate to be laid upon the table; such Order may be made without Notice immediately upon the conclusion of the speech of the Senator who has quoted therefrom.

Senator Mason quoted from a document purporting to be confidential. Senator Sir John Carrick then quite properly moved, in conformity with Standing Order 364, that the document be tabled. The question was put by the Acting Deputy President who was then in the chair and the motion was carried on the voices. All I am saying is that whilst that is proper Senate procedure it is a standing order that is not used very often. It could well represent an embarrassment to certain people unless the procedure is known to honourable senators. Senator Mason has absolutely no objection to that document being made public. In fact, we would be happy to incorporate it in Hansard.

Let as assume another situation in which a senator is innocently quoting from a document that he believes to be 90 per cent accurate but the remaining 10 per cent of that document maligns innocent people or contains charges against people which have no foundation at all. Unknowingly or unwittingly that senator could then, by a simple resolution of the Senate, when not too many senators are in the chamber and not too many are listening to the purport of the document or know what they are doing when they agree that the document be tabled, be forced to table the document. It then becomes public property and innocent people could be hurt. We have no objection to the procedure. I think it is appropriate for that danger to be flagged at this time. I thank the Senate for the indulgence of allowing me to say a few words on the matter.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order. I seek your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President, as to whether Standing Order 364 does in fact require, on the motion of the Senate, the tabling of a document which is not in fact in the senator's physical possession at the time he is referring to the content of it in the chamber. I took the request being made of Senator Mason and his acquiescence to it and the Senate's resolution to be in the context of a requirement that Senator Mason table the particular piece of paper from which he was reading at that particular time. That has been my understanding of how standing orders of this kind in fact apply. If indeed it is to be the case that Standing Order 364 is to be construed as requiring the tabling of a document not in the chamber, not one from which the senator is reading and not one from which the senator is quoting in that sense, it seems to me something of an extraordinary precedent that is in fact being set on this occasion. If that is indeed the purport of the standing order and if that is the way it is to be applied, I suggest that there be a formal ruling to that effect. Equally, of course, at the same time I submit that that is not the way that Standing Order 364 should be construed but that it should be construed as applicable only to a document in the physical possession of the senator and from which he is quoting in a physical sense in the chamber.

—I take a point of order. I think Hansard will show that what Senator Mason said-and I precis it-was: 'I am quoting from a 25-page confidential document'. He did not say: 'I am quoting from a piece of paper which contains extracts of a 25-page confidential document which is in my office '. The words themselves purported to be that he was quoting from a document. That, I think, in plain language, was so. That is why I moved the motion as such . I do not want to be vexatious in any way.
—You are not being vexatious. It is an interesting point.

—I am not being vexatious because indeed it could be an embarrassment as Senator Chipp said. I want to say that any honourable senator in this place who purports to quote from a document ought to take the risk of that document standing up and being counted because the only way--
—If he brings it into the chamber, yes, but not otherwise.

—Let me say again that this should be so if a senator says: 'I am quoting from this document'. Every day at Question Time an Opposition senator gets up and says: 'I ask that the document be tabled'. I in fact had to move that this document be tabled. It is normal common courtesy for a senator simply to ask that a document be tabled but that was not so in this case. Hansard will show, and I think Senator Mason acknowledges this, that he said he was quoting from a 25-page confidential document. If that is correct then it is fair for this Senate to ask for that document to be tabled.
—Senator Evans, in reply to your point of order, a precedent has been set in the Senate. If you wish to take it any further I suggest you take it to the Standing Orders Committee.
—With respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, a precedent for what?

—On 6 April 1980 a senator quoted from a document in the course of his speech. At the conclusion of that speech a motion was put by a Minister and agreed to that the document quoted be laid upon the table. The senator therefore tabled certain documents. A precedent has been set. That is my ruling. Senator Evans, if you wish to take the matter any further you can refer it to the Standing Orders Committee.

—With the utmost respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, I do seek further clarification of the ambiguity inherent in that ruling and, indeed, the ambiguity inherent in the Standing Order. I have no doubt whatsoever that there have been many occasions in the past when documents from which honourable senators on either side of the chamber have been quoting, in the sense of reading from them in the chamber, have been sought to be tabled quite properly and a resolution of that kind has been passed. I would be utterly unsurprised if that were not so. But the question in issue is whether a senator can be said to be quoting from a document for the purposes of the operation of Standing Order 364 when all the senator is doing is in effect referring to the contents of a document some distance away from the chamber. I raise this, Senator Carrick, in no political spirit and not in the context of this particular controversy because there is no controversy about making public this particular document. I imagine it ought to be a matter of some considerable concern to the Executive if something from which you happen to be quoting, even if you do not own up to it, turns out to be a paragraph from some highly confidential Cabinet minute.
—Or taken from a garbage tin by somebody else.

—Senator Carrick, if you are going to adopt that sort of attitude and that state of mind you bring this chamber and yourself into contempt. Can you not grow up? Can you not deal with an issue on its merits? Can you not come to grips with a serious point of order, a serious question of the interpretation of the Standing Orders which ought to be of profound concern to honourable senators on both sides of this chamber? You are impossible. You deserve not to be the leader in this place.
—You deserve to belong to Actors Equity.
—If you do not wish to--
—We were not being vexatious either.
—I know you were not. I acknowledge that.

—It is unbelievable, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we should have to put up with that nonsense. I simply make the point that if you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are unprepared, as you may well be in the circumstances , to deal with what is obviously a tricky and complex point and unprepared to consider it further in consultation with the President and rule further later in the day on the matter which I have raised, I would seek to move by leave that the matter be referred to the Standing Orders Committee. If you do take the point, that perhaps the matter ought to be deserving of some further consideration, then under those circumstances, I will, of course, await that further ruling from the Chair.

—I would like to speak briefly to the point of order. I am somewhat concerned. I am a little surprised that the Leader of the Government in the Senate should ask for a confidential document to be tabled. I ask, Mr Acting Deputy President: What would be the situation if I had merely borrowed that document from another person, if I had made genuine and conscientious quotations from it and if I could produce the document if necessary but in fact it was not my property and not in this place? Are we going to have a situation where, in a case such as that, honourable senators will be called upon to produce their materials? I think this is a matter which does require attention. I take the point raised by Senator Evans. I do not think Senator Sir John Carrick took up this point sufficiently. I think in a sense, certainly on grounds of logic, Senator Evans's rebuke to Senator Sir John Carrick was justified. If indeed a Minister of the Crown quotes only a sentence from a document as a matter of policy then any other honourable senator, on a motion of the Senate, can require that the entire document be tabled. That seems to be the implication, Mr Acting Deputy President, of your ruling. I just wanted to raise that point.

interject.speaker: Senator Sir John Carrick

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have no objection at all to this matter being referred to the Standing Orders Committee. Indeed, if the Senate so desires I will be very happy to move a motion to that effect. I simply make the point that if any honourable senator in this place purports to quote from a document, irrespective of whether he or she borrowed it-however it was obtained-that honourable senator, in conformity with the Standing Order, ought to be required to table the document if the Senate so moves. Mr Acting Deputy President, I move:

interject.para: That the matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders .

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, we are wasting time. On the point of order, it is fairly obvious that the earlier motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate referred to material handled and read from within the Senate. The particular document from which the honourable senator read comes under that motion, nothing else. We are wasting our time in referring the matter to the Standing Orders Committee. Any honourable senator, by request-that has been the courtesy-can ask for the document from which an honourable senator is reading to be tabled. That is the document to which we are referring. If within that document there is a quotation from another document somewhere else, the motion or the request does not cover that other document.
—The Chair says it does.
—That has been the understanding of this place as long as I have been here.
—The Chair could not do otherwise.
—Then the Chair ought to get better advice.
—There is a motion before the Chair that this matter be referred to the Senate Standing Orders Committee. I believe that is the proper procedure.

—I wish to make a brief statement to clarify my position on this matter. The matter has an important implication. The situation is that initially I did not bring a copy of the report into the chamber; I was quoting from my speech notes. My first reaction was to table those notes, which indeed I did. I understand they are in the Records and Table Office now and stamped. I was then informed by the Clerks of the House that indeed it would appear that this was not the case and that, in fact, I should table the document from which those quotations were taken.
—You got crummy advice.

—Irrespective of whether I got crummy advice, I felt it my duty to do that, that being the minimum compliance with the Senate's request that I ought to have made. But at this stage I raise the question of the future of that document because if, indeed, this matter is to be referred to the Standing Orders Committee I think it highly inappropriate that the document which I have just handed over should be formally tabled before a decision is made on the matter.

interject.speaker: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Senator Mason, in answer to your query, there is a precedent for this situation. I now put the motion:

interject.para: That this matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Collard Sen S.J.

talk.start.para: — Mr Acting Deputy President, it appears we can generate more radioactivity from the Standing Orders, or the misinterpretation of them, than we can from a nuclear reactor. For those honourable senators who are not quite aware of what is going on, we are discussing a matter of public importance, namely:

speech.para: Plans by the Commonwealth Government to encourage the early establishment in Australia of a nuclear industry, including enrichment of nuclear fuel and electric power through the use of nuclear reactors.

If ever we were in any doubt that this is an emotional subject that cannot seem to get its act together to be dealt with rationally we should not have any doubt now, having heard the Australian Democrats' introduction to that subject today. We heard Senator Mason. He has spoken on this subject without any facts. He has spoken rather irrational and emotional rubbish. Senator Mason was followed by Senator Siddons. The main part of Senator Siddons's speech referred to the problem of the possibility that plutonium might be used in nuclear weapons and that if somebody threw a handful of plutonium around we would have to evacuate Melbourne or whatever. I am not denying that certain problems are associated with plutonium. It is radioactive and it is an alpha emitter. Being an alpha emitter, cigarette paper can protect us from it. In other words, if I had a choice of being in a room with a taipan or a bit of plutonium I think I would stick to plutonium.

For Senator Siddons's information, there is also currently estimated to be about seven to nine tonnes of plutonium in the air-floating around the atmosphere-as a result of weapons tests of previous times. We do not need nuclear power generation to provide the fuel for nuclear bombs. As a matter of fact, none of this material comes from nuclear power generation. A very pure plutonium-plutonium 239-is needed to make a bomb. That material comes from defence or experimental reactors built specifically for that purpose. The plutonium that comes out of nuclear power generators is very impure. As well as plutonium 239 we have plutonium 240 and 241. I am not saying that this material could not make a bomb; it could. But it would be rather hazardous. It could be a fizzer and its qualities would be unknown. Nuclear power generation is not needed to make plutonium bombs.

As I said, this is an emotional subject. I imagine that a lot of that is because our introduction to nuclear power was through Horoshima and Nagasaki, where plutonium was used as a weapon. Had our introduction to electricity been through the electric chair we would have had the same hang-ups about it. Indeed, there were hang-ups when electricity was introduced. There were hang-ups about its being unsafe and the fact that people could be electrocuted. Of course, that has happened. Indeed, there is an element of risk which the community seems to accept, in order to get the benefits. That has happened with electricity. That is happening with nuclear power. I will say a little more about that later. Of course, it has happened with the motor car. There has never been a more devastating invention of mankind than the motor car, yet what legislature in the world would set up legislation to ban the motor car because of the number of people that it kills.

Most power is generated by the pressure of steam turning a turbine. That steam generally is generated by the burning of coal, oil, gas, or maybe by nuclear fission. All that nuclear fission takes place in a reactor. That brings us to the enrichment cycle. Uranium 235 is what is needed. It has been alluded to by all speakers on this subject. Currently, it is found in its natural state at a level of 0.7202 per cent. Most reactors require the uranium to be enriched to about 3 per cent before it can be used in a nuclear reactor. That is basically what enrichment is all about: We take the uranium out of the ground where it is found naturally in various parts of Australia and other parts of the world; we enrich it from 0.7202 per cent to 3 per cent; and it is then used in a reactor.

Senator Mason went on at great length about how this enrichment process means the uranium can be used for nuclear weapons. Senator Carrick touched on this matter. We need to enrich the uranium to at least 80 per cent to get it anywhere near nuclear weapons grade uranium. That is another furphy that is continually thrown about in this emotional argument. Nuclear reactors for power generation have been proved to be safe. It is interesting to note the the report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, the Fox report-from which Senator Carrick quoted-in its second finding and recommendation said:

The hazards involved in the ordinary operations of nuclear power reactors if those operations are properly regulated and controlled are not such to justify a decision not to make and sell Australian uranium.

As has been mentioned, fossil fuel powered stations provide a far greater health hazard to those around them. They emit radioactivity. Indeed, they emit more radioactivity than does a nuclear power station. Radio isotopes are leeched through the coal, burnt and go up through the chimney stack. These power stations also emit sulphur dioxide, nitrous oxide, carbon dioxide, trace metals et cetera. It is estimated that, due to the pollutants that come out of those chimneys, for every 1,000 megawatt powered power station, between 20 and 100 people will die every year from cancer and other respiratory diseases. This is because of the burning of fossil fuel.

Once again I return to the argument that society seems to accept that there are acceptable risks. We apparently accept that 20 to 100 people will die from the burning of fossil fuels. Yet for some unknown reason people have hangups about nuclear reactors from which there has not been one recorded death.

talk.start.para: —That is rubbish. There is a whole book of them here.

—It is up to Senator Coleman to prove what she says. She appears to be the only person in society up to this point of time who knows about any deaths from nuclear reactors used for power generation. To operate for a year a 1,000 megawatt power station needs 2.1 million tonnes of coal or 10 million barrels of oil. I believe that oil should never be used for power generation. It is a non-renewable resource. It is the main source of energy for transport and I believe that oil should be used at all times for that purpose. It should never be used for power generation. We could also use 1.8 billion cubic metres of natural gas to operate a 1,000 megawatt power station for a year. Solar power has been mentioned. To generate that much power for a year we would need 10,125 hectares of completely cleared land with pathways so that people could move between the reflectors and polish them. I repeat that we would need 10,125 hectares of completely cleared land to generate 1,000 megawatts of power for a year.
—What about solar cells?

—That is solar cells; photovoltaic cells. Alternatively, we would use 30 tonnes of uranium to generate that much power. No wonder it is one of the best, cleanest and most efficient methods of generating power in this day and age. As well as the deaths which result from the emissions from the chimneys of fossil fuel power stations there are all the deaths that occur, unfortunately , in the mining of coal. We can hardly have a debate in this place without Three -Mile Island being brought into the argument. I might mention that not one death or injury resulted from the Three-Mile Island incident. Yet we can all remember the hysteria with which the Press of the world greeted the Three-Mile Island accident. At that same time coal miners were killed in a coal mine, and that rated a mention of one paragraph. Where are our priorities? Is the life of a person working in the nuclear industry worth a lot more than that of a miner killed underground while mining coal? That seems to be the value put on this matter by the international media at this time. That is one of the unfortunate parts about this whole emotional argument.

speech.para: I refer now to future use. Senator Mason referred at length to the number of nuclear power reactors which will not be going ahead in the United States of America. Senator Carrick also rightfully said that this is due to the lack of the need for that energy in the foreseeable future. Many coal-fired power stations are also not going ahead. The last time I was overseas I talked to representatives of the United Kingdom Department of Energy and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry in Japan. Their figures are quite interesting. The United Kingdom is now using 12 per cent nuclear generation to provide its power. It anticipates that in 1992 it will be using 33 per cent nuclear power generation. Japan is now using 12 per cent nuclear power generation. It anticipates that it will be using 22 per cent in 1991 and 26.7 per cent in 1995. France, of course, is more committed to nuclear power. Some 40 per cent of its power is now generated by nuclear methods. It anticipates that it will be using 70 per cent nuclear power generation in 1990. So a lot of use certainly is being made and will be made of nuclear power, particularly in those countries which are flat out getting a clear sky because of the smog created by the burning of fossil fuels both for transport and power generation purposes. Nuclear power is by far the cleanest and safest source of power generation. Incidentally, France expects to be saving 73 million tonnes of oil through its nuclear program.

It is quite interesting that whilst we hear arguments at great length-I must confess that it has been a while since we have had a good debate in the Senate on nuclear power-some years ago the French were finding that their uranium was not working in their reactors as predicted. I have referred to this instance in the Senate before. When they did their homework they found that the uranium they were using came from Gabon and that instead of U235 being present at the rate of 0.7202 per cent the rate was as low as 0.42 per cent. When they did their homework they realised that about 1.7 or 1.9 billion years ago U235 was found naturally in formations at the rate of about 3 per cent. Through radioactive decay the figure is now down to 0.7202 per cent. When one realises that one starts to get an idea of what it is all about; that long ago natural reactors were actually operating in the ground.

As I have said, at that time U235 was found in the natural formations at the rate of about 3 per cent. It so happened that in these formations there was sufficient water in crystalline form to act as a moderator. So we had reactors operating naturally for as long as 150,000 years. Whatever man thinks he has done now mother nature has beaten him to it. Ever since that time there has been the waste from those reactors in the ground. There has been the plutonium and so forth. Nobody has worried about it and it has not worried anybody else. We have not had the governments to suggest that it is a good idea. We have not had the Democrats to suggest that it is not a good idea. It was a natural phenomenon, and all mankind is really doing is picking up a natural phenomenon and using it.

The cost of production of power has been mentioned. I will cite figures I was able to get from MITI in Japan in January 1980. The cost of production of power in Japan at that stage was 13 yen per kilowatt for hydro-electric power; 9.6 yen per kilowatt for oil generation; 12 yen per kilowatt for coal generation; 9.9 yen per kilowatt for liquid natural gas generation; and 6.4 yen per kilowatt for nuclear generation. That was the actual operating cost of nuclear power generation in Japan as compared with others at that time. Of course, Japan has very little of its own fossil fuel reserves and it has to use nuclear power. I would say that even though Australia is not currently looking at nuclear power generation, I for one would not have any objections whatsoever if it were. It would certainly mean that when we have disputes, disruptions or breakdowns in the coal mining industry we would have a means of power generation which could go on and on without refuelling. We could provide the power and we would not thus be as susceptible to all the hiccups which exist in the coal mining industry. I agree that this is a matter of public importance because we should be enriching the uranium in our own country and we should be looking seriously at the need for nuclear power generation for Australia.

speech.speaker: Coleman Sen R.N.

talk.start.para: —Perhaps one of the most important statements to come out of the conference of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science held this year was that made by the Dean of the University of Western Australia Faculty of Law, Professor Richard Harding, which was reported in the West Australian on 11 May. Professor Harding said:

speech.para: The Three Mile Island accident showed criminologists that no nuclear reactor system was safe or could ever be safe . . .

I believe more and more people throughout the world are beginning to see that as a reality for the very near future. It is not something that will perhaps occur in the twenty-first century. They see it as something that could happen right here and now. There are so-called experts-we have heard some of them today on the Government side-who differ on the issues relating to nuclear energy. Some see nuclear energy as the saviour of humanity; some see it as causing the destruction of humanity.

It is interesting to me that a physicist professor who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for chemistry publicly recognised the tie between nuclear power and nuclear weapons which the members on the Government side today failed to recognise. They keep on talking about the matter as though it involved two separate and distinct atoms. It is exactly the same atom. If one produces nuclear energy one produces nuclear weapons. It is the same and it does not matter what honourable senators say in this chamber about there being a difference. That is the situation. It was recognised by the Fox report. We have had selective quotations by the Minister for National Development and Energy ( Senator Sir John Carrick) and Senator Collard from the Fox report and what it said about nuclear energy. But they did not quote recommendation No. 3 of the Fox report, which states:
The nuclear power industry is unintentionally contributing to an increased risk of nuclear war. This is the most serious hazard associated with the industry.
I did not hear the Minister say that during his speech. I did not hear Senator Collard make that statement. They quoted selectively from the Fox report. They did not quote from the recommendations.

I think it is time we had a look at the state of the Australian uranium industry at the moment. We have so little control over it. Honourable senators might recall that only two years ago, I think, a fairly large amount of radioactive material was missing from the Mary Kathleen uranium mine. The Government regulatory committee that is supposed to look after these things- Senator Sir John Carrick spoke earlier about how the Atomic Energy Commission could enforce restrictions on the production, the mining and everything else-did not even know that it was missing. The company itself did not know that it was missing. Where is the safeguard there? Senator Sir John Carrick talks about the uranium that we send overseas being safeguarded. When he presented papers on that I spoke to them and asked him a series of questions, including questions about how we would monitor the use of Australia's uranium strictly for domestic purposes. He was very blase about it then and he is very blase about it now. What are we going to do? Are we going to colour it bright purple so that we will know that it is Australian uranium and must be used only for our domestic energy supply? Are we going to have someone stationed in every nuclear energy plant and interfering in other countries' internal operations? Are we going to have someone there monitoring the use of Australian uranium? How are we going to safeguard that aspect? How is the Government going to ensure that Australia's uranium will be used only for the production of domestic energy?

I put it to the Government that there is no way it can guarantee that the uranium will not be siphoned off. We have seen reports of large amounts of fissionable material having been stolen. A boatload of the damn stuff was missing and it still has not been found. Is Senator Sir John Carrick game enough to stand up in this place and say that it is not now in Argentina, Chile or Uruguay?

talk.start.para: —Or Israel.
—Israel or India. Is Senator Sir John Carrick game enough to stand up in front of the Australian people and say that this did not happen? It did.

speech.para: We are talking about responsibility. Let us look at the matter of responsibility. I do not trust most of the people who are involved in the Australian uranium industry any more than I trust those people who are involved in the uranium industry anywhere else. Let us look at the proposal referred to in an article under the heading 'Uranium enrichment plant plan' in the Australian Financial Review of 4 May 1982. The article is about a move to set up an Australian industry. It states:

Concrete moves to establish a uranium enrichment industry in Australia were taken last week when the Federal Government convened a meeting of Commonwealth and State officials involved in nuclear regulation.

I question the phrase 'nuclear regulation'. It has been established that there is radioactivity from the mineral sands at Capel in Western Australia and the nuclear regulatory commission that Senator Sir John Carrick talks about has no power to do anything to safeguard the health of the people there. A similar situation has arisen in Byron Bay in New South Wales. Where is the power? The Commonwealth does not have it. We have given it to the States and said: 'Look after it yourselves'. The article goes on to state:
The Governments of Queensland, the Northern Territory, Western Australia and South Australia--
They are all Liberal governments-
have all canvassed the possibility of setting up an enrichment plant in their home State.

Senator Mason made the comment earlier that Sir Charles Court, as Premier of Western Australia, was quite happy to have a nuclear power station go ahead there. But Mr O'Connor, the current Premier of Western Australia, has seen the light of day and the political reality. One of the first statements he made when he became Premier was to say: 'We will not go ahead with nuclear energy'. The article in the Australian Financial Review continues:
Two of the companies involved in the UEGA--
That is, the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia-
study group, WMC--
That is, the Western Mining Corporation-
and Peko Wallsend, have a direct involvement in uranium mining in these States.

Let us get back to responsibility and talk about the responsibility of the Western Mining Corporation, which could not even control a radioactive measuring gauge. It lost it from its Kambalda site. Senator Chipp was with me at a public meeting on the Esplanade in Perth some years ago-on 8 December 1978, I think- when we drew it to the attention of the people of Australia that that company had lost a radioactive part. What happened to it? It went to Singapore, completely contaminated. An entire furnace had to be melted down and returned to Australia. That shows how responsible the Western Mining Corporation is. This is the company which wants to go ahead with the uranium enrichment plant. Lovely!

Let us talk now about deaths in the uranium industry. I will make only a brief comment about the military side of the nuclear industry as I am going through this matter. We have debated this matter in this chamber once before. I am sure Senator Sir John Carrick will recall the occasion when the third edition of the booklet entitled 'Safety Record of the Nuclear Power Industry. Accidents, Leaks, Failures and Incidents' was incorporated in Hansard. I proved to Senator Sir John Carrick then and I will prove to him now that when he stands up here and says there have been no deaths in the industry he tells a mistruth because there is no truth in what he says.

Let us look at this booklet. I might add that this booklet was compiled in my office from other people's reports. They are not my reports. They are on record here and are available for anybody to check. In 1958-24 years ago-the Boris Kidric Institute at Vinca, Yugoslavia, reported that a nuclear reactor overheated resulting in one death. Six scientists were irradiated and transported to France for treatment. In 1958 in Los Alamos, United States of America, one death was caused by radiation in the uranium enrichment plant. The incident in 1961 at Idaho Falls, United States of America, was reported as the first major reactor accident in the United States of America. An explosion occurred, the cause of which is still not known. Three men were killed instantly . Their bodies were so severely irradiated that their exposed hands and heads had to be severed from their bodies and buried in a dump for radioactive waste. Have there been no deaths in the nuclear industry, Senator Sir John Carrick?

The next one concerns the military side of the industry. In 1963 the nuclear submarine USS Thresher disappeared on a deep test dive with 112 navy men and 17 civilians on board. No one has yet been able to say what happened. No deaths in the nuclear industry! That is the military side of the nuclear industry we are talking about. Let us get back to the domestic side of the nuclear industry and talk about the nuclear tests held at the Nevada test site when people developed strange diseases from which they died. Let us talk about what happened in 1964 at the Wood River nuclear installation in the USA. One death occurred from radioactivity in the uranium enrichment plant. There was a report on this subject in 1965 by the United States Public Health Department. Is Senator Sir John Carrick questioning the report of the Public Health Department when it states there have been deaths in the nuclear industry? When he gets up in this place and says there have been no deaths he tells a mistruth. He has done it before. I contradicted him then and I will contradict him now. The United States Public Health Department states that evidence suggests that excessive leukaemia deaths occurred among Utah residents. The report was shelved but it later became a very vital part of the Nugget file, which is still not readily available to people but which has been made available under the Freedom of Information Act in the United States. The Public Health Department report states:
From 1950 to 1964, 28 leukaemia deaths in the South West Counties of the State of Utah. Only 19 cases would have been expected to occur among the 20,000 residents of the area.
1959 and 1960-7 people with acute leukaemia, 5 of them children and teenagers.

In 1965 in Rocky Flats in Colorado in the United States of America fire exposed 400 workers to high levels of plutonium released in the atmosphere. Twenty-five got 17 times the permissible radiation dosage. Three hundred and twenty-five workers were contaminated, 56 developed cancer and 14 have since died. No deaths in the nuclear industry?

A report by Higson and Crancher of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, referring to deaths in the USA, not in Australia, states that between 1945 and 1968 ten workers died as a result of overexposure to radiation from experimental reactors or in laboratory work connected with the development of nuclear power. Let us talk about 1971 in Oklahoma, when an explosion killed a compressor worker as he was adjusting a compressor. At Windscale a man died of leukaemia after working for 13 years at a plant and being exposed to radiation dangers. The British Nuclear Power Co. admitted liability. We can talk about the situation that arises here in Australia. We had an admission of liability by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission when it accepted responsibility for the widow of a man who died after working at the Commission. There have been deaths. There have been deaths here in Australia. There will be untold deaths if we allow a uranium enrichment plant to operate in this country. In 1972 in Surrey in the United States two deaths were due to the failure of a valve. In 1973, two workers were killed while inspecting defective valves when a valve blew off at the Surrey reactor. A New Jersey truck dock worker accidentally spilt plutonium on himself while handling a leaking box of liquid waste in 1963. He died in 1973 aged 39. The company admitted liability but before he died had refused to pay compensation. Let us look once again at the report from Higson and Crancher of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. Until 1973, according to their report, not according to mine-I must stress that the collation only was done in my office-861 incidents had been reported to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in the United States. Senator Sir John Carrick has misled this Parliament on a number of occasions when he has said that there have been no deaths in the nuclear energy industry. He has known about such deaths. The whole booklet I have referred to has been incorporated in Hansard and is available in every library, including the Parliamentary Library. It is also being made available in high schools because people need to know the facts and they need to know what this Government is letting us in for if it goes ahead with the planned uranium enrichment plant in Australia.

speech.speaker: Rae Sen P.E.

talk.start.para: — The matter of public importance before the Senate today is in these terms:

speech.para: Plans by the Commonwealth Government to encourage the early establishment in Australia of a nuclear industry, including enrichment of nuclear fuel and electric power through the use of nuclear reactors.

Some previous speeches gave the impression that Australia should give a lead by being one of the few countries which will not proceed with the development of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes and, presumably, therefore will not be in a position to participate fully in the nuclear safeguards treaty and the nuclear safeguards policy which this Government has been at such pains to develop. The present Australian Government has developed a nuclear safeguards policy which I believe is one of the world's outstanding examples of such a policy. We have signed nuclear safeguards agreements with Canada, Finland, France, Sweden, the Philippines, the Republic of Korea, the United States, the United Kingdom and Euratom as well as negotiating recently with Japan and Switzerland. I think that shows at least the start of an extremely responsible attitude to the question being debated.

I believe that the whole Australian society, like the British society, could be seen to be adopting a responsible attitude to this question. Therefore I do not think the matter should be looked at as one in which any government in Australia has been irresponsible in its approach. Governments have been most careful and most thorough. Our attention should be directed to some of the other aspects, not to whether there has been good will towards the principle espoused by Senator Mason and others or whether there has been a genuine endeavour to achieve as much as possible in the appropriate control over nuclear energy in its various forms, but rather to whether we should proceed beyond that to utilise something which is being utilised by other countries at the moment. Almost 50 countries have nuclear power stations either in operation or under construction.

Much of the problem with regard to the question of nuclear energy is that the matter is seen by many people, with very understandable emotions, in the context of the 1940s and what happened at the conclusion of the Second World War. I can well understand that people have a horror about the wartime use of nuclear power , but there are thousands and thousands of nuclear warheads around the world at the moment. Australia's engagement in the peaceful use of nuclear energy will not determine whether there will be a repetition of what happened in Japan in 1945.

talk.start.para: —But it may well do.

—Let me come to that point. So many people, unfortunately, talk in terms of the technology of the 1950s and not the 1980s. Therefore I think it is important to look at several of the matters which have not been discussed to any extent today. Let me make my position clear. I strongly supported the abandonment of the proposed nuclear reactor at Jervis Bay at the beginning of the 1970s. At that time I did not believe that nuclear technology was sufficiently well advanced or that we had any reasonable basis on which we could conclude that we had overcome the waste disposal problem in particular. My motivation in relation to nuclear energy is in many ways, I believe, not dissimilar to the motivation-I accept that it is genuine motivation-of those who raised this matter today as a matter of concern.

speech.para: I believe that Australia can be extremely proud of what has been achieved by Australians in relation to waste disposal. The development of the synroc process was one of the most important events in the world in relation to the world's energy problems. It is one of the most important developments in relation to the future of mankind, the future of the human race. This breakthrough was made by Professor Ted Ringwood and a team at the Australian National University and subsequently with the assistance of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. General belief is that the synroc process-the tests conducted by both the University and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and the preliminary tests undertaken by the United States in relation to the synroc process have supported this conclusion-is the answer. It was a synthetic rock to trap and immobilise nuclear waste. It provides an exceptionally stable substance with a tremendous capacity to withstand leaching. It will enable the very small amount of nuclear waste to be treated in a way which will make it not harmful to future generations. In fact the way in which Ted Ringwood explained the process to me is, I think, a good way to describe it to a layman. It was an approach by earth scientists to use earth science principles to return to the earth something which came out of the earth in a form which is not likely to be more harmful than it was when it was in the earth in the first place.

I commend the process to any honourable senator who is interested in this question. I would be happy to act as an intermediary to arrange for Professor Ringwood to put on a display at the Australian National University to enable honourable senators to see how the process operates, if they have not seen it, and to get a better understanding of this type of substance. For those who do not know much about it, the physical substance in the end is a very dense, extremely heavy rock which can be made into a form of tube. It looks rather like ebony. It is very dense like ebony and it is a similar colour. It is made up of the materials which are most appropriate to take the nuclear waste and convert it into a substance which then can be put back into the ground. I hope that Australians, rather than talking about the dangers of nuclear energy, will at least pay some regard to this major breakthrough which has been obtained by Australians for the benefit of the world.

We need to look not at the bad American experience of nuclear energy, which is a bad experience, but at the British experience. I believe it is far more appropriate for us to compare ourselves with British society than with American society. I refer particularly to the fact that aspects of the development of the nuclear energy industry in the United States have been a little like the development of the building industry in that country, where hotel walkways have collapsed and all sorts of other construction faults have created tremendous dangers and caused a tremendous loss of life. Apparently the negligence in the nuclear construction industry has not been as high as it has been in the construction of schools, public buildings, hotels and other buildings, where there have been huge losses of life. British experience over more than a quarter of a century has been that nuclear energy is cheaper, cleaner and far safer than any other form of energy production available to the British people. I would have thought that that is an experience which we ought to take into account, particularly having regard to the way in which the British have been able to develop from their experience, a proper working safeguards policy. They have the experience upon which we can draw in order to implement a working process of control and regulation.

I accept that any form of energy production has some inherent risk. Undoubtedly there will be accidents in the construction of solar energy production facilities and undoubtedly people will die. There is no doubt that accidents and deaths occur in any form of construction. However, we should compare the risks involved and the losses incurred as a result of nuclear energy generation and those involved in the production of other forms of energy. Even if we accept Senator Coleman's figures as being totally correct-their relationship to this matter is a little dubious but I do not pause to debate that-we should also bear in mind that in the great smog of 1952 in London, 3,900 people died as a result of poisoning by the sulphur dioxide emissions from the coal fired thermal power stations. That is a tremendous number of people. Hydro-electric dams in the United States have caused in excess of 2,500 deaths.

talk.start.para: —How?

—The deaths were caused by destruction. I could mention one of the fears that I would have, as a resident of Launceston, if the prognostications of those who argue against nuclear power development were correct. If it is dangerous because the facilities might be negligently constructed, then I hope that nobody has negligently constructed the Trevallyn dam because if it has been negligently constructed, as apparently some people assume all nuclear power stations will be constructed, then half of Launceston will be wiped out.
—Are you suggesting that would be a bad thing?
—I can imagine that after last Saturday the honourable senator may think it does not matter to him, but I can assure him that it matters to me whether or not Launceston is wiped out.
—You live on a hill; very pleasant.

—I thank the honourable senator. However, I have my office in the area which would be wiped out by any such disaster. Just imagine the damage that would be done to various parts of Tasmania if any of those huge dams have been constructed negligently.
—Better not build any more.

—Senator Mason should not buy into an argument with me about that. In view of the time I will come very quickly to the point I want to make. Bearing in mind the experience of Sweden, the United Kingdom and France, in which there have been recent reviews and recent considered conclusions that nuclear energy is the safest and best form of energy to go on with, and bearing in mind the comparative damage that would be done to the environment by, for example, the construction of a dam in South-West Tasmania where we have the option of losing a huge wilderness area-which I think would be absolutely disastrous for the future of Tasmania, for the future of Australia and for the future of the world-then I cannot see that we should not at least be considering and developing properly the safeguards which will enable the nuclear alternative to be considered if the power is necessary and if there is not a breakthrough, which is unlikely at the moment, in some of the other alternatives which should be pursued. I refer to alternatives such as conservation and co-generation, as well as tidal, wind, solar and other forms of power generation. I believe that we need to consider further development in relation to nuclear energy and that should go ahead as soon as possible.

speech.para: My answer to the concerns of Senator Siddons, Senator Coleman and others is that if, as Senator Coleman said, we have nuclear energy and therefore nuclear weapons, then we already have nuclear weapons either present or anticipated in 50 or more countries and the sooner we get the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty implemented actively with satellite surveillance, on the ground inspection and everything else that follows, then the better we are likely to be able to prevent the sort of holocaust which every reasonable person considers to be of great danger to the world. I cannot see that Australia, as the one country of all comparable countries not going ahead with the development of nuclear energy, is likely to do anything more than cut off its nose to spite its face. I believe that in many ways it would be much better for our own society to look at getting this clean and cheaper form of energy than to go ahead with something which is both dangerous to the health of the public and to the health of those employed in industries such as the coal industry, which creates problems of pollution with carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide and waste materials of various sorts.
