I find it very hard to understand how reasonable people concerned about the environment, concerned about the future of the human race, cannot say that looking rationally at nuclear energy it is far safer and far cleaner than the alternatives. I hope that this debate has advanced the consideration of the nuclear alternative in Australia, and that Australia and the Australian Government will continue to move along the right path. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

proctext.para: Ministerial Statement

speech.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —by leave-On 4 December 1980 Senator Lewis gave notice of a motion that all Bills and amendments to Bills brought into the Senate should be supported by a financial impact statement that provides estimates of gains or losses of government revenue and the cost and recurring annual costs to the Government, industry and other sections of the community in implementing the legislation. We discussed the matter and he later wrote to me proposing instead that a Minister's second reading speech should provide estimates for the balance of the financial year and the next and succeeding financial years in respect of any costs, revenue and savings to the Government and of financial burdens and savings for industry or other sections of the community. I agree, as a general principle, that disclosure of information concerning government costs, revenue and savings expected to arise from proposed legislation leads to more informed parliamentary debate. Where proposed legislation is expected to have significant effects on the Government, it is already common practice for Ministers to disclose that fact and to provide any estimates that can be reliably made. There are, however, good reasons for not making public comprehensive financial estimates for a series of years. These reasons were set out in detail in a statement made to the House of Representatives on 4 March 1980 by the former Minister for Finance, Mr Eric Robinson, in response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled 'Parliament and Public Expenditure'.

speech.para: Briefly, the Government's forward estimates are necessarily based on current knowledge and are subject to substantial uncertainties. If disclosed they could lead to rigidity in expenditures because of the implicit commitments particular interest groups tend to read into such figures no matter how they are qualified. As a result, the Government's budgetary flexibility could be severely curtailed to the detriment of the responsible conduct of economic policy. In some cases, there could be objections to disclosing even first year estimates, for example where a measure has sensitive foreign relations implications. In other cases, such as omnibus legislation, first year estimates may be impossible to calculate with any accuracy or only with an unwarranted allocation of scarce departmental resources to the task. Nor would it generally be possible to provide information about the financial costs and savings for industry or other sections of the community. Many government measures involve costs to some sections of the community and benefits to others, often of an indirect kind, but the net impact, whether in the aggregate or for particular sections, cannot usually be measured with any precision. To attempt to make such estimates could be a costly and complex process necessarily involving consultation with bodies outside the Government. Even then the result would be doubtful estimates that could not be readily interpreted or put to good use. This, of course, does not absolve the Government from the need, when formulating legislation, to take account of the impact on industry and other sections of the community.

Accordingly, after consideration of the matter, the Government has decided that in future, to indicate the financial impact of proposed legislation, a Minister' s second reading speech on a Bill will include, where it is practicable and appropriate to do so, estimates that can readily and reliably be calculated in respect of any significant costs, revenue and savings to the Government arising directly from that legislation. The estimates usually will be the amounts expected for the remainder of the current financial year and the estimated amount for a full financial year when the legislation is fully operative; but, where appropriate, Ministers may provide further information. I am sure that honourable senators will welcome this decision by the Government as a contribution to informed parliamentary debate and public discussion. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —Pressure is coming from various sources to impose fiscal responsibility on the Fraser Government, in contrast with the ad hockery and opportunism which saturate its record. The statement just given by the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, was apparently prompted by a notice of motion from Senator Lewis on 4 December 1980 which was debated on 11 March 1982. The Lewis motion sought to secure financial impact statements on the fiscal effects of all legislation to be incorporated in second reading speeches. What we have just heard from the Minister purports to be a response from the Government to that suggestion. It is in fact an apologia for inertia designed to facilitate the perpetuation of the existing system. The Government and Senator Guilfoyle purport to respond positively to the suggestion of fiscal impact statements or greater fiscal responsibility with these words:

speech.para: . . . the Government has decided that in future, to indicate the financial impact of proposed legislation, a Minister's second reading speech will include . . .

The statement then adds enough qualifications and exclusions to make that commitment meaningless. For example it states that this will be done 'where it is practicable and appropriate' and where the information or the estimates 'can readily and reliably be calculated'.

The statement from Senator Guilfoyle is evasive in a more fundamental and important way. It says nothing about control of what have become known as tax expenditures; that is, tax concessions. Indeed, it fails to acknowledge the concept of tax expenditures or mention tax concessions. A dollar of revenue forgone through a tax concession has at least as much impact on tax levels, government deficits, government borrowing requirements and so on as has a dollar actually spent by the Government. I say at least because in most circumstances it has more effect; in fact it costs more. Most payments distributed by governments are to some degree taxable and therefore the net cost to government revenue of a dollar spent by government is something less than a dollar. The net cost to revenue, to the Budget deficit, to government borrowing requirements or whatever of a dollar of revenue forgone through a tax dodge, a tax concession or tax expenditure is a dollar. Tax concessions or tax expenditures are also much more likely to escape scrutiny by parliament or by anyone else and even to escape detection. On the other hand, overt expenditure by governments must be appropriated. When new legislation is introduced almost invariably estimates of the cost of that new legislation, the direct expenditure incurred by it are given. Every year the cost of direct expenditures can be determined in the Appropriation Bills and other legislation.

An example of the way in which tax expenditure escapes not only scrutiny but also detection was provided by the 64 questions on notice about the cost of revenue of tax concessions. These were put on notice in June last year by Ralph Willis and answered in part in February this year. Of the 64 questions, the cost to revenue of 42 of the concessions could not be costed. The 22 that were costed in the answer supplied by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) incurred a total cost in excess of $1,000m. The cost of the other 42 remains the subject of wide-eyed conjecture. The 22 which were costed, including some outrageous rorts which I will detail, cost more than $1,000m in revenue forgone, equivalent to anything up to $1,500m in direct expenditure by the Government. For the reason that I stated earlier, most or a great deal of payments from government are subject to a tax drawback and therefore the net cost to revenue is somewhat less than 100 per cent. The net cost to revenue of a tax expenditure is 100 per cent. It is no wonder, given the fact that 22 concessions alone have cost revenue more than $1, 000m and 42 could not be costed, that Professor Mathews said at the Australian Institute of Political Science Summer School a few months ago:

the . . . financing system and the disintegrating taxation system which lies at its heart have led to policies directed almost wholly towards the control of government spending, when the real problem which has emerged in Australia is one of restoring control over government revenue.

It is no suprise that this Government avoids a tax expenditure debate. It has so much to hide. No previous government and no previous Prime Minister can match Mr Fraser's profligate record in this respect. Some of the personal contributions of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to fiscal irresponsibility include the announcement that he made on 14 April 1980, straight off the top of his head, that all expenditure on irrigation development, water conservation and water distribution would be immediately deductible from taxable income, some of it at a rate of 120 per cent-a rate which has now been reduced to 118 per cent. When the effect of averaging that concession is taken into account a taxpayer on the maximum marginal rate of 60 per cent gets a 93 per cent government subsidy on non-depreciating capital investment which then incidentally, if the taxpayer cares to cash in the capital gain, is also tax exempt. It is this sort of thing which prompted the advertisement in yesterday's Australian Financial Review headed 'Investment Opportunity-$1,000,000 Tax Deduction'. The advertisement refers to the Mongyer Lagoon property in the Moree district of New South Wales. The advertisment states:
Under current legislation, capital expenditure on irrigation works is tax deductible at a rate of 118 per cent in the year of expenditure.
It goes on to state:
This property offers first class capital security and potential for substantial capital gains.

That is the sort of the anti-social advertisement which has been prompted, initially by the Prime Minister and of course subsequently by the Government, condoning and perpetuating what the Prime Minister has done. No explanation has been given for such a massive subsidy for a particular form of capital investment; that is, a subsidy of 93 per cent--

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that the statement made by the Minister for Finance responded to a call by Senator Lewis that there should be estimates of gains or losses to government revenue and the cost and recurring annual costs to government of any legislation introduced. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to try to help us define the limits to which this debate might properly go and the limits to which speakers might address themselves in the extent to which they wander.

—I have been listening to Senator Walsh. There has been some correlation between the point of view which he has been expressing and the statement brought down by the Minister. However, he is starting to get to the circumference of the issue. I ask the honourable senator to confine his remarks to the ministerial statement.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I wish to respond to the point of order. The matter to which I am referring was the subject of legislation. When that legislation was passed-I think in the autumn session of 1980-no estimate of the cost to revenue was provided to the Parliament when the legislation was presented to it and passed by it. This was exactly the subject of Senator Lewis' s complaint. No explanation was given then and no explanation has been given in other circumstances. No explanation has ever been offered for that 93 per cent hidden public subsidy for a particular form of capital investment. The Prime Minister's own rationale at the time was that it was a relief measure for farmers then stricken by drought. The Prime Minister postulated that a tax dodge for irrigation development would solve the liquidity problems of farmers who had neither water nor money. It was admitted at the time that the proposal was not costed and was not put before Cabinet and that no departmental advice had been sought. It has since been costed by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and the Treasury in submissions to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure at $38m in the current financial year.

speech.para: In October 1980 we received another instalment of fiscal irresponsibility straight off the prime ministerial head with the film tax rort which was either incompetently or dishonestly costed at the time at $2m. It is now admitted that the cost is in the vicinity of $24m-a 1,200 per cent increase. The rort is that expenditure on film production is immediately deductible from taxable income at a rate of 150 per cent and that the first 50 per cent of income derived from that film will be free of income tax. In its original form the write off-the 150 per cent tax deduction-was available as soon as the money was paid into 'a production account'. That of course was a blueprint for the indefinite deferral of taxation without ever making a film; a fact which I have no doubt was soon perceived by John Stone and other watchdogs of the public purse in the Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office and, therefore, modified as from May of last year. But even in its modified form the surviving scheme provides tax expenditure, that is, expenditure of taxpayers' funds, of up to 120 per cent of the cost of producing a film. It would obviously be cheaper for the Government to make the films with money directly appropriated and identified as government expenditure, and then to give the films away. The author and architect of the two schemes that I have outlined is now on a world ego trip to unveil his blueprint for economic recovery.

talk.start.para: —Not for Australia though, for the world. He cannot fix it here but he can fix it for the world.

—Precisely. The class dunce now seeks to become the lecturer. Given the fact that Australia's economic performance, throughout Mr Fraser's prime ministership, compared with that of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development as a whole and compared with the performances of, amongst other countries, Austria, the Netherlands, West Germany and Japan has been dismal and wretched, it is highly unlikely that these nations have anything to learn from Mr Fraser. Fiscal impact statements could enhance the acceptance of fiscal responsibility by governments. The statement by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle makes it perfectly clear that we will get no meaningful financial impact statements or financial responsibility from this Government.

speech.speaker: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

talk.start.para: —I congratulate the Government and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) on this statement. I thank the Minister for it. I am delighted that the Government appears to have accepted about 70 per cent of my proposal. However, before I go any further, I briefly make some reference to the matters which Senator Walsh has just raised. As usual Senator Walsh has been away on a frolic of his own and has totally failed to understand that the purpose of this proposal which I put to the Senate is not control by direct means but simply control by public exposure. In my view, if Ministers are required to make known to the public what the cost of their legislation will be so that the public is able to see that it is not just a matter of whether it sounds as though it might be a good idea or whether it sounds reasonable but that it will cost the community certain millions and millions of dollars, then the public is able to analyse whether it is a good idea in the light of the cost to the taxpayers of the nation. I hope that the public disclosure of the cost of what frequently appear to be simple items of legislation will lead to some restraint.

speech.para: I instance, for example, metrication. In the late 1960s and the 1970s this nation was full of reform. People were wanting to reform things. They could not get around to reforming things quickly enough. In the process they frequently failed to analyse the cost of the reform. As usual, when reform is in the air wisdom goes out the window. The result was that a Senate committee brought down a report about metrication and after some huffing and puffing the Government introduced a metric conversion Bill which went through both of these Houses with every person speaking in favour of it. With due respect to the legislation, there was a total failure to make any estimate of the costs to this nation. Let there be no doubt that the costs to this nation could be measured in hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars, frequently for no value whatsoever. It makes no difference to mum whether she buys a pound of peas or a kilogram of peas. It makes no difference to one's motor vehicle whether one buys a gallon of fuel or a litre of fuel. But just imagine what it has cost the petrol industry to convert gallons to litres throughout the nation. It is an absolute waste of money. No one had really applied his mind to what would be the cost to this nation of such legislation. I am rather hopeful that as a result of this proposal some sort of analysis of legislation will be made. It is disappointing to me that the Government has said that it can provide estimates of its own expenditure and its own revenue in relation to legislation, yet it states-I will quote the words of the Minister for Finance:

Many Government measures involve costs to some sections of the community . . . and benefits to others, often of an indirect kind, but the net impact, whether in the aggregate or for particular sections, cannot usually be measured with any precision.
It concerns me that the Government is not prepared to bite that bullet. The Minister goes on to say that although that estimate is costly, perhaps the results will be doubtful. She then states:
This, of course, does not absolve the Government from the need, when formulating legislation, to take account of the impact on industry and other sections of the community.

In other words, the Government is saying: 'We cannot work all this out. It is a bit difficult for us to work out and make public. In fact, when we introduce the legislation we have to work it out anyway, but we want to keep that to ourselves '. I believe that as a result of the Government's steps, which the Minister has explained to us today, what will happen is that within her Department some people will start to develop some expertise at estimating. In due course, somewhere further down the track, the Government will decide to take steps to make that information on estimates which it must make available to the legislators so that we will be able to understand what will be the cost to the community.

talk.start.para: —It does not matter if those estimates are not absolutely spot on.

—As Senator Chipp said, it does not matter if the estimates are not absolutely spot on. If the Government had said 'We think the cost of metrication to this nation will be $150m', that is not to say that the Parliament would not have adopted it. But the Parliament might very well have said: 'If it is going to cost us $150m, how would it be if we just converted to metric the steel industry or some other aspect?' I am not saying that the Government or the Parliament would not have adopted the metric conversion legislation, but I believe that the Parliament was deprived of a vital piece of information by not having before it a reasonable estimate of what would be the cost to the nation. Industry around this nation has spent on metrication hundreds of millions of dollars which could easily have been spent on increased wages and improved working conditions for the people working in those industries . The industries had to meet these expenses and the result has inevitably been increased prices to the consumer. The consumer had to meet the $150m or $20m, or whatever has been the cost of metrication to this nation. I believe that the legislators, the Parliament, ought to be aware of the cost.

speech.para: I am interested to note that President Reagan in the United States of America has introduced a system called 'regulatory impact analysis' whereby all regulations which are to be brought before him for a signature must have an impact analysis attached to them. I understand that the first thing that has happened is that there has been a slow-down in the regulations of the United States. That must be a good thing. We see so many regulations pouring through our Parliament that one can imagine how many regulations pour through the United States Parliament. Further, the costs of regulations to the nation are required to be analysed in some way. I assure the Parliament that not only will I proceed to keep pressure on the Government in due course to disclose to us the impact on the nation of the legislation brought before the Parliament, but also I give notice now that I intend to continue to press for the cost of regulations to be made public at the time regulations are proclaimed.

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: —I join the Australian Democrats in complimenting very sincerely Senator Lewis in bringing this matter before the Senate. I hope my compliment and support of him do not bring the same response it brought last time, when he misunderstood my compliments and made some rather unkind remarks about me. Quite sincerely, I think he has performed a service for this Parliament in bringing this matter on for debate in this chamber and to the attention of the Government. He moved:

speech.para: That all Bills and amendments to Bills introduced into the Senate from the commencement of the Budget Session 1982 should be accompanied by a financial impact statement--
I stress the words 'financial impact statement'-
which shall contain the following information for each of:
(1) the balance of the financial year; and
(2) the following two financial years-
(a) the estimated costs to Government (if any)
(b) the estimated revenue of Government (if any)
(c) the estimated savings of Government (if any)
(d) the estimated financial burden . . .
(e) the estimated savings (if any) which will be of benefit to industry or other sections of the community.

I believe that unassailable logic is contained in that proposition. Senator Lewis gave the startling example of metrication. I wonder whether this Parliament would have agreed to the excesses of metrication when we did, had we known the true social cost, the true financial impact. I remember that once during the metrication cycle we went through the insanity of making a criminal or other offence-I think it would be a criminal offence-of bringing in a ruler marked in inches. It was an offence against the Crown. I am not saying necessarily that would have been prevented had Senator Lewis's wishes been adopted and in operation at that stage. But certainly we would have had a rethink about the so-called virtues, the manic desire, the fanaticism to pursue metrication, had the Parliament had such financial impact statements before it. After complimenting Senator Lewis, I also want to compliment the Government. Unlike the spokesman for the Labor Party, I believe that credit should be given where it is due. It is clear, as the spokesman for the Labor Party said, that the Government has not gone nearly as far as Senator Lewis wishes, but certainly it has gone a fair way down the track. On 11 March, which was not too long ago, when Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle promised to undertake some action on this matter, it was agreed that the Government-I quote from the Minister's speech--
has decided that in future, to indicate the financial impact of proposed legislation, a Minister's second reading speech on a Bill will include, where it is practicable and appropriate to do so--
That sentence frightens the hell out of me, as it does to anyone, but I suppose it has to be in there-
estimates that can readily and reliably be calculated in respect of any significant costs, revenue and savings to the Government arising directly from that legislation.

That is a significant step forward in the information given to senators before they vote on a Bill, and it is a tribute to Senator Lewis and to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, and indeed, to the Government for acquiescing.

Having said that, I conclude by expressing the hope that the Senate in its wisdom in future years will go further than simply financial impact statements and come to social impact statements on legislation. There is an area here where this Parliament thinks too often and too restrictedly about questions of money. We adopt a balance sheet mentality on legislation that comes before us. We say: 'It is going to cost this or save that; therefore it is a good thing'. I believe that in much legislation, while it might well be useful, and it is useful for Senator Lewis's proposal to be adopted so that senators know what the financial cost of something should be, we ought also to be informed of what the social cost and the social plusses of legislation might be.

I give two or three brief examples. On education, how absurd it is to mention or to have our minds directed only to the dollar cost of education when debating it. That is all that we do. Having sat in Cabinet, I know the unenviable job of the Minister for Education. When he comes in to make his submission at Budget time or comes into Cabinet with a submission on a matter of education, he is regarded as an irritation. People say: 'God, you want some more millions from us for education.' Instead of regarding education as a vital necessity and an investment, because of the psychology of this place the Minister for Education is now regarded as a menace who is going to produce an unanswerable argument for spending on something millions of dollars that we wish we could save. Unless we have a turn-around and look at the social impact of what we are doing, that balance sheet mentality will remain.

I give two brief examples of private members' Bills brought in by the Australian Democrats. I have one Bill now before the Senate-I hope it will be debated and passed by all parties this week-which removes from the Sales Tax Assessment Act that part of the cost represented by freight which represents a component of cost for the purpose of assessing sales tax. In other words, when the 12 1/2 per cent sales tax goes on to an item, the Democrats believe very strongly that it should go on the cost of that item and that freight should not be included in the unit cost of the item before the sales tax is applied, because if it is-and it is now under present legislation-people living in rural areas are being discriminated against. They are being penalised for living in the country. Not only are they paying for the freight itself to bring both raw materials and finished goods from city to country, but also they are paying additional sales tax on the goods because freight is included in the unit cost of the goods upon which the sales tax is levied. That is a double payment for people living in rural communities.

It is a relatively simple matter, to follow Senator Lewis's proposition, for the Minister to say that the financial impact of legislation will be X dollars, the savings in the cost to the revenue will be X dollars. That might be several million dollars. But I believe that the Senate would be in a far better position to assess the value of the Bill to be debated here, I hope, next Thursday, if it had a social impact statement with it as well. Perhaps some group in the Government can assess and bring to the Senate a statement showing the beneficial effects which will accrue from decentralisation and the social impact of this world-wide exodus of people from rural areas to city areas: The increase in pollution, crime, drug addiction, prostitution, and family breakdowns, and of all those social factors which a move away from decentrali- sation to centralisation is causing.

As it is now, the Senate, when the Bill is debated next Thursday, will be tempted to look at this question-I am sure that the Government will look at it- and to say: 'The deficit in the Budget has blown over; it is more than we thought; this Bill of the Australian Democrats, although it will help country people, will make the deficit blow out further; therefore we shall oppose it'. Honourable senators will not even consider or contemplate the social advantages that would accrue to country people, and the social advantages to the whole nation, if we could use this and other measures of attracting people from the cities back to country areas. That is why I say that the excellent suggestion of Senator Lewis should be built on by having statements on social implications as well.

The last example I give is that of the other private member's Bill that I have before the Senate, on which I shall not be pushing for a vote before the Senate rises because I suspect that it would not yet have the approval of the majority of the members of the Senate. I refer to the imposition of a tax on the advertising of alcohol. The liquor industry has been very active among members of the House of Representatives and senators since I introduced the Bill. If ever there was a unanswerable case to be presented for a massive advertising campaign to people in Australia not necessarily not to drink but, if they drink, to not drive, it is here. I think that 55 people died on Australia's roads over the brief Easter period. Something like 200 to 300 people became permanently maimed over that period because they drove motor vehicles after abusing alcohol.

I think an unanswerable case in logic can be built up for placing a tax on advertising under the user pays principle and using that that money for counter- advertising and saying to people: 'If you are going to drink for God's sake don' t drive a car and kill someone or maim someone who is innocent'. If Senator Lewis's excellent suggestion is adopted a financial impact statement can accompany that Bill and honourable senators will know what is the cost to revenue and what is the cost to the breweries or whatever. But they will have no idea of the social savings and the social impact of that legislation. I would have thought that if that statement could accompany a Bill such as mine to introduce a tax on the advertising of alcohol it would present logic that would be totally unassailable. We will probably look at that-as the breweries and the liquor interests are now asking honourable senators to look at it-simply with a balance sheet mentality. I conclude by complimenting Senator Lewis for an initiative that has been successful. I compliment the Government for reacting positively to a good initiative.

speech.speaker: McLaren Sen G.T.

talk.start.para: —My remarks will be brief. At the outset , I want to reject the criticism that was levelled at my colleague Senator Walsh during his remarks. At one stage a point of order was raised and it was said that Senator Walsh was departing from the context of the statement by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle). However, since then the debate has been very wide-ranging, particularly with regard to the comments of Senator Chipp. I look forward to Senator Chipp's introduction of a Bill on the advertising of alcohol and to the financial impact statement which he will put down with the Bill to see what this measure will cost the Government in revenue.
—What do you mean by 'cost the Government'? It is going to give the Government money.
—It might. That is why I am looking forward to seeing the financial impact statement on what it will cost.
—It won't cost us anything. Do I have to tell you again?

—The honourable senator has said that. I accept that at the present time. We will see about that. That is not the reason why I rose to speak to this financial statement put down by the Minister for Finance. I congratulate Senator Lewis on having achieved some small success. He has his foot in the door with this matter. I hope that as time goes by this statement will go much further and that some definite figures will be given by the Government not only insofar as legislation and amendments to legislation are concerned but also in relation to government expenditure.

speech.para: I was attracted to an article yesterday in the National Times by Geoffrey Kitney dealing with the enormous cost to the taxpayer of the Government Information Unit. When the GIU was first set up we were led to believe that it would cost no more than $100,000. Of course, the Government is having a great deal of difficulty in getting its message across to the people. The Government is now spending, according to Mr Kitney, nearly $4.1m on the GIU operation. If every Budget time a statement could be put down in this Parliament of what the Government intends to spend in the future-the Government might bring down only one more Budget-over and above what it told us it was going to spend when it first set up the GIU the taxpayer would be more enlightened.

There are many other methods of government expenditure which we could look at also. That would be very enlightening. We heard the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) give notice today of all the overseas jaunts that will be taken by Ministers during the recess. We all recall very well the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in 1975 when he said that he would not be a tourist Prime Minister and that his Ministers would stay at home and not waste public money in the way he accused the previous Government of doing. Yet, we had a long list of Ministers' names given to us today. There was no mention of the amount the taxpayers will have to foot while these people are overseas or of the cost of the visits of all of the people who have gone before them and those who will go after them while this Government remains in office. I completely reject the criticism which was levelled at Senator Walsh and the strictures which were placed upon him following a point of order so that he could not develop his argument to the extent that Senator Chipp was allowed. However Senator Walsh is capable of taking care of himself and he will do that at some future time, no doubt during the financial debate. I say again that I hope that this is a forerunner and an opening of the door much wider so that we in this Parliament will be able to debate at length the costs of much of the legislation which is being brought down by this Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill to amend the income tax law covers two important subjects.
It will give effect to the Government's decision, announced by the Treasurer on 14 April 1982, to amend the secrecy provisions of the income tax law.
The amendments will permit the Commissioner of Taxation-in very special and limited circumstances-to disclose to certain royal commissions information obtained from official income tax records.

The second main feature of the Bill is the legislation necessary to give effect to one of the housing assistance measures announced by the Government, namely the scheme of home loan interest tax rebates that was foreshadowed by the Treasurer on 18 March 1982.

Associated with this group of measures is another amendment which will permit the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Construction to be given information from income tax records for the purposes of administration of the Government's new scheme of home deposit assistance to families on low incomes.
I turn now to the details of these measures.
Disclosure of taxation information to certain royal commissions

The secrecy provisions of the income tax law generally require that the Commissioner of Taxation and his officers maintain absolute confidentiality about information on taxpayers' affairs that comes into the possession of the Commissioner in the course of administration of the income tax law.

However, there is in the law authority for the Commissioner to supply taxation information to specified authorities, mainly those having responsibility for the administration of laws under which benefits of one kind or another are paid by the Commonwealth.

In this situation, Mr President, the Government recognises that the amendments now proposed do break new ground. The measures are in response to recommendations contained in interim report No. 3 of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and follow a strong plea by the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking.

Provisions in the Bill will specifically permit the Commissioner of Taxation to make information from income tax records available to these two ongoing royal commissions. It will allow such information to be passed to other royal commissions that are given terms of reference that authorise such a course.

A royal commission that receives information obtained from taxation records will be able to disclose it in any report to the Governor-General, or in its proceedings, so long as this is done in a way that does not disclose the identity of the person or persons concerned.

In addition as a result of amendments made to the Bill in another place, the Bill in the form before the Senate will facilitate examination in camera of a person appearing before a royal commission, by permitting disclosure of taxation information to that person or to counsel representing that person if the information concerns the affairs of the person or was furnished to the Commissioner of Taxation by that person.

A royal commission will also be permitted to divulge tax information, including identification of persons, to the Attorney-General if it holds the view that the information indicates that there may have been a breach of a Commonwealth Act.

In turn the Attorney-General may, if he considers it appropriate to do so, pass on the information reported to him by a royal commission to the Australian Federal Police, which will be able to use it for internal purposes.
Mr President, the Government has not lightly taken the decision to permit these royal commissions to be provided with confidential tax information.

It is an old and well established principle in this country that taxation information should be kept confidential and the effectiveness of the taxation system owes a lot to that very important principle.
In coming to this decision, therefore, the Government had to weigh very carefully two competing areas of public interest.

On the one hand there was the need to maintain taxation confidentiality and, on the other, there was the necessity for action to be taken to support enquiries in particular areas of special public interest.

In these circumstances, in reaching the decision we have come to, we have felt it appropriate to ensure that the highest possible level of confidentiality, compatible with the decision, should be maintained.
Accordingly, the proposed legislation will impose very strict secrecy restraints on persons to whom taxation information is conveyed under the new provisions.

These restraints will be of the same general kind as those that already apply to taxation officers and others who receive taxation information and will extend to the royal commissions, the Attorney-General and the Australian Federal Police , as well as to the respective staffs of those bodies or persons to whom tax information may necessarily be communicated.
Furthermore, the proposed amendments are so structured that persons to whom confidential tax information is conveyed under them will be precluded from using it in an action to prosecute any person.
Mr President, it bears repeating that these amendments do not evidence any policy of generally easing the strict confidentiality applying to tax records.
As the Treasurer said when he was foreshadowing these amendments, their effect will be watched very closely and they are not to be taken as a precedent for any other relaxation of tax secrecy.
Home Loan Interest Rebate
Mr President, honourable senators may recall that, on 18 March 1982, the Treasurer made a ministerial statement in another place following a detailed review by the Government of housing policy.

In his statement the Treasurer reinforced the Government's commitment to preserving the highest practicable level of private home ownership in Australia and identified four main problem areas in the field of housing finance.
This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision to alleviate one of those problems-the burden of mortgage payments.
These tend to be highest in real terms, of course, in the early years of a housing loan.
This Bill proposes the provision of a rebate of tax for home loan interest payments made on or after 1 July 1982.
The basic features of the rebate were referred to in the Treasurer's statement, and he also released a detailed supporting statement at that time.

In those circumstances, I trust that I can be brief in my references now to the rebate, particularly as it is explained fully in the explanatory memorandum that is being made available to honourable senators.

The rebate of tax to be authorised by this Bill will be available to an individual taxpayer resident in Australia in respect of the first five years of occupancy of the person's sole or principal residence here.

Subject to certain upper limits, the basic rebate will be 32 cents for each dollar of interest paid on or after 1 July 1982 and during the relevant income year, provided the interest has accrued while the taxpayer occupied the dwelling .
A feature of the rebate is that existing home-owners may qualify.

It will be available to home-owners who first occupied a sole or principal residence on or after 1 July 1977, and will extend to those who first occupy a sole or principal residence no later than 30 June 1985.

For a married person-and this will apply also to a person in a de facto marriage relationship-the five year occupancy period will run from the date on which either of the partners first become an owner-occupier of such a residence.
As regards the limits on the rebate, the basic upper limit will be $500 per dwelling in the first year of owner-occupancy, to be reduced by $100 per year for each subsequent year.

Rules covering people who took up occupancy prior to 1 July 1982 will mean, for example, that if the occupancy occurred in 1981-82 the person will be eligible for the full first year limit of $500 in 1982-83.
The limit otherwise applicable in any year will, however, be increased by an additional amount of $200 where the dwelling is also home for a dependent child or dependent student.

Where a taxpayer changes his or her place of residence within the five year period, he or she will be entitled to the rebate in respect of interest attributable to the acquisition of the second dwelling, but the upper limit will be determined having regard to the date on which he or she occupied the original dwelling.

Special arrangements will apply where two or more persons have interests in a dwelling which is occupied by them as their sole or principal residence and where a dwelling is also used by a taxpayer for purposes other than as a sole or principal residence.
In the case of a matrimonial home the interest rebate will be transferable between spouses irrespective of which one incurred and paid the interest.
This will help to ameliorate the effect of another basic rule, which is that the rebate cannot exceed the tax otherwise payable by the taxpayer.
With those introductory remarks, I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

The purpose of this Bill is twofold. Firstly, it extends the Government's assistance schemes relating to phosphate and nitrogenous fertilizers for a further three year period until 30 June 1985. Secondly, it widens the scope of the phosphate fertilizer scheme to provide for the payment of a subsidy on both locally produced and imported fertilizers.
The original fertilizer schemes were introduced in the mid- 1960's to stimulate increased use of fertilizers as a means of expanding agricultural production.

The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) recently submitted to the Government its report on the question of whether assistance should continue to be provided for the consumption of nitrogenous and phosphate fertilizers after 30 June 1982 when current assistance arrangements are due to expire.

Following examination of this report, the Government decided to accept the IAC' s recommendation that the current schemes be extended for a further three years. However, it has been decided to defer a decision on a further recommendation of the IAC that the assistance should be terminated after 30 June 1985.

The amendments to widen the scope of the phosphate fertilizer scheme were made in the other place on 5 May 1982. This extension to cover imports will ensure that farmers have adequate access to fertilizers at competitive prices.

The subsidy on imported phosphate fertilizers will be payable on those fertilizers which are imported between 1 July 1982 and 30 June 1985 and sold for use, or used by the importer, in Australia as a fertilizer or are used by the importer in the production of a fertilizer mixture for use in Australia.

The Government has considered the situation of Australian fertilizer manufacturers who receive a measure of protection from the current arrangements. In this regard, the Government accepted the IAC's view that the payment of a subsidy on imported phosphatic fertilizers would not be likely to lead to a significant reduction in the local manufacture of these fertilizers.

Australian manufacturers at present produce virtually all of Australia's phosphatic fertilizer requirements. The IAC found that domestic production is efficient in that output is generally competitive at world prices. The IAC also considered that single strength superphosphate produced in Australia has a significant price advantage over potential imports.

For the next three years, assistance will continue to be paid at current rates These are $20 per tonne of contained nitrogen for nitrogenous fertilizers and $ 12 per tonne of single strength superphosphate or $138 per tonne on the available phosphorous content of other phosphatic fertilizers.
The subsidy schemes are estimated to involve a relatively constant annual budgetary outlay of from $60m to $65m.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

proctext.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a further payment of $A8,965,000.00 to be paid initially in the form of promissory notes, to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). As honourable senators will know Australia was one of the founding members of the Fund, which commenced operations in 1977.

The primary objective of the Fund is to help increase agricultural production in developing countries. In addition, its activities are focussed on the poorest nations and the poorest sections of rural populations. The initial capital resources of the Fund totalled $US1 billion to which Category I members, the OECD countries, and Category II members, the OPEC countries, contributed, with nominal amounts being contributed by Category III members, the developing countries. These initial resources have been fully committed in the Fund's first four years of operation. A replenishment of the Fund is therefore necessary to enable IFAD to continue its lending program. Although commitments from donors are urgently required to enable the Fund to approve existing and new loan proposals through to 1984, no draw-down of the new resources will occur for some time. Australia will not in fact incur any expenditure under this replenishment in the 1981-82 financial year.

Negotiations as to the overall replenishment level, to be recommended to concerned governments, commenced early in 1980. After prolonged inter-category and extra-category discussions a target of $US1.1 bilion was finally agreed on at the fifth Governing Council session in January 1982. Of this target Category I countries agreed to contribute up to $US620m and Category II countries up to $ US450m. In order for Category I countries to move beyond the earlier category target of $US595m, five countries have pledged additional contributions. Australia is technically regarded as one of these countries by virtue of the Government's decision to contribute its share of 1.74 per cent of up to $US600m, which is $US10.44m, equivalent at the ruling exchange rate to a contribution of $A8,965,000.00.

The Government believes that the International Fund for Agricultural Development plays an important role in the promotion of increased food production in developing countries. The Fund accords with one of our chief aid priorities in providing the impetus and wherewithal for developing countries to help themselves achieve self-reliance in food production. IFAD plays an important role in promoting long-term food security in developing countries through its focus on projects in the agricultural sector. These projects cover not only increasing production but also give specific attention to the poorest groups, taking into account distribution and availability which are key aspects of developing countries' overall food security. The countries and regions in which IFAD is concentrating its assistance are precisely those in which the major problems of food insecurity are most acute. Australia sees the concentration of effort on food security matters as a particularly productive avenue for achieving progress in the North-South dialogue at present. As a major primary producing country with considerable agricultural expertise it is especially appropriate that Australia should play an active role in an organisation such as IFAD.

I believe that it is both in Australia's national interest and in the interest of the international community as a whole that we should continue to support the International Fund for Agricultural Development by contributing $A8,965,000.00 to the replenishment of the Fund. This amount represents essentially continuation of Australia's overall share in the Fund. I hope that other countries especially the larger donors, will act promptly to lodge their agreed contributions, to enable IFAD to continue its important work in improving the lives of millions of poor people.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-
This Bill will amend the income tax law in two respects.
Firstly, the Bill will make further amendments to the secrecy provisions of the income tax law.

These amendments are supplementary to those proposed in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 by which certain royal commissions, the Attorney-General and the Australian Federal Police will be permitted to be supplied with taxation information in special circumstances.

The second feature of the Bill is the provision of an exemption from tax for income derived by a company-to be called the Australian Wool Testing Authority Limited-that is being formed to take over the Australian Wool Testing Authority as a going concern and to continue the functions of the authority.
I turn now to the details of these measures.
Disclosure of Taxation Information to Certain Royal Commissions

Mr President, the amendments proposed by this Bill to section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act are designed to limit further the circumstances in which a royal commission may communicate confidential taxation information to the Attorney-General.

As honourable senators know, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 proposes that a royal commission which receives information from the Commissioner of Taxation may disclose that information to the Attorney-General where it appears from the information that a law of the Commonwealth has been breached.

By the amendments proposed in the present Bill a royal commission will not be permitted to communicate taxation information to the Attorney-General unless it is of the opinion that the information indicates that a person may have committed an offence against a Commonwealth Act which carries a penalty of 6 months or more imprisonment.

This qualification to the measures follows the raising of certain matters during the course of debate in another place on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 and is made in recognition of acceptance by the Government of a view put forward by the Opposition that only in cases of some gravity should confidential tax information be capable of being passed to the Attorney-General and the police.

As this tighter restriction modifies measures contained in the Income Tax Assessment Bill (No. 2), the proposed new commencement provisions will mean that the change will take effect coincidentally with the taking effect of those measures.
Australian Wool Testing Authority Limited
Honourable senators would be aware that the existing wool testing authority is a body corporate established under the Wool Industry Act and that its income is exempt from tax.

Following the review of Commonwealth functions carried out last year, the Government decided to transfer the authority to the private sector and legislation authorising the transfer was subsequently passed by the Parliament.

The purpose of the legislation now proposed is to provide an exemption from income tax for the new private sector company-the Australian Wool Testing Authority Limited-the members of which will be drawn mainly from bodies representative of the various sectors of the wool industry.

Mr President, the exemption from income tax provided by the Bill will be limited to income derived by the company from carrying out functions of the kind that the Wool Testing Authority is authorised to carry out.

Accordingly, the exemption will apply to income derived on or after 1 July 1982 from the testing of wool and other fibres and their products, and from the issuing of certificates and the making of reports on such tests.

The exemption will correspondingly apply to income derived by the company from the investment of surplus income from its testing activities or of funds that are to be used in or in connection with its testing operations.
An explanatory memorandum on the Bill is being made available to honourable senators, and I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this legislation is to give effect to the Government's decisions on two significant recommendations made by the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Parliaments Appropriations and Staffing and, related to the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration regarding the promotions and transfer procedures in the Public Service, amendments concerning the requirement to give reports to officers who are aggrieved by decisions made in relation to promotions, transfers and temporary performance of higher duties. The Bill also includes certain other amendments to the Public Service Act 1922 and other legislation, to which I refer later in my speech.

In 1976 the Royal Commission made a number of recommendations to improve the promotion and transfer processes within the Public Service. The recommendations were examined extensively by the Public Service Board, following consultations with the Joint Council, a statutory consultative body chaired by the Public Service Board, and including representatives of departments and peak union councils. This Bill gives effect to the Government's decisions on those recommendations.

The proposed new promotion arrangements will revise procedures which were introduced in 1946. The Government believes that it is time for the introduction of new promotion procedures which are designed to meet the contempary needs of the Service, but will continue to uphold, and indeed strengthen, the tradition of a Public Service based on merit for appointment and promotion. The Bill establishes relative efficiency as the sole criterion for promotion in the Australian Public Service by repealing all references to seniority. Honourable senators will appreciate that, besides providing an equitable basis for the advancement of officers, this change is an important manifestation of the primary purpose of the promotion process, namely, to advance the efficient operation of the service. It will remove the last vestige of credibility from the mistaken view that advancement of officers under the Public Service Act is determined by length of service. The Bill introduces revised arrangements which will enhance the efficiency of the Public Service. In this connection I draw the attention of honourable senators to the provisions relating to the advertising of vacancies and the appointment by the Governor-General of chairmen and promotions appeal committees for fixed terms.

The promotion process is an important factor in the efficiency and economy of the Public Service. Procedures for the promotion of officers therefore must be devised to make the most effective practicable contribution to the efficient functioning of the Service. The Bill seeks to foster that objective. The proposed section 50B defines the sole criterion for promotion as the relative efficiency of officers available for promotion. That section requires regard to be paid to the capacity, work performance, experience, qualifications and personal qualities of the officer. In some cases it is desirable that greater weight be given to one or another of these factors and sub-section 50B (3) authorises the Board to so direct.

Sub-section 33 (2) is directed to timeliness in the filling of vacant positions . This provision allows the procedures to be initiated as soon as a vacancy is forseen and for the completion of all formal steps-that is advertising, selection and appeal processes-to be taken in anticipation of the vacancy arising from, say, the age retirement of an officer. The amendment provisions, of course, bring that staffing action into effect only when the vacancy actually arises. Section 50L provides the permanent head with more flexibility in allocating his resources within his department. The section authorises the permanent head to rotate officers between positions. It is important that the authority of the permanent head should be clear in order that he can best utilise the skills and abilities of officers available within the department to meet the changing needs and shifts of emphasis in the activities of the department.

The promotion appeals system is an integral part of the promotion process. It is inevitable that such a system is a source of delay in filling positions by promotion and it has been much criticised for that reason. Nonetheless, the Government believes that, in the interests of strengthening the efficiency of the Public Service an appeal system is necessary. The Government believes the present system, as it has operated in the past, with promotions appeal committees comprising an independent chairman, a departmental nominee and a staff association nominee is appropriate. It may not be generally realised that some 70,000 appeals were lodged in 1979 and approximately 35,000 were lodged in 1980, and the promotions appeal committee arrangements have on the whole dealt with that volume expeditiously. This has been possible through established procedures not being overburdened by formality and by the committees avoiding procedures which place appellants in the unwanted role of adversaries.

Recent court decisions appear to indicate that, as the Public Service Act is presently worded, the promotions appeal system should be conducted within an adversary framework and require a greater degree of legal formality than has in practice applied, or is necessary or desirable, to see that an appellant's case is fairly and fully heard and determined. The Government's view is that the objective of the appeals system-giving to public servants the opportunity to state their case for promotion in competition with others, whilst facilitating the promotion of the most efficient officers in the interests of overall Public Service efficiency-will be best served by amending the Public Service Act to establish beyond doubt that promotions appeal committees can deal with the appeals coming before them on a basis which gives to appellants a full and fair opportunity to put their own cases for promotion and to answer any matter adverse to their interests before the committee without an undue emphasis on legal formalities or the creation of an adversary framework. Section 50D of the Bill seeks to achieve this. It will permit promotions appeal committees to develop procedures to ensure fairness in determining appeals while paying regard to desirable personnel practice, and to the practicalities and costs of handling the very large volume of appeals made annually.

The Bill also provides for officers who are aggrieved by decisions made in relation to promotions, transfers and temporary performance of higher duties to be given reports about those decisions. These amendments are contained in the proposed sections 53L to 53N and the transitional provisions in the proposed sections 79 to 81. These provisions reflect the Government's recognition of the recent developments in administrative law; however, they are quite distinct from the proposed amendments to the promotions appeal arrangements in proposed section 50D. The provisions of that section deal with the procedures which are to apply to the hearing of an appeal by a promotions appeal committee. The provisions to be introduced by sections 53L to 53N, deal with the requirement to give an explanation, on request, of decisions by promotions appeal committees. Each provision is the complement of the other but they apply to different aspects of the decision making process.

The Government has a clearly stated policy that persons affected by decisions made under statute should have the right to seek a statement of reasons. The proposed sections 53L to 53N introduce provisions to give effect to this policy in terms which are specifically tailored to the needs and requirements of the Public Service promotions process. They permit a person aggrieved by a promotion decision, being decisions to transfer, promote or direct an oficer to perform temporarily the duties of an office and the associated decisions of appeal committees, to request a statement which explains the basis for that decision. This statement will enable the officer to understand why the decision was made and will provide a proper basis for him to consider whether that decision should be further challenged. The provision will require that the statement in relation to a decision to promote another officer must contain a copy of the relevant duty statement, the criteria that were used in selecting the successful person, the procedures which followed and an assessment of the officer seeking the statement against the criteria which were used. These specific requirements will be in substitution for the more general requirements of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

The proposed provisions are intended to strike a balance between conflicting elements which arise in the promotion process. There is a need to consider the privacy of those who were applicants for promotion. It is an important element of personnel management that individual staff members should have information on themselves protected from unwarranted disclosure. On the other hand, there is the right of an officer to know and understand decisions which have been made about him or her. The proposed amendments provide, however, for the continuation of the application of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act in all other respects and, in addition, provide that statements under these provisions will be handled in the same manner as statements under section 13 of that Act so that, firstly, reports can be the basis of legal action under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, secondly, reports can be reviewed by a Federal Court as to their adequacy, and, thirdly, an officer refused a report on the basis that he or she is not entitled to it can seek a review by a Federal Court. Time limits on the making of requests and the supplying of reports are similar to those in the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act as are other technical provisions relating to the exercise of decisions by delegates. In the light of the special provisions that will be made in the Public Service Act, the relevant decisions defined in the proposed section 53L will be exempted from the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

Clauses 79 to 81 are transitional provisions which will apply similar requirements to those in the proposed section 53L to decisions made under the Principal Act before the amendments made by this Bill are proclaimed to come into operation. There have been consultations on the proposals for reporting on reasons for decisions with representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Council of Professional Associations. The amended provisions now to be introduced include some of the proposals made by these representatives although the Government was unable to accept all the proposals made.

Another important change made by the Bill is to remove the divisional structure of the Public Service, as was recommended by the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. Since 1901 positions and officers have been grouped into four divisions. Significantly, the present structure requires different levels of educational qualification and skills for admission to the Third Division and Fourth Division. The original design envisaged a small number of separate salary structures: the First Division for permanent heads and like officers; the Second Division for senior executives; the Third Division for clerical and professional positions; and the Fourth Divisions for the remaining officers.

Some of the occupational groups which have been introduced in the structure of the Service in recent years do not sit well within the divisional framework and it has been necessary to develop complicated dual divisional arrangements. Further, whereas all Third Division officers were once paid in accordance with a uniform scale of salaries, there are now more than 60 separate pay groupings, many of them based on special training or qualifications. Consequently, the divisional structure has become increasingly anachronistic. Clause 15 repeals those sections of the Act providing for the divisional structure. The proposed arrangements will enable the design of occupational groupings to be tailored more readily to the operational requirements of the Public Service. They will help to achieve better utilisation of the manpower resources of the Service. Staff in the Public Service will continue to be employed within separate occupational groups, each with its own salary structure and appropriate qualification requirements, but the label of Fourth, Third or Second Division will no longer apply. Movement within or between occupational groups will, as now, depend on efficiency and, where relevant, qualifications. Consequent upon the removal of the divisional structure the provisions of the Act relating to recruitment have been amended. The new provision retains the central role of the Public Service Board to ensure that the Commonwealth continues to be served by public servants who are selected according to merit in open competition and not by processes based on patronage or nepotism.

The other amendments to the Public Service Act are more limited in their effect . The first relates to the amendment to that part of the Public Service Act covering the staffing of the parliamentary departments. These amendments reflect the Government's decisions on the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. Briefly, the changes will enhance the autonomy of the parliamentary departments by empowering the Presiding Officers to create or abolish offices and to promote officers. The present provisions of the Public Service Act require these matters to be submitted to the Governor-General in Council for approval.

Clause 44 of the Bill inserts a new section 64, which updates the debt recovery scheme which enables creditors to obtain payments from debtors employed by the Australian Public Service by means of attachment of their salaries. The revised scheme introduces an administration fee payable by the creditor to offset the costs incurred by the Commonwealth in arranging collection of the debt. The amendments will bring arrangements for the recovery of debts from public servants more closely in line with normal practices in the community. Clauses 53 and 58 of the Bill include amendments which will provide that the agreement of the State Premier must be obtained where it is proposed to invoke the mobility provisions of Part IV of the Public Service Act in relation to State employment. Part IV of the Act specifies the rights of staff of the Service who transfer to other public employment.

Amendments are also made to the Superannuation Act 1976 and the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976. In the normal course, severance payments upon retrenchment are more favourable than those made upon resignation. The effect of these amendments will, upon certification of the Board, debar from entitlement to retrenchment benefits which would otherwise accrue, an employee of the Commonwealth covered by these Acts who is retrenched after declining an offer of suitable alternative Commonwealth employment. The Government does no consider that in this situation the person should be entitled to retrenchment benefits when it is in fact his or her own decison to sever his or her employment relationship with the Commonwealth when suitable employment within the Public Service is available.

The third group of amendments insert a new section 39 into the Act which will enable dual appointments of permanent heads. By virtue of this provision a person who is already a permanent head can be appointed to hold simultaneously another office of permanent head. A person holding two offices of permanent head will be paid only salary and allowances appropriate to the original office. Clause 82 is a transitional provision which will enable dual appointment to occur prior to the revised arrangements for the appointment of permanent heads being proclaimed to come into operation. The Government considers that such flexibility is desirable.

The remaining provisions in the Act are of three types. The first deals with changes to the technical arrangements for appointment of acting permanent heads and other changes of a similar kind which experience indicates will lead to improvements in the administration of the Service. The second, including the changes made to the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act, is consequential on the changes made to the promotion process and the abolition of divisions within the Service. The rest are formal amendments to adjust references in other legislation. The Government believes that the changes introduced in this Bill have significant benefits for the efficiency of the Service. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
