AIR ACCIDENTS (COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982
This Bill complements the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Amendment Bill 1982 which I have just introduced into the Senate.

The Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963 is a companion statute to the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Act 1959. It applies to persons travelling as passengers in aircraft operated by the Commonwealth and to passengers on aircraft not so operated who are travelling as Commonwealth employees, or other persons whose cost of travel is met by the Commonwealth or who are travelling for the purposes of the Commonwealth.

This Bill increases from $45,000 to $100,000 the limit of liability of the Commonwealth in respect of personal injury or death arising from an air accident . This is consistent with the limits proposed in the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Amendment Bill 1982 which I have just introduced. By this Bill, the Commonwealth will meet the same conditions of liability in respect of air accidents as it imposes on commercial airline and charter operators.
The Bill also extends the application of the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963 to certain classes of persons currently without a cause of action under the legislation.

The definition of 'passenger' has been broadened to cover aircrew and airborne workers such as aerial photographers, instrument fitters etc. This extension of coverage is based on the Governments view that there is normally a commonality of employment between aircrew airborne workers and passengers carried in aircraft on Commonwealth sponsored flights to which the legislation applies. Under the new criteria all Commonwealth employees killed or injured in aircraft accidents on such flights will have a similar cause of action against the Commonwealth for damages. The provision does not however apply to aircrew of an authority or corporation undertaking commercial transport operations.

The Bill also contains a provision whereby persons with concurrent repatriation pension rights arising from an air accident during peace-time service will no longer be debarred from claiming damages under the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963. In 1973, repatriation entitlement was extended to cover peace-time defence service and the exclusion provisions of the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963 thereupon debarred a cause of action against the Commonwealth for damages. The modification of the exclusion provisions now proposed will mean that where concurrent entitlement to a Repatriation pension arises during peace-time service, a member of the Defence Force or his dependants will now also have a cause of action under the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963. Any damages awarded as the result of a claim will be taken into account to reduce the concurrent Repatriation pension so as to avoid any ''double benefit'' accruing in respect of the one accident.

Finally, liability under the Principal Act is proposed to be adjusted in future by reference to the limit of liability applicable under section 31 (1) of the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Act 1959 as proposed to be amended by the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Amendments Bill 1982.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CIVIL AVIATION (CARRIERS' LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

The purpose of this Bill is to amend part four of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act to accord with the Government's decision to increase the liability limits applying to domestic and non-convention international air carriage and to make provision for the Act to cover the new air service licence classifications that are to be introduced.

The Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act gives force of law in Australia to the Warsaw Convention and Hague Protocol which limit the extent of airlines' liabilities in respect of damages arising from carriage on international flights . More specifically, Part IV of the Act applies similiar conditions to domestic airline and charter operations in Australia and to non-convention international carriage.

Under Part IV of the Act the liability of domestic and non-convention international carriers for death or injury to passengers, or damage to baggage, is limited. Passengers or their relatives do not need to prove negligence on the part of the operator. The injured party is required to prove the amount of damages being claimed and the amount awarded is then limited by the Act.

The Government has been concerned particularly at the adequacy of domestic liability levels which were last reviewed in 1976. The 1976 amendments reflected the levels that generally applied to international operations.

However, the liability limits provided by the Warsaw Convention and associated instruments are expressed in terms of gold francs, the value of which has fluctuated considerably in recent years with movements in the price of gold. To rectify this situation, an international conference in Montreal in 1975 sought to introduce new protocols which express the limits in IMF special drawing rights. However, these protocols have yet to come into force and the government is currently examining possible interim arrangements regarding limits on airline liability for international carriage until such time as the protocols take effect.

The Government is also concerned with the broader question of compulsory insurance for the domestic carriers liability to passengers. This matter is presently under consideration in joint Commonwealth/State government forums. The question of an even broader third party compulsory insurance scheme is also of concern and is however a much more complex issue for which consideration will be required by both the Commonwealth and the States.
I now turn to the specific provisions of the Bill.

Clause 2 of the Bill makes provision for the act to commence operation on a date to be proclaimed. In order that the operators may be given sufficient notice to effect any necessary insurance arrangements the proclamation date will be a short while after the Bill's passage through Parliament. Provision also exists to make a separate proclamation for Clause 3 to coincide with the commencment of new air service licensing arrangements.

Later this year, it is proposed to introduce regulations under the Air Navigation Act to provide for new air service licence categories. In particular, commuter and cargo operations will receive clear acknowledgement of their increasingly important role in the provision of aviation services by introducing new licence categories-the supplementary airline licence and licences for cargo only operators.

Clause 3 extends the definitions of airline licence and charter licence in section 26 of the principal Act so that carriage by operators under the proposed new air service licence classifications will continue to be covered by the provisions of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act.

Clause 4 of the Bill amends part four of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 to increase the level of liability for death or injury to passengers from $45,000 to $100,000. Similar increases apply for the liability limits for damage to baggage. For registered baggage the limit will be increased from $300 to $900. For baggage in the passengers' own care the increase will be from $30 to $90. Provision is also made for these limits to be amended by regulation in future. This will facilitate introduction of what are essentially machinery amendments and allow a more regular review of the liability limits that apply.
The Bill also makes provisions for the existing liability limits to continue to apply to all accidents that may have taken place before the date of commencement of the increased liability provisions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —The last time we were debating these Bills I made a range of points detailing the opposition of the Australian Democrats to the imposition of fees on second and higher degrees. I do not propose to repeat all of those tonight, although it seems that unfortunately time will again prevent us from going to a vote on this issue. I briefly recap: The major point I made last time was in relation to the Government's proposition that the funding of higher education may become more the responsibility of students and others in the community, than just that of the Government. I suggested that it was not possible for the Government to take such a stance unless it could table either in the Senate or in the House of Representatives some guarantee from others that they would be willing to pick up that cost which the Government planned to vacate. If this cannot be done I believe that, given our history of the support of tertiary education coming almost totally from government, any government in Australia would be in dereliction of its responsibilities not only to the present but also to the future of this country in jeopardising our tertiary education institutions and students. I have also said elsewhere that it is our belief that the Government is opting for future without shock. That is easily done by ignoring the future and by being shocked only by the present.

speech.para: Until today I thought I had a fairly detailed understanding of the problems of a range of institutions. However, upon representations from a chief administrator of an institution in Victoria I discovered that at that institution a person is teaching a course in metal work without having access to any of the machinery used in private industry. The machinery used in private industry is fully computerised and the machinery which people in that institution have to deal with is not computerised. We get to the point of believing that if we put money into a drag line in a mining enterprise, that is investment; if we build a railway line, that is investment; but if we educate the people to have the skills necessary to operate within those areas, it is a cost. That is absolutely absurd. Indeed we believe that funding for education should be seen totally within the framework of an investment in our own citizens and in their future and in the future of the country. Therefore let us cease talking, as we do so often, about the high cost of education.

The Government in not proposing to increase or decrease the actual amount of money spent on education but to impose a fee on students who have already been the products of an education system in this country which, at the primary, secondary and indeed tertiary level, has cost them a great deal of money. The funds provided by the Government to those institutions have also been fairly substantial. What we are seeking to do now is to introduce a disincentive for students who have got to the top of that education system to achieve second and higher degrees. That is to fly in the face of all predictions about what we need in this country. We need every bit of top skilled labour we can get. We need every one of our citizens who in any way shows any aptitude to take advantage of second and higher degrees. That is what we need in every case, and yet it is suggested that we should introduce a disincentive.

Indeed the Democrats go further and suggest that in a sense we should look in the opposite direction and should even look at paying people to do those second and higher degrees, because that is how desperately we need them, in the same way we pay for the introduction of certain goods in this country-for example motor cars and certain goods such as clothing and footwear-because the Government maintains the need to do so. In that way we also ought to pay people to produce certain types of skills. There is a direct analogy and yet the Government is again suggesting some rather penny pinching proposition.

talk.start.para: —It is a banana republic approach.

—It certainly is in terms of what we need in this country. I refer to a document entitled Challenge to Australia from which I shall quote. If the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) wishes it to be tabled I am happy to do so.
—Who wrote it?

—Part of the document was written by the Honourable Mr Justice Michael Kirby. It is entitled 'Towards the Third Millennium' and is a response to three other distinguished Australians who set out a challenge to Australia. In the paragraph entitled 'Higher Education' Mr Justice Kirby states:

speech.para: OECD figures show that Australia's levels of education are amongst the lowest in the Western world. Whereas at the age of 17 years more than 90 per cent of Japanese are still at school and more that 80 per cent of the United States, in Australia, we can barely muster 40 per cent.

It seems to me that rather than bring into the Senate Bills which seek to introduce disincentives, the Government ought to bring forward some far-reaching , innovative educational policies which suggest how we might come to grips with the obvious problems, some of which I detailed before. I refer again to the problem of increasing the involvement of lower income groups in our tertiary institutions; the problem of increasing the total amount of involvement-in other words, the type of proposition to which I referred in the quotation of Mr Justice Kirby; and the problem of attempting to look at the manpower requirements of this country well after the year 2000 and at what type of contribution our tertiary institutions will make to that, as well as what range of top class skills we will need at that time. We have problems in regard to a whole range of minority groups involved in tertiary education and even in regard to one of the majority groups, that of women.

Probably the most needed policy innovation that the Federal Government ought to be bringing forward concerns what particular skills we will need for the Government's projected new industries. I do not want to be so cynical as to suggest that the Government has not even thought about the projected new industries for this country. Let us take it that it has thought about the projected new industries for this country.

talk.start.para: —Even nuclear power?

—Yes, even including nuclear power. What policies does the Government have in terms of fostering those skills in order to have them in place in the time required? The reason I raise this question is that time and again major developments are touted around in this country but when they actually come on stream we have to go outside Australia to get the skills needed while our citizens remain unemployed. That happens time and again in this country. Our own citizens are in the dole queues while we scour the rest of the world for skills we need for these developments. These developments do not just happen; in some cases they have a 15-year time lag. But even if the time lag is as close as four years, we could still have these skills in place.
—Have you got an example?

—There is an example in my State of Queensland. I refer to the aluminium industry development outside Bundaberg. I was told that this would create a whole lot of employment in the area. However, I found out that this employment was to be in the unskilled labour force. When I asked where the skilled labour force would come from I was told that it would come from the same place as the rest of the skilled labour force comes from-overseas. Our failure to put into place policies that enable us to give the citizens of Australia the chance to operate their own industries at the top level is an indictment not only of this Government but also of previous governments. Because I am talking about second and higher degrees, I am talking about that level.

speech.para: Lastly, I refer to new industries. New industries do not come from the technical area, no matter how much needs to be done in that area. Certainly I do not decry what the Government has done in this field; indeed, I am on record as supporting wholeheartedly the Government's innovations in the field of technical education. But technical education will provide us with the top innovators for new industries. In the communications field and in the technology and biotechnology areas the innovators, the people at the forefront, are the highest educated people in the land. We are not talking about an attempt to establish an elitist situation. We are talking about the very guts of an economic policy. We have to get in place our people and our industries or else we will be looking down the barrel of a gun. That time will come when our current industries run out of steam. They are doing so. Everybody must admit-indeed, the Government admits it because it is constantly propping up our manufacturing industries-that our manufacturing industries are running into the end of their useful life in terms of the economy. We have to put in place new ones. They must be on the drawing boards and we must have people to do that.

The Australian Democrats see this Bill as an incredibly short-sighted Bill-an attempt to put into place a disincentive at the very time that we should be putting in place an incentive. We do not see it in terms of whether it is good for people's souls or in terms of any other types of proposition floating around , including the user-pay philosophy. It is consistent with the user-pay philosophy that the community ultimately uses people in higher education. The Minister for Education, who is at the table, must know from his own situation that the skills for which he worked hard and which were provided to him in part by the Government were used for the benefit of the community. Such people receive a reimbursement for their labours. As a free enterprise government I am quite sure that the Government does not wish that such people not receive a reimbursement commensurate with the level of effort and the level of their skills.

But, ultimately, it comes down to the fact that such people pay in their taxes for their education. They are the people who everybody in this country will have to rely on in future years for their incomes and for their pensions. Those people will provide the backbone for Australia well into the year 2000. Let us support them now and do away with this penny pinching and what Senator Chipp would call balance sheet mentality and look at the educational, social and economic consequence of such a move.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —The Senate has before it three Bills which seek to introduce for a minority of tertiary students fees payable by them for a proportion of the cost of their education. The pessimistic outlook that has been described by the Australian Democrats spokesman, Senator Macklin, is not one that I share. I believe that the perspective out of which these Bills arose in the review of Commonwealth functions, a task carried out by senior Ministers of this Government in every area of government activity, has a quite different explanation. The first question that arises concerns access. It was almost entirely on this matter that these Bills were opposed by the Opposition. The question of access was debated fully last October when these Bills were first introduced and were passed by the House of Representatives but failed narrowly here in the Senate. The debate this month has added very little to the question of access.

speech.para: Essentially the question is in two parts. Are low income students denied access by this partial reintroduction of fees? I believe that the answer is no. For a start, the fees will apply to only a small proportion of tertiary students, the proportion who have already gained a degree and who are going on to some kind of postgraduate study. Of those postgraduate students, the fees will apply only to a proportion-those in I would call the fourth category. The first category comprises those who have shown most talent in their earlier studies and are successful in gaining Commonwealth postgraduate awards, the second category comprises those students successful in gaining university research grants, and the third category comprises those who are successful in gaining research grants from industry and other private benefaction. It is only the fourth category- those who have missed out already on the grounds of academic merit in the three earlier categories, including some persons close to being perpetual postgraduate students-who will be required to pay a fee, which will be less than one-fifth of the recurrent cost of the fees. I believe that it is not a matter of denying students access to study.
Debate interrupted.

debate.sub1.title: Passports-Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia

proctext.para: Passports-Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia

interject.speaker: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

interject.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I ventilate what I regard as the inadequate operations of the officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs in Canberra who are responsible for making decisions relating to permanent residents who need to have recourse to a certificate of identity in lieu of an Australian passport. The story which I am about to relate commenced on Monday of this week when a Mrs Virginia Evanian came to my office with her 16-year-old daughter. Mrs Evanian has Australian citizenship and, of course, an Australian passport. She has two young children who were born in Australia and who are going with her to the United States of America for one month. The father is not going. He is a permanent resident. The daughter of 16 years was in the difficult position of having come to Australia from the Middle Eastern country of Iraq when she was one year old. I took the view that this 16-year old girl obviously had to have some travel documentation. I certainly was not unmindful of the fact that there might be difficulties in this regard because she was a former Iraqi national. Although there are no difficulties in the 16-year-old girl obtaining a re-entry visa from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Iraqi Government took the point of view that as the girl had left the country 15 years previously and on every indication she would ultimately become an Australian citizen, it was not interested in the matter. That is the decision of that Government and I do not cavil at it.

speech.para: I immediately conferred with the passport office of the Department in the Commonwealth Government Centre in Chifley Square, Sydney. I wish to place on record that I found the staff of that section, from the most senior officer to the most junior, to be extremely competent. Obviously this was a situation where a decision had to be made in Canberra. The whole thrust of my argument relates to the ineptitude of the people with whom I had to deal. I say at the outset that the staff dealing with passports in Sydney and Melbourne have a constant daily clamour from people for Australian passports. These people work under extreme pressures. I admire their self-control. They are always courteous to me and I always receive prompt attention. When senior officers in Sydney said that this was a decision to be made in Canberra, I agreed. I knew without being told by certain people in Canberra that when a person seeks asylum in Australia and he or she might have to go overseas for some reason we issue that person with some documentation.

What completely appalled me when I spoke to people whom I regard as being in the middle echelon of the section of the Department dealing with passport control in Canberra was that I got what I considered could at the least be called studied indifference. They gave me a long story about how this girl had lived in Australia for 15 years and, therefore, technically she was not somebody who was seeking political asylum. I knew that. At the end of a five minute fruitless telephone conversation, which was not helped when the person to whom I was talking appeared to be talking to someone else in the room and saying, 'Tell him this', or 'Tell him that', all I got was a lot of negatives. I am a member of Estimates Committee D. I think I and my colleagues on that Committee have a fair idea of how passport control operates. The thing which I resented-I said so very forcibly at the end of my telephone conversation-was that I did not want arguments as to why I could not get this visa. I wanted reasons why I should be able to get it.

The former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Macphee, made a statement last week in the House of Representatives. We now have six months within which to digest the information contained in that statement and we can assess the changes that have been made to the obtaining of Australian citizenship. In passing the Minister made reference to the numbers of people who have not exercised their rights to obtain Australian citizenship. We could have arguments to the effect that it was not the time to do it or that those people who have waited year after year and have never obtained citizenship panic and want citizenship as a prelude to the possession of an Australian passport.The girl is 16. In fact, she is still a high school student. I suppose when she is 18 she will make up her own mind what she will do. I resent the inability of the people in Canberra to give me a clearcut decision and say: 'We will issue the document.' If the girl wanted to go to the Middle East with the present turbulent conditions between Iran and Iraq, she could unwittingly be a pawn in a dispute. But she only wanted to go to the United States of America for a month.

I understand from Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle that the passport people in Sydney have said that no application has been made on behalf of the girl, Rita Evanian. There has not been any application because her family came to me for guidance. They realised she could not get an Australian passport. My criticism-I maintain the rage tonight-is that the people I spoke to in Canberra were completely indifferent to offering a solution. In fortification of my argument I have a telegram which I showed to Senator Baume before he left the chamber. It has been sent by the extremely competent State secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, Merv Malcolm. The union, of which the girl' s father is a member, demands immediate action. I do so because these people want to leave Australia and go to the United States within a week. I seek leave to have the telegram incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

We would appreciate any assistance you can give in obtaining a certificate of identity for the daughter of our member Mr E. Evanian stop she required the certificate to enable her to visit USA on a short holiday with her mother
M J Malcolm Secretary NSW State Council AMWSU

talk.start.para: —In making this plea tonight I expect, within the next 24 hours, somebody at the central office of the Department of Foreign Affairs to authorise the passport office in Sydney to issue Rita Evanian with a certificate of identity or some other form of documentation. It seems to me that the Department of Foreign Affairs is unaware of the facts which were given to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. While I ventilate this case here tonight-I am sure that ministerial intervention tomorrow will settle it satisfactorily-there must be hosts of similar cases. Whilst I would be the last to deny somebody with genuine credentials political asylum, if we have the facilities to issue certificates to such people we should be able to do so promptly in the case of a family whose members have been law abiding taxpayers for the whole 17 years that they have been in Australia. I raise this matter with some regret because I know you, Mr Deputy President, as a Minister in the Government in the years 1972 to 1975 will be aware that a man that you and I admired and a very effective Minister for Immigration, the Honourable Clyde Cameron and I, in my humble position as Chairman of the Immigration Advisory Council, resisted offers from the Department of Foreign Affairs to take over passport control. We lost the battle. The former member for Hindmarsh, if he is listening tonight, will know that his own sagacity was vindicated. The Department of Foreign Affairs should not have control of this matter; it should be given back to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I leave the matter on that note, confident that in 24 hours a signal will go to Sydney and justice will be given to these people.

speech.speaker: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

talk.start.para: —I find myself in a very difficult position tonight, one that I have never been in before. I want to talk about what I believe to be a scandal within the Victorian branch of a Federal union. I have papers available to me which name names and which, I believe, verify the misappropriation of almost $10,000 from the union. I am well aware that proceedings in the Senate are privileged. I find it very difficult to know how I can make clear to the Senate the information which has been passed to me without naming names, although that is what I intend to try to do. I might add that it will become clear that members of the union concerned will be able to work out, and I suppose any journalist or any other people who wish to apply their minds to the matter would probably be able to work out, in due course, who the people are. But at least, by endeavouring to avoid naming names, those names will not be emblazoned across the daily media.

speech.para: The Victorian branch of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia-the union which is commonly known as the liquor trades union- is another State branch of a Federal union in which the apathy of the rank and file unionist has allowed the socialist left and the communists to take control, to the detriment of the rank and file members. At least 10 of the 15 members of the committee of management of the Victorian branch are Communist Party or Socialist Left union officials, who appear to me to have conspired to cover up a scandal by one of their faction. But it is now too late, because the dogs are barking it around the John Curtin Hotel in Melbourne. As I have said, the scandal is the misappropriation of almost $10,000 from the Victorian branch of that union by a union staff member, and it is also the failure of the committee of management or any of its officers to refer the matter to the police, their failure to take adequate action to recover union funds, and their failure to take steps to ensure that the official concerned cannot get reappointed to a similar position-which in fact is what has now happened; in other words, he has been reappointed to a similar position in another union.

I turn to verification of the misappropriation. The story concerns a person whom I will have to call Mr X, who seems to have a way with union officials as well as a way with union funds. He was involved in an earlier problem, back in 1976. An extract of what I believe to be the minutes, from which I will quote, discloses that some time prior to February 1980, Mr X apparently misappropriated from the Victorian branch of the liquor trades union some thousands of dollars of union funds. It would appear that when this was discovered arrangements were made for him to resign, and clearly it was intended that the knowledge of the theft of these funds would be kept within the union management. His letter of resignation came before the committee of management at its meeting on 13 February 1980. I quote from extracts of the minutes of that meeting. I trust that senators will realise that I am trying to read these extracts without referring to names, so that may account for some of the problems.

The letter of resignation was read, and then a person whom I believe is the State Secretary of the union spoke on reasons for the letter of resignation. Another person spoke on the resignee's service to the union and expressed the hope that the matter would be handled within the union, which is, as I say, what I believe, that clearly the knowledge of this theft was going to be kept within union management. In due course it was resolved that the resignation be accepted . There was then resolved that the trustees, the Treasurer and the Secretary meet with this gentleman 'in order to obtain a suitable solution to the problem' . I might add that I am informed that the trustees, the Treasurer and the Secretary were all of the same faction as the gentleman concerned, and in fact the Secretary had appointed this gentleman to his position. It will be noticed that there is no police action. There is no suggestion of referring the matter to the police. The Treasurer was present. There is no statement by the Treasurer of what the amount of the misappropriation was. In fact, there is nothing within the minutes which really explains what it is all about other than that the matter was explained to the committee of management. It is quite clear, reading from those minutes, that at that stage it was intended to keep the matter totally enclosed within the committee of management and not to allow this information to become public in any way. What is important from those minutes is that a minority faction--

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask that the honourable senator table the documents from which he is reading .

—Yes, I will certainly do that. I make it clear that it is Senator Button who has required me to table these documents. The documents contain names . The tabling of the documents will make those names available to those who wish to have a look at the documents.

speech.para: I now turn to what I believe to be an extract from the minutes of the committee of management for 6 May, nearly three months later. It is clear that by then some members of the committee of management had become concerned and a motion was carried stating:
That under rule 4A of the Federal and Branch Rules, ex organiser . . .--
The man has now resigned-

-be shown to have been disqualified from office and is also disqualified from holding future office in the Federation and this to be recorded in the minutes. Further, that the Secretary be instructed to take all actions necessary to recover all monies misappropriated and/or any other action deemed necessary to be undertaken.

I note that, in fact, the Treasurer whom I mentioned before spoke against the motion. I mention that because since then the Treasurer who took no action and who, in fact, spoke against the motion has now been appointed a trustee of this union. The motion was carried.

talk.start.para: —Is this the resolution which says that he can't be a member of the union any more?

—That is right. The next item on the agenda raised the matter of an unpaid account to the United Distillers Pty Ltd on behalf of the ex-member of the union. Apparently, he had got into the United Distillers for a sum of money. There was an interesting resolution:

speech.para: That the account from United Distillers on behalf of . . .
The ex-member--
be paid immediately--
In other words, union funds will be used now to pay his account-
and be added on to monies already owed.

In effect, what the union was deciding to do was to pay another of this bloke's bills and then say: 'Well, he already owes us so many thousands of dollars, what does it matter if we add a few hundred more?' I have no idea of what size the account was. Three months after the first time the matter was raised there had been no police action and no suggestion of the matter being referred to any authority. I have an extract of rule 4A-Disqualification for Office. It states:
No-one shall be eligible to nominate for or hold a Federal or State office:
who has admitted to, or has been found guilty in any court of law, of larceny, embezzlement or any other form of dishonesty in relation to the property or funds of this Union.

I think it is a great pity that further action was not taken. It may very well have been that the current circumstances in relation to the employment of this person might have been avoided. That, of course, is another matter of great concern. The next day after that meeting of the committee of management there was a general meeting of the members of the Victorian branch of the union. I will again read from the minutes and delete the names. The minutes state:
Questions were asked about the misappropriation of money by . . .
Secretary reported that this figure was in deficit in the region of $9,565.00 and . . . was entitled to accruments of $7,000, unless otherwise decided as per Branch rule 41 (e) and 41A (f).

There is no explanation of how $7,000 was arrived at, but I presume it had something to do with long service leave or holiday entitlements. Clearly the implication is that there would be some sort of an offset unless the matter was otherwise decided. But it is also interesting to note that at that general meeting a financial report was presented. The financial report stated that:
The Balance Sheet for the 3 months ending February 29th, 1980 showed a deficit of $12,104.00.

In other words although the deficit by Mr X was alleged to be about $9,565 for some reason the balance sheet deficit was $12,104. After that, and notwithstanding the resolution that action be taken to endeavour to get back the union official's funds, there seems to be a deathly silence-until 2 September 1981-which is nearly 18 months later. Again I quote, with some variation, from an extract of the minutes of the Committee of Management on that day in which a question was asked:
if . . . is paying back the monies owed to the Union. The Secretary replied that he would be having discussions to ensure that this occurred.

Again there was no police action to bar Mr X. My information is that this gentleman has now become an officer of the Victorian branch of another union which is controlled by the left wing. I understand that he is now a delegate of that union to the Trades Hall Council. I would have thought that these matters would have been of great concern to Senator Button and any other Victorian senators, Liberal, Labor or Democrat. I have mentioned the factions that are involved. What has clearly happened is that this faction has endeavoured to cover up what is a major theft and hide if from the rank and file members of the branch of that union.

My purpose in exposing this matter this evening is quite frankly the hope that rank and file members of this union will begin to realise that apathy creates problems, and the committee of management of this union has problems. I hope that it sees its way clear to take action. I realise it is difficult to get to meetings at night when one would rather watch Don Lane or someone else but it is important for members of union movements to take an active interest in their union. I believe that the evidence which I have-I will table papers in the Senate tonight-fully justifies my raising the matter in the Senate. But I also say this: I intend to hand copies of what I believe to be copies of minutes of these meetings to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). I believe they are genuine. I welcome any investigation by the Australian Federal Police or, if the Attorney-General thinks it is a State matter, the State police or the Industrial Relations Bureau.

talk.start.para: —Order! No order has been made for the tabling of the documents quoted from by Senator Lewis. Senator Lewis, do you seek leave to table them?
—No, I do not.

speech.para: Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That the documents quoted from by Senator Lewis be tabled.

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: —I moved that the documents be tabled because I do not think we should have spooky stuff such as ' Mr X' being used instead of a person's name and that sort of business when Senator Lewis is making very serious allegations about the Victorian section of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia. I want to make only one or two comments. The first comment is that if criminal offences or other offences against the membership of a trade union have been committed and it is established that that is so, the Australian Labor Party does not condone or approve of it in any way and condemns it in much the same way as Senator Lewis has sought to condemn it, but not, I hope, by innuendo. I am surprised in a sense at Senator Lewis's selective indignation about this matter because--
—But there were other names in the minutes, not just Mr X.

—I understand that. I am not talking about Senator Lewis's selective indignation about people. I am talking about his selective indignation about the issue. What has happened, clearly, is that a constituent who is aggrieved by what has happened in the liquor trades has given these documents to Senator Lewis and he has come into this chamber and used this forum as the appropriate one to solve a problem in a trade union. I am saying to Senator Lewis that I have sat here since he has been a senator-I do not know how long it is; three or four years-and heard him in full flight in support of Government legislation in relation to trade unions which Senator Lewis told us at the time would deal with all these problems.
—Don't misquote me.
—Oh yes, he did. I am not misquoting Senator Lewis.
—Don't confuse me with what the Minister has been saying.

—Senator Lewis cannot back out now. He has been putting up his hand for years as if he has suffered from sheep bleats or something like that. He knows perfectly well that he was leading the rah-rah boys when industrial relations legislation was brought into this chamber to solve all these problems and to give trade union members access to industrial tribunals to deal with the problems of their unions. What I am concerned about is that Senator Lewis has come in here as a bumpkin lawyer from Warr- nambool with all the vast experience he has had in defending drunks at the Warrnambool police courts and has used this--
—Why are you so touchy?
— I am not touchy at all.
—It certainly comes across that way.

—If Senator Walters can wait a minute she will hear what comes across because it will come across the chamber from me, not from her. What I am concerned about is that this matter has been raised in this way instead of following the procedures which this Government has established for solving these problems and which are the proper procedures for a member of a union to follow if that member is aggrieved by a situation of this kind, and that is--
—They are too frightened of retaliation.

—Senator Walters does not know what she is talking about. The justification for the action taken by Senator Lewis is that his heart is bleeding about the consequences of apathy in trade unionists. The fact of the matter is that someone went to him with a group of documents. Senator Lewis got very excited about them and rushed in here with them. In order to protect his little story from the Press he has called somebody Mr X instead of indicating who he really is. That is what Senator Lewis has done. The appropriate course for members of unions to follow in relation to this sort of thing quite clearly is to take the matter, if it is a police matter, to the police. If it is not a police matter or if a union member wants something investigated the matter should be taken to the Industrial Registrar. That is why those facilities are available. All I am saying is that if this establishes a precedent whereby, although tribunals are already provided for this purpose, the Senate-based, as the honourable senator said, on parliamentary privilege-is to become the tribunal for making these sorts of allegations, where will it all end?

speech.para: I think that is the undesirable character of what Senator Lewis has said. We will look at the documents. I hope that Senator Lewis's constituent who took them to him will be guided by Senator Lewis to take his documents off to the proper place and have the matter determined by an appropriate tribunal-not the Senate-on the merits, because that is what ought to be done. I regret that Senator Lewis has seen fit to do this in this way. I am in no position to make any judgments about the facts which he alleges. Nor is anyone else in this chamber in the position to make any judgments other than the subjective decision -which Senator Walters, I have no doubt, will have made already-to hang Mr X or whoever is involved. There is no capacity in this chamber to make judgments about these issues.

talk.start.para: —The minutes record the misappropriation.
—I ask Senator Lewis whether he is saying that the Senate should make some sort of judgment on the basis of what he has said here.
—Yes.

The conditions under which such a certificate may be issued are clearly defined by passport regulation 9, which the Minister has no discretion to override. Regulation 9 (1) provides:

speech.para: An authorised officer may issue a Certificate of Identity to an alien who is about to leave the Commonwealth and who is stateless or unable to obtain a passport from a consular representative of the country of which he claims to be a national.

If, as Senator Mulvihill suggests, Miss Evanian-despite her 15 years residence in Australia-has chosen to retain her Iraqi nationality, she is not stateless. Therefore, unless she can demonstrate that she is unable to obtain a passport from a consular representative of her country in Australia--

talk.start.para: —They have refused that in Canberra. They have told her they are not interested in it. That is what I put to your people in Canberra. They were too stupid to understand it.

—In that case I will further raise that matter with the Department. Senator Mulvihill will understand that unless that is so Miss Evanian would not qualify for a certificate. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

question.para: (1) Can the Prime Minister inform the Parliament of the total cost of security arrangements for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM).
(2) What was the cost of flying the Queen of Australia from London to Melbourne in the RAAF VIP 707 jet.
(3) How many cars from the Commonwealth car pool were taken from (a) Sydney to Melbourne, and (b) Canberra to Melbourne.
(4) What was the cost to the taxpayer of hiring the Lakeside Hotel in Canberra for Commonwealth visitors and their staff, and what was the total cost of security at the Lakeside.
(5) Was compensation paid to the hotel for unoccupied rooms and cancelled functions.
(6) What was the total cost to the taxpayer of entertainment for all visitors to the CHOGM conferences (a) at Melbourne, and (b) at Canberra.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The total cost of CHOGM security was of the order of $9,750,000. Some accounts have yet to be finalised, and therefore some adjustment of this figure can be expected.

The total includes costs incurred by the Victoria Police and the Australian Federal Police on their arrangements and by the CHOGM Task Force in providing equipment and facilities for the Police. It also includes the cost of the Defence contribution to security.

A very large number of police were engaged on CHOGM duties-in the case of the Victoria Police for example, I understand that about 3,500 police (or 44 per cent of the Force) were involved. The Police effort involved a major planning and management input and a huge commitment in such areas such as traffic control , venue security (hotels as well as the Meeting and other venues), personal escort and motorcade escort duties for the 41 delegations to name only some. Major cost areas included police overtime and allowances, accommodation, the provision of special facilities and equipment by the Commonwealth, and transport and communications costs.

(2) Not all costs are known, but the estimated cost of flying the Queen in the RAAF 707 aircraft from London to Melbourne, including the cost of positioning the aircraft in London, was about $347,000.

(4) and (5) $156,000 approximately. This included the cost of taking over the residential floors progressively before the Retreat commenced and compensation for the loss of revenue from the bars, restaurants and function areas resulting from the total closure of the Hotel to the public. The cost of security at the Lakeside has not been identified separately from other security costs.
(6) The cost of official entertainment for CHOGM delegates was of the order of:
(a) $164,000 in Melbourne; and
(b) $21,000 in Canberra.

Overall, the expenditure on CHOGM was considerable. This was always to be expected. But the benefits also are considerable. The Prime Minister of India ( who has offered her country as host for the next meeting) has indicated that expenditure of the order involved is small compared with expenditure for destructive purposes and worthwhile in the pursuit of more constructive objectives. That is in the wider context. In more immediate terms, Australia gained directly from the good will and understanding which a significant portion of the world's national leaders and media representatives were able to gain only by their presence here, and from the way we treated them and how they observed us.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

answer.to.qon.title: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination

question.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

question.para: (1) On what date did the Australian Government last give consideration to making a declaration recognising the competence of the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination under Article 14 of the 1965 International Convention on the Elimination af All Forms of Racial Discrimination, which entered into force on 4 January 1969.
(2) On what date did the Australian Government last give consideration to withdrawing the Australian reservation with respect to Article 4 (a) of the convention.
(3) How many nations have ratified the convention and which of them made reservations with respect to Article 4 (a).

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government is currently not in favour of making a declaration under Article 14 of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. The Government considers that Section 6 of the Commonwealth Racial Discrimination Act 1975, which binds the Crown in right of both the Commonwealth and each of the States, provides adequate redress for complaints involving racial discrimination through its investigative, settlement and other procedures. Against this background, and taking account of the optional nature of Article 14 declarations, the Government does not intend at present to make such a declaration but is keeping the matter under consideration.
(2) The Government is also keeping the question of Australia's reservation in respect of Article 4 (a) of the Convention under review.

The Government's current view is that conciliation and mediation augmented by civil remedies, rather than the use of criminal sanctions, are the best means of dealing with racial discrimination and its associated tensions and prejudices. The Racial Discrimination Act does proscribe acts of incitement and assisting or promoting racial discrimination whether by financial assistance or otherwise, as well as providing a comprehensive range of civil remedies. This specific legislation reflects the Government's firm commitment to eliminate racial discrimination. Many acts involving violence or incitement to violence are also punishable under existing criminal law. Legislation strictly of the kind referred to in Article 4 (a) has thus not yet been passed and is not in immediate prospect. The Government therefore considers that the reservation lodged in relation to Article 4 (a) should be retained.
(3) One hundred and ten states have ratified, acceded to or deposited notifications of accession to the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.
The following states have made reservations or declarations in relation to Article 4 (a):
Australia; Austria; Bahamas; Barbados; Belgium; Fiji; France; Italy; Malta; Nepal; Tonga; United Kingdom.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 25 February 1982:

question.para: Did the Minister for Housing and Construction, in reply to Question No. 1646 ( see Senate Hansard page 322) concerning information on the percentage of domestic dwellings owned outright, state that ' . . . because the questions asked in each survey and the census were slightly different the data available are not strictly comparable'; if so, what are the reasons for the difference between questions, and; (b) in what specific way the data is not strictly comparable.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) Yes. The questions asked about housing tenure in the surveys and the 1976 Census were slightly different because of the different methods of collecting data.

Information from the 1980 Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Survey of Housing Occupancy and Costs was obtained by trained interviewers, who asked households specific questions about their accommodation. The interviewers were able to provide clarification of questions where required. Information about housing tenure from the 1974-75 ABS Household Expenditure Survey was obtained by similar means.

Census forms are delivered and collected by trained ABS officers, but these officers are not generally present when the household fills in the questionnaire . The questions in the Census are thus designed to be simpler and more straightforward to avoid misinterpretation.
(b) Data collected in ABS surveys is not strictly comparable with that collected in the 1976 Census because:

(i) in the 1976 Census, 2.5 per cent of all households provided answers to housing tenure questions which were incomplete or inconsistent. These answers were recorded in the 'not stated' tenure category.
In ABS surveys, the interview method is more able to ensure that an appropriate response to the tenure question is obtained from all households.

(ii) The 1974-75 Household Expenditure Survey did not include areas outside the six State capital cities and Canberra and may therefore have produced a different overall picture of housing tenure from that which would have been obtained from a survey with full geographic coverage. The 1980 ABS Survey of Housing Occupancy and Costs and the 1976 Census both covered the whole of Australia.

(iii) A population census requires information to be collected from all households but the results of the 1976 Census were derived from processing a fifty per cent sample of households from all parts of Australia except the Northern Territory, where responses were completely processed. The 1980 ABS Survey of Housing Occupancy and Costs information is based on data collected from a sample of two-thirds of one percent of the population. The 1974-75 Household Expenditure Survey was based on a sample of approximately 9,000 households in the six State capital cities and Canberra. Thus sample variability is a factor affecting all three sources to some degree.
(iv) In the 1976 Census some households who failed to answer the question on mortgage payments were recorded as outright owners rather than purchasers of their dwellings.

In the ABS Survey of Housing Occupancy and Costs and the Household Expenditure Survey the interviewer asked follow-up questions on mortgage payments to those households who identified themselves as home buyers, and errors due to omission of mortgage payment information would have been less likely.

question.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

question.para: (1) What is the possibility of Australia participating with Japan on the development of fifth generation computers.
(2) What steps will the Government take to:
(a) remedy the lack of research carried out in this field; and
(b) encourage Australian participation with Japan in fifth generation computer development.
(3) Why has the Australian Government done so little to facilitate Australian participation in this field?

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am advised that Japan expects a ten-year research and development effort to be required for the fifth generation computer system. In recognition of the complexity of the pro- ject an International Conference on Fifth Generation Computer Systems was held in Tokyo in October 1981 to discuss the present state and future problems in computer development. Contrary to some published reports, advice received from the Australian Counsellor (Scientific) in Tokyo after discussions with the appropriate Japanese authority, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI), indicates that no plans have yet been made for international participation in research and development. It is therefore not possible to determine if Australian participation is possible.

(2a) Government assistance to computer research is directed mainly through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Industrial Research and Development Incentives scheme. The IR&D Incentives scheme has recently been reviewed by the IAC in its inquiry on Certain Budgetary Assistance . The IAC's report is currently under consideration.

A number of important and complex issues would have to be addressed before a policy of assistance directed specifically at the computer manufacturing industry could be considered. A full and public examination of the issues would be desirable. The Government has indicated its intention to send a reference in 1982 to the IAC on the question of assistance for the Australian computer industry. Computer software, an important element in developing fifth generation computers, may be included in the scope of the inquiry.

The issue of government assistance to computer research may alternatively be viewed in the context of support for a technology, rather than an industry. There is a trend in other countries towards greater selectivity in the support of those technologies which are fundamental to a wide range of industries. The Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia has already identified technologies which it expected to be important in this sense for Australia. The key role of computers in business and manufacturing activities is widely recognised as an important factor in international competitiveness.

(2b) There are a number of generally available mechanisms by which Australian participation could be encouraged if Japan were to seek international involvement in research and development in relation to fifth generation computers:

(i) Australia's Agreement with Japan on co-operation in Research and Development in Science and Technology provides a mechanism for co-operative activities such as the exchange of personnel in mutually agreed fields of scientific and technological research and development. Research and development in relation to fifth generation computers could form such a field. Co-operation under the Agreement is funded by the Government, and is co-ordinated in Australia by the Department of Science and Technology.

(ii) The Government's offsets policy requires successful overseas tenderers for Government contracts valued at $1 million or more to give a commitment to seek to place orders with Australian industry to a minimum level of 30 per cent of the value of the imported content of the contract. The program seeks to obtain high technology offsets wherever possible. For example, under this program, CSIRO has had for some years a research and development agreement with the Japanese computer manufacturer, Fujitsu.

talk.start.para: —On 24 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2439) Senator Chipp asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question without notice concerning banking profits.

The trading banks observe the same maximum as savings banks for their equivalent housing loans.

Housing loans of under $100,000 remain subject to control, with the maximum interest rate currently being 13.5 per cent. Higher rates may, of course, apply to other forms of financing not subject to control, such as short term bridging financing.

talk.start.para: —On 18 March 1982 (Hansard, page 924) Senator Button asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

answer.to.qwn.title: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Staff Ceilings

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —On 24 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1091), Senator Townley asked me a question without notice on the effects of staff ceilings on research undertaken by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

answer.para: The Minister for Science and Technology has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Over the last six years, the level of CSIRO's staff ceiling has risen by 441 positions (7.6 per cent) even though 344 positions (5.9 per cent) have been surrendered over that time. This apparently anomalous position is brought about by the fact that CSIRO has been subjected to the Government's across-the-board staff cuts, while, at the same time, it has been asked to undertake additional activities and accept responsibility for establishments previously accounted for under the ceilings of other government bodies. The major increases to CSIRO 's staff ceiling were provided to cover the transfer to CSIRO of the Materials Research Laboratory of the Department of Defence, and the non-nuclear activities of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission; for the transfer of 380 staff previously funded from the Wool Research Trust Fund; for additional responsibilities such as the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory and research in the extended Australian Fishing Zone; and for the Government's apprenticeship scheme and projects funded by the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Program.

Notwithstanding the overall ceiling rise, the need to surrender positions prompted the Executive of CSIRO to adopt a more determined policy of selectivity and concentration of research effort. Under this policy the number of research programs is being reduced and, in particular, no program of research is being continued where the level of resource allocation is so low as to make prospects for success unlikely. Apart from the initial review undertaken to initiate this policy, and the continuing review of their research programs by Chiefs of CSIRO Divisions, the Executive of CSIRO also commissions periodic Divisional and Subject Reviews with the aim of directing resources to produce more concentrated and effective research.

The policy of reduction and termination of programs in areas of lesser priority has been pursued to a greater extent than that required to meet the Organisation's commitment to surrender positions. This has been done to release resources, in terms of both staff and funds, for redeployment into other programs, especially those in research areas which have been identified by CSIRO as having high priority for expansion. These areas are energy, oceanography, biotechnology, soils/ water, plant pathology, and manufacturing industry. Some 140 positions have been redeployed in this manner over the last two years.

This policy of selectivity of research effort will enable CSIRO to maintain scientific excellence while concentrating on nationally important and scientifically rewarding areas of research. I can assure the honourable senator that the quality of CSIRO's research will not be allowed to deteriorate.

talk.start.para: —On 24 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1096), Senator Harradine asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

answer.para: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and deals with a so-called attempt by the Government to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act relating to compulsory unionism. Is the Minister not aware that it is impossible for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to award compulsory unionism under the current provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act? Is the Minister aware that the Commission can award preference only, and then only after a full hearing, after all reasonable steps have been taken by the employee organisation to recruit, where there is evidence of employer resistance or where it is in the best interests of industrial relations for the Commission so to award? Is the Minister further aware that the human rights of individual employees are fully protected by the operation of the conscientious provisions enshrined in that legislation? If the Minister is aware of all those aspects will he not agree with me that the Government's attempt to portray this piece of legislation as an attack on compulsory unionism is a con trick on the Australian public and that it will in fact open the way to those unions which now have preference in their awards to do what the Government ought to oppose, that is, resort to forcing persons to become members on the job, which is the current policy with some more militant unions?
The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government believes that it is a basic principle of human rights that individuals should be able to choose freely whether they wish to belong to a trade union. This has long been clear Government policy. The Government considers that the time has now come to provide for that right without qualification in the federal jurisdiction. For that purpose, amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 have been proposed to remove from the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission jurisdiction over the giving of preference in or in relation to employment to members of registered trade unions.

In introducing these amendments, the Government is well aware of the circumstances in which and the means whereby the Commission has exercised its jurisdiction in this area in the past and it is not suggested that the Commission has acted improperly in any way. The fundamental question is whether freedom of individual choice should continue to be so limited. The Government's view is that it should not.

It should be stressed that in taking this approach, the Government appreciates the danger that some unions and employers might be more disposed to employ various forms of discrimination to coerce individuals to become union members. To prevent this, provision will be made for a right to compensation for the person discriminated against from the offending union or employer.

talk.start.para: —On 28 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1572) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

answer.para: Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen Press reports that tonnes of food supplied by foreign countries for refugees in Somalia are being sold openly in Mogadishu while people in refugee camps are complaining of starvation and that food aid from the European Economic Community to Ethiopia is also being sold? Does the Australian Government supply food aid to Somalia and Ethiopia? If so, can the Minister assure the Parliament that this aid is reaching the refugees rather than being sold or being used to feed Ethiopian and foreign troops fighting against the Eritreans?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware that Press reports have been made along the lines referred to by the honourable senator. The Australian Government does supply food aid to Ethiopia and Somalia. However, care is taken to ensure that it reaches those most in need of it and that it is not diverted to other uses.

At the International Conference on Assistance to Refugees in Africa (ICARA) held in Geneva in April 1981, the Government pledged an additional $8m to be provided as food aid in 1981-82 to refugees in Africa. Our shipment of food aid to Ethiopia comprises 24,500 tonnes of wheat for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and an additional 900 tonnes to be distributed by World Vision. This aid is valued, including freight and other costs, at about $4.7m. In Ethiopia the food aid will be consigned to UNHCR who will ensure that it reaches intended beneficiaries.

'UNHCR has agreed to support, with food aid, settlement projects and transit camps organised by the Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission. The projects will help returnees, displaced persons and locals in need. Some of the wheat will be exchanged for maize, the preferred staple in the rural areas. A small amount will be sold to meet internal distribution costs which are very high.

The food aid for Somalia includes 10,400 tonnes of flour and 2,000 tonnes of rice valued, including freight, at about $4 million. Of this 4,000 tonnes of flour will shortly arrive in Mogadishu, with the balance of flour and the rice to be shipped in May. The food aid will be for the direct use of refugees.

All of the food aid being provided as part of our ICARA pledge is in fact being handled by UNHCR on our behalf. The World Food Program is also involved in monitoring and supervision and both organisations will report on its use.'

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —On 28 April 1982, Senator Lewis (Hansard, page 1575) asked me a question without notice about safety and security arrangements for protecting the Bass Strait petroleum production platforms. I should like to amplify my reply as it concerned the restrictions applying to vessels in the area.

answer.para: The internationally accepted 'safety zones' of 500 metres around each platform prohibit all vessels from unauthorised entry. These zones are declared under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act.

The Restricted Area declared by the Department of Transport applies to all vessels over 200 tons. The boundary of the Restricted Area extends from the shoreline to approximately 50 nautical miles from the coast to surround the platforms and the offshore pipelines. The boundary lies approximately five nautical miles beyond the platforms. The Restricted Area is expected to be replaced at the end of 1982 by the 'Area to be Avoided' measure recently approved by the Inter-governmental Maritime Consultative Organisation (IMCO). This area has the same dimensions as the existing Restricted Area. Amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act will be introduced to make the Area to be Avoided a prohibited area with respect to all Australian vessels over 200 tons. The IMCO recommendations for the Bass Strait area will be mandatory for international vessels registered in countries which implement specific legislation regarding the Bass Strait area. The recommendations will remain advisory for vessels registered in other countries. However, because of IMCO's standing, a high degree of compliance is expected.
The Government presently has under consideration the question of restricting the entry of vessels under 200 tons to a zone around the platforms which is greater than the 500 metre safety zone.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1770) Senator Hill asked me a question without notice concerning progress on the new River Murray Waters Agreement, and I now provide the following additional information to the reply I gave to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The final draft of a new Agreement is now being edited by officers of the four governments concerned, including appropriate provisions drawn up by the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor on new water distribution clauses, which had not been fully worked out by an advisory committee of the River Murray Commission when the Prime Minister and Premiers endorsed a draft of a new Agreement in Melbourne in October 1981. I am not in a position at this stage to foreshadow when the matching legislation will be introduced into the four parliaments.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —On 9 March 1982 (Hansard, page 576) Senator Ryan asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the following question without notice:

answer.para: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the 12-point program for the advancement of women announced yesterday by the Government of France to mark International Women's Day? Will the Governmnt undertake to examine the French initiatives, which are reported to include increased family allowances and pensions for women, laws to promote equality and to prohibit sex discrimination, reform of the laws on alimony and common property and reform of discriminatory tax laws? Is the Government prepared to make a commitment to Australian women similar to the commitment made to French women by the government of France?
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of Press reports of an announcement made by the Government of France to mark International Women's Day. The Australian Government is committed to freedom from discrimination, equality of opportunity and equal status for women, and I applaud any movement in this direction nationally or internationally.
I am not able to comment further on the French initiatives until I am able to study them in detail. I will undertake to examine these initiatives and report further to the honourable senator.
